conclusion: Data collection done by corporations is good for consumer
premises: past few years there have been lot of news about companies collecting and selling user data. this has basically turned your phone into tracking tool that can make calls. there are several reasons why companies collect data but most prominent one is that they create a profile of you and sell it to advertisers. holy grail of data profile is to 'copy' persons identity to that extend that it can predict what are persons preferences even before person knows themselves. and to be clear in this context i use word advertiser in a broad way including companies, charities and even political or religious parties. anyone that want you to do or buy something. most of the ads are just informational telling you about the product but some are promotional giving you a discount on a product . these were my premises . companies offer products free or at low cost but in order to make profit they turn your behavior to ad profile. profile is sold to advertisers that inform you about their product in hope of you buying. but here is the catch. at the end of the day it is your choice to act . maybe you liked the ad maybe you didn't. all the ads do is inform that the product that you might like according to your previous behavior exist. it doesn't limit your options or force you to do anything. you can still do your own research and find competitive products and pick the one that you really want or even choose not to buy any of them. amp; x200b; you might have more information on one brand than another but thanks to ads you have more information than without them. ads saves you some time doing research and you might find products that you didn't know that existed without the personalized ads. if the profile is well done, it might offer you things that you would like but didn't know where to find. they offer you more options and according to your preferences these options are most likely ones that you might consider once you have been informed about them. amp; x200b; third benefit of personalized ads is that they offer you discount time to times. not all ads do this but some does. and if you want to have some product ad from store that you don't normally use might save you some money. we wouldn't have google search engine or facebook social media if they would require a subscription. some say that you pay for these free services with your privacy. i say you get free services and personalized ads that are both good things. i can always close my device and choose not to watch ads when i want privacy. amp; x200b; in order to chance my view you have to show how cons of personalized ads out weight their benefits.

auto_conc: there is nothing wrong with advertisers collecting your data and selling it to them
gt: 1. my information could be used to harm me. a burglar would be happy to know when i have a vacation along with my home address, a pedophile would be happy to know what route my kid takes from school, and any blackmailer would be happy to know that i'm gay and my family doesn't know about me. 2. in many cases, not only i don't get any free or discounted stuff, but in many cases i need to pay more. health and life insurance would expect me to have a shorter life expectancy if the find out i'm smoking, and it means i will pay them for less time until they need to pay me back. 3. my information is worth money, and i should have it. very rarely corporations give you access to all the information they know about you, and in most cases they don't even tell you what information they have or even that they have any information . 4. mislabeling. i can see from your profile that you once said something about preplanning a character in the context of rpgs. i don't like this idea in my games, and when i'm looking for players for my game, i will exclude you. my ai doesn't know what you wrote inside it might have been a discussion, i didn't read , but it already flagged you for it. as you can see, it's not fair for you, it opens the rules for abuse create many profiles so you bypass all filters, giving you unfair advantage over more decent players , and could make me miss a great player amongst all the abusers.

conclusion: The pronoun problem is really about attitudes, not assumptions
premises: agitation about gendered language only occurs because people with a bigoted or intolerant attitude refuse to comply with requests to use a different term. people arguing about this issue are conflating respect with agreement and endorsement. i have a legal obligation to tolerate others, and to be polite i should go further to respect people, even if they are different than me. all this means is using the right pronouns if i m corrected. anything beyond this basic respect is completely optional because it s based in opinion, not fact. this article presents some strong but faulty claims about why we supposedly shouldn t make assumptions and instead should ask for people s pronouns. the argument fails, however, because the premises are disputable. many theories of gender exist, and even in academic disciplines and modern feminism there is no consensus on what gender is or does. if it is disrespectful to reference apparent gender, why do we have gender at all and consider it so important? briefly, the issues are: gender is a social construct, but the article claims it to be individual many people and theorists disagree with the idea that gender is individual or innate and mental the article s theory of gender is neither accurate nor descriptive of society gender is much more than a mental state or identity, as it influences a lot there is no universal agreement on how to define gender; the article s way is one of many, not the only way. gender as tied to biology, performance, appearance, and mind all have certain validity, especially when considering how gender is referred to i do not buy the idea that gender stems from or perpetuates oppression. most people like and support our ideas of gender; if you are happy under the current system, it s not oppressive to you. the few that don t support them deserve accommodation, but otherwise it s something they have to live with. ultimately, my conclusion is that i should give people basic respect, but i have no obligation to endorse theories which i disagree with. we re allowed to disagree on societal issues; it is neither bigotry nor lack of respect. that would only be if i did not grant you the respect of using your pronouns when you informed me. to say otherwise would be no different than arguing that a pro gun supporter is a murderer, or is responsible or pushing for school shootings. tl;dr: gender is really complicated. what we do now is good, but also respect what people ask you to do. there are many ideas of how to approach gender, and we are allowed to disagree on what gender is and does. cmv

gt: i think the issue here stems to when you made the claim that you have zero legal obligations to refer to someone by their preferred pronoun. there are many places which are starting to label misuse of pronouns as hate speech. this doesn't come down to being a bigot or intolerant, this comes down being able to speak freely with out criminal prosecution. i agree we need to be polite, but under the constitution i'm allowed to refer to you as what ever i want to.

'

gt: i ll try to answer this one by walking through some premises that fit together:god loves all his children. because he loves his children, he wants them to experience the joy and glory that he experiences. he wants his children to become like him. this requires that they have experiences to learn and to grow. in order for his children to have these experiences, god created a world for them to live on. through adam and eve, this world became a fallen world a world which includes pain and suffering, unfairness, and requires work. this is a necessary step in god s plan to teach his children and help them grow. they must be allowed to live in a fallen world away from his presence and progress by choosing to do good even though they are not with him. i suppose the best way to describe what i mean by fallen world is a world which includes entropy, a gradual decline into disorder. there s a duality here god s children cannot know true joy unless they have experienced sorrow no pleasure without pain, no virtue without vice. in short, god sends his children to a fallen world so that they might be able to experience both the good and the bad, and learn to choose the good. as other commenters have mentioned, free will is an essential part of god s plan for his children. god does not generally intervene and infringe upon the free will given to his children, even if not intervening means that there will be suffering. not all suffering is caused by free will, and i see that your argument is mainly related to this type of suffering suffering not caused by the free will of others. in my belief, this suffering comes because of the fallen world we live in. our physical bodies are imperfect, and are subject to horrible things like cancer. god allows this because people learn from suffering and because he has a plan for everything to be made right in the next life. this life can be viewed as but a small moment in an eternity of growth and progression. if one believes in a life after this, and that the growth and experiences received here will be carried into the next life, one can believe that all experiences on earth, both positive and negative, make it possible for god s children to experience the joy of becoming more like him. if god loves his children, then he wants the best for them, and the best gift he can offer them is the type of life he lives. now, since according to scripture, no unclean thing can enter into god s presence, all of his children that came to live in this fallen world, no matter what they do, are prevented from returning to his physical presence after death. this on its own would completely foil his plan to allow his children to return to live with him with the knowledge and growth they gained on earth. because god loves his children, he provided a way that this obstacle could be overcome. he sent jesus, whose atoning sacrifice provided the reconciliation necessary for his children to be able to return to god s presence after death. if you believe in jesus, you believe that his great suffering and sacrifice is the way through which god is able to make fair all that was unfair in this life. you give the specific case of the vast number of children that die every year this is a great question that causes many to ask your very same question. the question, your question, is: how can we believe god loves his children when their is so much suffering, especially when those suffering are innocent children? the answer requires acceptance of the premises explained above that:1. this life is not all. 2. this life is the means to an end, which end is joy in the presence of god. 3. god provided a way that all that is unfair in this life can be made right in an eternal perspective. 4. the suffering we experience in this life intimately helps us to grow and progress this progression is essential in an eternal perspective. specifically, depending on which judeo christian religion you ask about children that die, you ll get different answers. here s the answer that makes sense to me given the above premises:children and innocents who suffer and die early in this life will have everything made right in the next life. babies that die go to heaven. in summary, you can reconcile the suffering that takes place in this world and the statement that god loves his children if you believe in the statements above. even if you don t believe in the statements, you can still accept that this is how those who do believe in god reconcile believing that he loves them with the suffering in the world.

gt: although the eu is not a federation or structured in the same way as the united states, it s certainly reasonable to draw parallels. for the us, each state is partially sovereign, but also a part of the overall federation. they are granted representatives in two ways. one way is weighted based on the population of its member states. that s the house of representatives. the other is based on the virtue of being a state. prior to the creation of the the federal government, each state made a conscious agreement to join based on different contingencies. the more populated states have more of a voice in the federal government. but the less populated states would not have been incentivized to join if their voice was almost entirely drowned out by other states with larger populations. so they came up with the connecticut compromise to make an adjustment so that those less populated states had both representation based on population and the virtue of being a state. now, although again it s not a perfect parallel, 4 countries make up 50 of the population of the eu. if germany, france, uk, and italy had more similar interests than the other 24 and voted solely based on population, they could enact policies that harm the other 86 of member states. the us federal government is set up in a way where this won t happen. more populated states still get louder voices, but the representation of the states is corrected to a fair way that their membership was predicated on. more populous states have their representation corrected downwards, less populated states have their membership corrected upwards, but the rank order of the representation of all states still falls perfectly in line with their population. and they all agreed to this, again due to the weight of their population and the virtue of being a state. it would be entirely unfair to backtrack and revise the structure of representation without giving the delawares and wyomings and north dakotas the choice to leave the federation.

conclusion: Providing a cure for homosexuality is better than advocating for its acceptance
premises: so i think its pretty obvious which post made motivated to do this. the persecution of gays in the middle east, for example. dont get me wrong, ive got nothing against homosexuality but itd be so much more convenient if we were able to eradicate it. also im not suggesting that gays should be forced to accept the pill. if you want to live a life that is not full of stigmatism, thats completely on you.

auto_conc: I think homosexuality should be eradicated, cmv
gt: straight guy here. this seems to hit a similar parallel to a i read earlier this week saying that a theoretical pill could be offered to correct the mind dealing with gender dysphoria and or someone that is transgender. basically, first off, calling it a cure is quite strong and can be seen as insulting to those who are homosexual. there s nothing specifically wrong with being gay, thus there s nothing to cure. furthermore, let s say that there was a pill or medical treatment similar to the aforementioned where it would turn a homosexual into a heterosexual person, then you re having the person completely re work how they interact with society, how they speak to people of both sexes, and who they decide to mate with. in essence, you re changing the their personality, who they love, and how they give receive pleasure. that alone may outweigh the social stigma they may experience by some. lastly, this doesn t fix the issue of people being intolerant or downright hatred of homosexual people. thusly, you re not fixing any issue whatsoever, since the problem is still there.

conclusion: Pascal's Wager is ultimately meaningless because it ignores the existence of other religions.
premises: arguments for the belief in a god or gods fascinate me, but none have ever really made me question my agnosticism as much as pascal's wager. amp; x200b; what immediately occured to me, however, is that the wager assumes that there are only two possibilities: the christian god exists, or he doesn't, describing it at one point as a 'con flip'. in fact, one could even suppose that there an infinite number of such possible gods. amp; x200b; i think logical proof should be answered with logical proof, so i drafted a quick counter argument. i am by no means a logican or a philosopher, so i fully expect there to be holes in my argument, and i would welcome criticism of it so that i can either improve it or discard it. i think arguments 10 and 11 are where this argument is weakest, and i d love to hear suggestions for how to prove the probabilistic application of averages. amp; x200b; 1. god is, or god is not. reason cannot decide between the two alternatives. 2. 3. choosing the correct god provides infinite benefit. 4. 5. it logically follows from 3 that the set of all possible values for the number of gods is the set of all natural numbers. 6. since the set increments at a linear rate, the median of the set is equal to the average. 7. the position of the median in a set can determined by dividing the size of the set by two. 8. any infinite number divided by a finite number is infinite. the limit of f x x 2 as x approaches infinity is infinity 9. it could be said then, that the average value of this set is infinity. 10. in a universe where it could be proved that there were between one and three gods, it would be most logical to make probabilistic decisions assuming there are two gods, just as it is most logical to make decisions about dice considering the average result of that die. 11. thus, it makes most sense to make probabilistic decisions assuming that there are an infinite number of possible gods. 12. if there are an infinite number of possible gods, the chance of choosing the right one approaches 0, just as the rewards from picking the correct one approach infinity. 13. if one has an infinitesimally small chance at an infinitely big reward, one can say that the expected value of the choice is undefined and that the reward is thus irrelevant. amp; x200b; i'm pretty sure this makes sense, but if you disagree, then please, cmv.

x200b; what immediately occured to me, however, is that the wager assumes that there are only two possibilities: the christian god exists, or he doesn't, describing it at one point as a 'con flip'. in fact, one could even suppose that there an infinite number of such possible gods. amp; x200b; i think logical proof should be answered with logical proof, so i drafted a quick counter argument. i am by no means a logican or a philosopher, so i fully expect there to be holes in my argument, and i would welcome criticism of it so that i can either improve it or discard it. i think arguments 10 and 11 are where this argument is weakest, and i d love to hear suggestions for how to prove the probabilistic application of averages. amp; x200b; i'm pretty sure this makes sense, but if you disagree, then please, cmv.
auto_conc: pascal's wager is logically indefensible.
gt: you forgot to include the by your logic infinite number of gods that are willing to accept followers that follow the correct principles even if they don't know or follow any god. do good by your friends, family, and neighbors. if there are gods and they are just, then they will appreciate your good works. if there are gods and they are unjust, then they are not worth worshiping or following. if there are no gods, then you will be remembered favorably by those you encountered, and if there's no afterlife, then that's the best you can hope for.
masked_conc_attacks: the problem with pascal's wager is that it assumes that there are only two possible gods. if there are two gods, then the probability of picking the right one is 0. if you pick the wrong one, then there is a probability of choosing the right god. if i choose the wrong god, then i have no chance of choosing either god.
known_conc_attacks: i don't know what you're talking about, but i'm going to try and change your view. if god is unknowable, then it's not logical to assume that god is not unknowable. if there is a god, then there is no reason to assume he isn't unknowable either.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't know about you, but pascal's wager is a bit of a strawman. it assumes that there are only two possible gods, and that the probability of choosing the correct one approaches infinity. however, it doesn't assume that there is only one god. the only way to prove this is to prove that god exists is by proving that he doesn't. if you believe that god doesn't exist, then you are assuming that god does exist.

conclusion: Cheating is unforgivable because it shows horrible character and lack of self control. Forgiving this shows lack of self respect.
premises: i noticed that cheating has been normalized especially with people of color poc in the media and in real life. it's sexist if you ask me. let me first define cheating. cheating is telling your partner you won't be having a sexual or romantic relationship outside your relationship, but still doing it. it's not considered cheating to me if it's an open relationship or you were forced with violence and whatnot. also, when talking of relationships, i mean mutual relationships that have or had love in them. i don't want to hear of forced marriages, abusive relationships, or bad arranged marriages cause those have a very different dynamic from what i'm thinking about. if the passion has died in your relationship, it is better to break off the relationship. i don't mean divorce though cause i know that involves money and can be messy, but people can acknowledge the death of a relationship and separate at least. to me, if you cheat that means you don't love your so. if you really love your so and understand the pain it would cause them, you wouldn't consider cheating. if your so is having problems sexually and you cheat, that's basically showing that sexual satisfaction was more important than the emotional bond you shared. there's also many ways to attempt to resolve this issue. and if it's that big of a deal and unsolvable, you can move on to an open relationship or seperate break up. people who take back those who cheat come off as extremely desperate for the financial benefits in the relationship and or the emotional support they felt in the relationship. i feel when people take back people who cheat, it's because they don't feel they'll ever find anyone to replace what they had which can be a valid point, but still sad desperate . imo i feel it's a better bet to live the rest of your life without a cheater than with someone who will disrespect your emotions like that. i feel this all makes perfect sense, but it's like the older i get the more people are acting like i'm living in fantasy land. beautiful independent women are taking back horrible men after cheating with multiple women. great men are taking back women who cheat too. what's going on?

auto_conc: it's better to break up with your partner than to continue the relationship with them.
gt: an aspect of forgiveness for cheating that many most? people consistently undervalue is that while cheating is a horrible thing to do to a person, it doesn't necessarily disregard the entire history that two people may have shared together. i've seen several older couples that find out one of the people cheated over decades. to be sure, once that knowledge is out, the relationship is forever changed. also note, that there was a huge discrepancy in the two people's understandings of what the relationship was to begin with. one person thought they were both being faithful, the other spent a significant amount of energy hiding some amount of their activities from their partner. once cheating becomes known, the relationship cannot be what it was, because it wasn't what it was claiming to be before that point anyway. to get back to why someone might forgive a cheater and it's ok: have you tried dating people? 90 of the people you will find in the dating pool are just not a good match for you, and a significant portion of those people are just not ready for a meaningful relationship to begin with. comparing that to a partner who cheated, in a simple pros cons format, will often place the cheater on the better side of the comparison, even with the huge 'cheated on me' con. the relationship likely had many positives before the cheating was known, and most of those positives haven't changed. ie: if the partner was worth staying with before the cheating and actively making the subjects life better, then once the cheating is known, they aren't making the subjects life as good as they once were, but it's still a net positive. going back to the older couples, sometimes it just isn't worth it to go back into the dating pool, you simply don't have enough time left in this world for it to be worth it. you might argue that is because they are showing less self respect, but i would argue that is merely accepting the facts of life. the world is what it is and you can do a simple math analysis on how many years it takes to get to a point of trust with a person. clearly, a cheater has ruined a significant amount of trust, especially physical intimacy, but relationships are about a lot more than that, and a truly sorry cheater can spend the rest of their years how many years is that anyway? making it up to their partner. not a very romantic solution, but definitely a situation that favors the forgiver. you mentioned the financial aspects of a relationship, and cheating actually has basically 0 impact on that. i once sat in a psychology class having to write an argument about the phrase 'those who marry for money get all that they deserve' and my only critique on the statement was 'why are the words 'for money' in that sentence? those who marry get all that they deserve, it doesn't matter what your reasons are, if you marry purely for love, you're just as big a fool' maybe the love is gone, maybe they aren't a really big fan of their partner personally, but the financial aspects of the marriage mean their whole life is fairly easy as long as they don't separate, or in some cases, initiate separation. this can, again, be a net positive. sometimes, people are just punishing themselves or whatever by keeping a cheater, but a lot of the time, it's not so much forgiving the cheater for cheating as much as acknowledging that life is just better by keeping them, even though it will never be as good as it might have seemed. that might sound depressing, but i've seen it in action. i've seen someone leave a cheater, only to come back 4 years later because things just weren't working out, and life with a cheater is better than what it was without the cheater. easy decision to make from that perspective. typo's and stuff, at this point i'm done.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that cheating is bad for the person who cheated. it's not like cheating is a bad thing for the people who cheated, it's just that it's a bad way to live your life. if you don't want to be in a relationship with someone who cheats, then you shouldn't be in that relationship. but if you're in a monogamous relationship, and you want to stay in one, then that's fine, but that's not the same thing as cheating.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you. however, i think you're missing the point of the argument. the argument is that cheating is a bad thing to do, and that it is morally wrong to do it. that is, if you don't want to be cheated on, you shouldn't be in the relationship. if you want to have sex with someone you love, you should be in a relationship with them, not with someone who doesn't love you.
auto_conc_attacks: you are correct that cheating is a terrible thing to do, but you are also correct that it is a bad thing to break up with your partner. however, i don't think it is necessarily better to break off with your so than to continue the relationship with them. if you are a good person, you will be a better person if you don't cheat.

conclusion: There is no valid reason to act in a moral way. Ethics are redundant, and individuals should be egocentric.
premises: when we see a happy person, we share a part of their joy. this is caused by the process of empathy, for which the anterior insular cortex is responsible. that is a region of the brain near the amygdala. seeing fellow humans happy caused them to be happy, therefore they began to be moral. initially, they carved flowers in cave walls, later they wrote proposals and tractates on parchments, and eventually philosophers such as aristotle formed the organized system of ethics. they have been taught this by their parents, learned that in school, came to that conclusion by talking with their peers etc they prevail everywhere around the world, and change is difficult and slow. aside from machiavelli, whose views only roughly correspond with modern day machiavellianism, ayn rand was one of the first philosophers who suggested egocentrism. that was only around 70 years ago. also, humans still take joy in the happiness of other humans. they are fond of the delight of their friends, lovers, parents etc they are motivated to make self sacrifices for the sake of other people. there's nothing wrong with 'second hand happiness'. if you love your wife and buy her flowers, she'll be happy. assuming you have an unimpaired amygdala, you will also be happy for her. that's how the brain works. i feel that what i'm about to say now might be superfluous, but i also anticipate that people will bring it up if i don't cover it immediately. wish your co worker good day, and he might volunteer to handle some of your assignments. however, sometimes initial rewards are more valuable than relationship enhancement. say your neighbor is looking for a thousand dollar bill and he can't find it. you find it and pocket it swiftly without him noticing. now, if you gave it to him, he'd most likely be grateful. he might cut your grass, invite you for lunch; but if you take the 1000 you will be rewarded by something far better, money. a moral person would return the money. an egocentric person would keep it. additionally, i would like to point out that in most cases, and this one, those who do something are the ones who have a higher duty to explain it. we shouldn't be ethical 'just because' or due to it being 'good'. amp; x200b;

conclusion: The word god shouldn't be used if you can't define it as a being
premises: words, as always, change in meaning over time, they morph and adapt as people choose to use them. this facet of language is often abused in discussions. this is a reason why it's helpful to banish ambiguous words so that they're forced to be swapped by the full intention behind them instead of the words themselves. however, i'm not of the opinion that we should rely on the dictionary as the tool closing the deal for what the definitions are. i don't have anything against ambiguity and fluidity of meanings however my point is that when two persons want to convey meaning to one another they have to be on the same ground. so here's my point: there's a surging trend these days of calling yourself a believer in god but not being able to qualify it and not accepting any attribute that others want to associate with it. the only attributes those people claim are not really valid in my opinion. for example: god is the starting point of the universe though not agreeing on if he has a mind or not, or any of its will, or any criteria for that matter god is the universe itself same as above, this doesn't tell us anything about it a sort of pantheism but that isn't with a mind or will. from my view i think this is highly confusing. i would call this atheism but those persons would still refer to themselves as theists or deists because they've chosen to keep using the word god. in some cases those persons even adhere to a religion or at least follow a certain set of ways of living, a system of values related to it. maybe this is vague and those persons just don't want to offend anyone. this seems like a weak position to me. is it still a guide of life? there used to be a time when we fought over the exact attributes that the gods of certain religions possessed, and before that deities were more anchored in reality even taking human forms as kings. is this a move from the personal religion to a new kind of religious transition? making peace between faith and rationality? deities being more vague than ever? however i'm open to changing my view if anyone is able to relate to situation in my post.

conclusion: The Term LGBTQIA+ is Actively Harmful Towards the Cause it Tries to Support Because it Drives Away Potential Supporters for Being... Too Much.
premises: let me explain what i mean by this. i recently came across an ad for the democratic party in which people in regular clothes held up cardboard placards with the group or cause they were advocating for written on them. women s rights , racial equality , etc. what i found particularly eyecatching was a young man who said, i support the lgbtqa community , or the like. at that statement, i cringed. before i say anything else, i want to mention that i am by no means homophobic i have friends who are gay, how could i possibly be homophobic? i support equality for all, and find it ridiculous that in 2018 we still come to an agreement as a nation what consists a marriage, and what is equality. that said, i believe there is absolutely no need to add the two three new categories to the already wordy phrase, as if trying to say that people who fall under those categories were not already represented with lgbt, and especially q: intersex, asexual, and allies who are heterosexual . i have voiced my concerns in the past about how the term feminist may possibly have an adverse effect because those who are already colored to believe that presently the two sexes are equal enough already are going to reject the term, believing the term to mean what it does not: advocacy for the supremacy of the female gender, above the male. i have since recinded that argument, partly because i believe now that to force society to change certain aspects of revolutionary concepts need to be superlatively termed to give them the attention they need, and partly because i am a man and it s really really difficult to say the above to a well concerning woman. in the case of lgbtqia , i ask again what is gained by the addition of three extra categories? lesbian, gay, and transgender are self explanatory. bisexual i had trouble in the past because as a heterosexual man i could not comprehend why those who are both homo and heterosexual would want a whole different category to describe them in advocacy, but i ve come around to accept the notion that they are different from lgt. i did not exactly know what queer meant until a few years ago when that term was added into the already existing lgbt , and the way it was explained to me was they represent all of those sexual minorities who are neither heterosexual or transgender, a sort of umbrella term to make sure that nobody is left unrepresented. what would the addition of those who are asexual or intersexed, and hetero but supporting address exactly? let me say, in my opinion, what the addition does . it creates further confusion for those who are on the fence about the issues of gender and sex. it makes the group less appealing to stand for if you were already against the movement wait, you re telling me they added another category of people?

gt: i love all animals. some i love as pets, others i love as food because they are delicious, others i love because they are cute. so yes i m an animal lover. i would note that plants talk to each other. the smell we associate with freshly cut grass is actually a chemical distress call, one used by plants to beg nearby critters to save them from attack usually it's an affront by insects, but in this case, it's lawnmower blades . after all, when danger strikes whether it's landscaping equipment or a hungry caterpillar plants can't lift their roots and run. they must fight where they stand. according to researchers at the institute for applied physics at the university of bonn in germany, plants release gases that are the equivalent of crying out in pain. using a laser powered microphone, researchers have picked up sound waves produced by plants releasing gases when cut or injured. although not audible to the human ear, the secret voices of plants have revealed that cucumbers scream when they are sick, and flowers whine when their leaves are cut source: deutsche welle .

premises: you've probably heard of the new 'deepfake' technique for swapping faces in video or images by now, and the fact that it is often used to creating fake porn of celebrities etc. but i don't really think so. i think it is perfectly fine to make and even publicly post such media. i guess the reasons why i think so can be summed into three main points: 1. it's not real. it's fiction. it doesn't represent an actual event. there isn't really any meaningful difference between this and a bad photoshop, or a caricature drawing, or even fanfiction text. it just looks more real, but why does that really matter? no matter how real it looks, it isn't . it may look uncomfortable to some people to see what looks like themselves in vulgar scenes, but just because something is uncomfortable to look at to some, does not mean it is inherently immoral. 2. you don't own the image of your face. every day you willingly give it away by walking in public or posting selfies of yourself online. this is especially true for celebrities. it's almost their job to make their appearance as widely known as possible. and even if you don't, you're not entitled to 'own' illustrations of yourself like a copyrighted piece of art anyway, at least not by default. it's human nature for people to remember how other people look and picture them in their heads, even in thoughts such as sexual fantasies. and if that's okay then i don't understand why it's not okay to just copy these thoughts into a tangible format such as an illustration. 3. technology is ever improving, and faked imagery is only going to get more realistic and easy to produce. i'm sure last century there were people equally offended by faked porn that would to our eyes look ridiculously bad and unrealistic. fakes are here to stay, and we need to adapt our sense of morality to reflect this reality. i believe this will happen and such images will get normalized sooner or later either way, but i think it would be in everyone's interest to just get it over with and make it sooner rather than later.

conclusion: 4chans algorithm for discussion threads is superior to Reddits.
premises: the more people comment on a post, the longer it stays on the front page. i think this is preferable to the upvote downvote system because that means the most contentious and engaged topics are what is seen. too many interesting posts on reddit go unnoticed due to rigorous downvoting. sometimes a publication like national review can put out a very interesting article but it will never be seen on r politics due to the left slant of most of its user base and the barrage of downvotes such a post would receive. if such a post were instead ranked based on interaction rather than voting, i think you d see a more diverse range of topics. i don t want to single out r politics but it s the easiest sub that comes to mind. it d be nice if the material that is visible was ranked on how much discussion it creates rather than how much it pleases the crowd. this way a few downvotes early on cannot bury a post, the only thing that can do that is being so uninteresting that nobody bothers to comment on it.

conclusion: No person in the world is justified to say nigger or any variation of the word, so it should be removed from casual language entirely.
premises: this comes from the recent outcry against the white woman who, while singing along with kendrick lamar on stage at one of his concerts, said nigga multiple times as it was part of the song lyrics. why must we, as equal humans living in a modern progressive world, continue to use a word whose origins are rich in slavery, oppression, and discrimination? instead of being used by whites to oppress blacks, it has a newfound power by blacks, as whites are heavily criticized when they use it. this has not solved the issue that it originally created, this instead has caused a societal shift that has simply changed the hands of the people in power of it. the argument that it has a different, discriminatory meaning when said by non blacks is outrageous. i ll continue my argument with a quote: people respond in accordance to how you relate to them. if you approach them on the basis of violence, that s how they ll react. but if you say we want peace, we want stability, we can then do a lot of things that will contribute towards the progress of our society. nelson mandela turning the anger against whites juxtaposes the seemingly impossible task of creating peace and cooperation. in the case of the kendrick lamar concert, the white woman on stage, the fellow singers in the crowd, and lamar himself were all equally at fault for saying nigga . similarly, it is not compromise when one side loses all power and the other side gains it all, as in the case of the word now only being acceptable when said by blacks, and this lack of stability will not contribute to the progress of our society, that mandela, and the rest of us, desire. this argument is, however, not countering its usage in historical contexts, as in the case of older documents or books such as to kill a mockingbird. in these special cases, we cannot ignore history in its pure form, and we use these cases as fuel for the progressive fire that will bring us to peace.

conclusion: Websites should not have mandatory limitations on passwords.
premises: by forcing a password to be over 8 characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that are less than 8 characters. by forcing a password to contain numbers and or special characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that do not contain numbers and or special characters. most people use patterns when adding numbers and special characters to accounts. they replace certain letters with numbers sp chars, or they add the numbers sp chars to the end. when passwords are forced to be more complicated, or when websites force users to change their passwords often, the odds of users forgetting passwords will increase. as someone who has worked in it, i can say that the easiest way to guess a user's password is to read the stickynote stuck to the computer. people write down passwords when they can't remember them. it makes it very easy to gain access to their account; even easier than if they had a very common password such as 'letmein'. when users forget passwords often, websites employ methods such as attaching email addresses, phone numbers, social media accounts, and recovery questions to the account. this reduces overall security, because if any of those things i just mentioned are hacked, then a 'hacker' can easily gain access to the user's account without having to guess their password. for example, if i can see that their account recovery question is 'what was my mother's maiden name? ' , then that is almost certainly easier to guess than it would be to guess their password. the overall security is reduced. instead of forcing password restrictions, users should have the freedom to choose a password as 'strong' or as 'weak' as they wish. inform the users when they are making their account how strong their passwords are, and give recommendations. but at the end of the day, let the user choose whatever password they wish at their own discretion. cmv!
argument: Websites should not have mandatory limitations on passwords. : by forcing a password to be over 8 characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that are less than 8 characters. by forcing a password to contain numbers and or special characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that do not contain numbers and or special characters. most people use patterns when adding numbers and special characters to accounts. they replace certain letters with numbers sp chars, or they add the numbers sp chars to the end. when passwords are forced to be more complicated, or when websites force users to change their passwords often, the odds of users forgetting passwords will increase. as someone who has worked in it, i can say that the easiest way to guess a user's password is to read the stickynote stuck to the computer. people write down passwords when they can't remember them. it makes it very easy to gain access to their account; even easier than if they had a very common password such as 'letmein'. when users forget passwords often, websites employ methods such as attaching email addresses, phone numbers, social media accounts, and recovery questions to the account. this reduces overall security, because if any of those things i just mentioned are hacked, then a 'hacker' can easily gain access to the user's account without having to guess their password. for example, if i can see that their account recovery question is 'what was my mother's maiden name? ' , then that is almost certainly easier to guess than it would be to guess their password. the overall security is reduced. instead of forcing password restrictions, users should have the freedom to choose a password as 'strong' or as 'weak' as they wish. inform the users when they are making their account how strong their passwords are, and give recommendations. but at the end of the day, let the user choose whatever password they wish at their own discretion. cmv!
auto_conc: websites should not force you to make a password that includes numbers and special characters
gt: as someone who works in it, you should know the common methods for obtaining passwords. using brute force is one of the more common methods, and passwords with less characters are a lot easier to guess than with more. using 8 characters as a minimum with special characters and capital letters gives 95 8 possible passwords. that s over 6. 6 quadrillion possibilities. 6 with fifteen 0s . modern cpus can t crunch that many passwords in a reasonable amount of time. reducing the requirements makes it a lot easier to hack into. as for the physical methods, those are assuming that the hacker has access to the physical locations. in those cases there is usually some sort of physical security to the location to prevent it. not always but in that case, it doesn t matter how easy or complicated the password is. forgetting the password and using password recovery is always a method that can be breached. which is why more websites are using 2 factor authentication instead, where they send a text message instead of email. finally, it is not the website s responsibility to ensure that users keep their password stored or remembered. it s their responsibility to make sure that their website is secured, and provide a method for users to recover it. so enforcing higher security for passwords is the most they can do.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about, but i don't think there's anything inherently wrong with forcing a user to change their password. it seems like you're saying that forcing a password to contain numbers or special characters is a bad thing, but that's not the case. the problem is that many people don't have the time or inclination to change the password. if they do, they're going to have to resort to brute force to get around it. it's not like they're forcing people to change passwords, it's just that they don't want to do it.
known_conc_attacks: the problem with this is that most of the time it's not the user's fault for not remembering their password, it's the website's fault that they can't remember their password.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure if this is a good idea or not, but i'd like to point out that a lot of websites do not force you to make a password that includes numbers and or special characters. they do it because they don't want to.

conclusion: Diversity of beliefs and thoughts is way more important than diversity of identity
premises: it's a pretty simple one. few people complain about how the majority of young people and the media are liberal, and mostly circlejerk in echo chambers of opinions. now i will acknowledge sometimes identity automatically gives you a different viewpoint. for example, diversity matters when talking about islam, because a muslim can talk from experience. but i dont think having a muslim person in unrelated cases is worth anything just because they're muslim. in general, i'd rather have a board of 10 straight white males with all differing political stances and opinions than a board of black, white, men, women, and whatever else inbetween that all have leftist opinions. if that makes any sense. cmv.
argument: Diversity of beliefs and thoughts is way more important than diversity of identity : it's a pretty simple one. few people complain about how the majority of young people and the media are liberal, and mostly circlejerk in echo chambers of opinions. now i will acknowledge sometimes identity automatically gives you a different viewpoint. for example, diversity matters when talking about islam, because a muslim can talk from experience. but i dont think having a muslim person in unrelated cases is worth anything just because they're muslim. in general, i'd rather have a board of 10 straight white males with all differing political stances and opinions than a board of black, white, men, women, and whatever else inbetween that all have leftist opinions. if that makes any sense. cmv.
auto_conc: I think diversity of thought is more important than diversity of people.
gt: i think diversity of perspectives and expertise is the most important thing. thinking about it in terms of my work as a scientist, i've found a lot of value in working with people with diverse training. i work in one area of biology that intersects with a lot of other fields, and i'd rather tackle most projects with a team of smart people that includes a math major and a chemistry major than three biology majors. i've worked with people from a variety of demographic backgrounds and i think about them primarily in terms of what they're good at doing; their race and sexuality are irrelevant. however, politically, all of these people range from center left to far left. i have never worked with a conservative professionally, because they either don't want to go into my field or don't make the cut. there is no ideological litmus test that stops conservatives from becoming scientists. they're not being persecuted. they just don't make it. part of the issue is that conservatism in the modern american form holds some very stupid ideas that repel intelligent people who have a wide range of life experiences. for example, anyone who goes to college for several years is likely to have at least a few gay friends and want them to be happily married if they so choose. it's hard for someone who knows several gays as normal people who want to live normal lives to be afraid of them getting married or see it as a threat; that view can come only from unfamiliarity and or fervent belief in a self contradictory book of ancient fables. conservatism is also closely associated with several anti science views and policy actions, including rejecting evolution and denying the existence of anthropogenic climate change. people intelligent enough to become scientists are very unlikely to hold those conservative views. likewise, scientists are likely to have traveled quite a bit for research and to conferences, and to have lived in several different places; all of these things provide some exposure to other cultures and reduce the fear of other cultures, or of mixing of cultures, that's implicit in mainstream conservative positions on issues like immigration. if you were to insist that teams of scientists must have political views proportional to those of the country at large basically affirmative action for political views you'd have to reach for completely unqualified people to fill the conservative spots, and they'd have nothing to do but sit around picking their noses. conservatism in general rarely imbues somebody with ideas that make them valuable for any task, and certainly not in the way a different measure of diversity of knowledge such as college major does. there is certainly a role for center right conservatives, or at least for centrists, in opposing the occasional excesses of the far left. i would like to see a reasonable, good faith opposition to the far left as a moderating force in our politics. but conservatives who fit that mould are pretty rare.

conclusion: the story of Job teaches no valuable lessons, other than God is a jerk.
premises: by this i mean that the book doesn't contain any notable insights nor does it resolve any interesting theological questions, albeit i personally love it as a piece of absurdist fiction. worse than that, it seems to be undermining the very religion of whose holy text it belongs to. the book revolves a lot about theodicy; the problem of evil in the world. how can bad things happen to good people, and vice versa? the closest thing the book gives to an answer, is that we puny mortals can't grasp it. the israelites are taught time and again, that the reason they're getting slaughtered by fillistines or robbed and exiled is because they have turned away from god and sinned. they are led to believe, convinced by prophets send by god, that their actions have consequences corresponding to their sins. obviously when job suddenly gets hit by outrageous misfortune, his friends believe him to have committed some secret sin to cause it. we know however, that no such cause exists, and that god just wanted to prove a point to a buddy. god even scolds the friends for assuming that jobs misfortunes were caused by sin, like they have been repeatedly taught by him. all through the bible people are explicitly being punished or provided for according to their sins. by punishing job he is undermining the coherency of his followers, by denying them the belief that has kept them together through suffering and exile; that their suffering isn't pointless, and that it's all just and right. even if job gets richer in the end, how about his original sons and daughters who died horrible deaths for no reason? in the book satan raises the question of the possibility of selfless righteousness. some people are righteous whilst reaping no benefit whatsoever. the problem of unpunished evil goes completely unanswered. also, whether job even remains faithful is, in my opinion, up to debate. is it faith to maintain that god is injust and unfair? he repents at the end, but i would say satan won the bet here. furthermore, job is obviously right in saying that he is punished through no fault of his own, and therefore unfairly. he never explains how his action was fair, apparently because 'god works in mysterious ways' tm and no human could ever understand. except we can, it's right there, black on white, in the beginning: god punished job to prove a point to satan, and if people can't grasp the reasons for their suffering, they are probably either nonexisting or preposterous as they are in the case of job . basically the take away seems to be that sometimes, god is just a bully. phew, sorry about the rant, really needed to get this off my chest. anyways, i know that there are much more knowledgeable people than me in this sub, so i hope you can show me where i've completely missed the point which is probably the case and tell me why i'm wrong!

conclusion: I believe that it is both a waste of resources and unjustifiably selfish to have children in these times. I would go so far as to say its immoral.
premises: i got into an argument with someone over my opinion today, and they weren t able to articulate a convincing counter argument so i m wondering if one of you might be able to. my thinking is thus: we are living in an era of upheaval and political unrest all around the globe. we are just beginning to feel the effects of global warming and climate change, and in the years to come the effects will become even more dramatic. the planet is overpopulated. and it s been estimated that there are 153 million orphans around the world who need homes. if you simply must have a child, adopt one of the many who need a family. with all that said, what incentive is there for having a biological child? some people want to have a child that shares their dna, that looks like them, that will continue their lineage. and i m sorry, but in my book that s just plain old fashioned selfishness. why do you think you re so special? it s that kind of limited, self centered thinking that has gotten us to a crisis point as a planet. once all the orphans in the world have been adopted, and we ve turned back the clock on global warming and overpopulation, then maybe it ll be acceptable to procreate again. there was a point in human history where we needed to procreate so that the species would survive. now the opposite seems to be true we need to not procreate if we want to survive. i realize this is a very emotional subject for a lot of people. but really, why would you do that when you could adopt a child in need? for the sake of our planet and our species. can someone can come up with a different argument, that can withstand the scrutiny of logic?

conclusion: In no academic institution, including grade school, should there ever be such a thing as mandatory attendance. If a person can pass without ever having to show up to class, they should be allowed to do so.
premises: now, for starters, i'm not a big fan of our educational systems, but since i cannot offer a better practical alternative for the time being, let's speak in context of the current systems that are commonplace across most countries today. let's keep it simple, and we'll address any complexities as they arise in the comments. with regard our current standardized educational systems, the majority of schools and universities require that a student be present for a certain percentage of lectures in order to pass the course. imo, this is pure fucking bullshit; regardless of whether a student is in middle school, high school, under grad or post grad. plenty of the courses that i've been required to maintain an attendance rate of 85 of over the years have been a complete waste of time, and i could have been utilizing my time better doing countless other things. i just don't understand what the point is in having students attend the courses when they don't feel like doing so. interested in hearing different views on the matter.
argument: In no academic institution, including grade school, should there ever be such a thing as mandatory attendance. If a person can pass without ever having to show up to class, they should be allowed to do so. : now, for starters, i'm not a big fan of our educational systems, but since i cannot offer a better practical alternative for the time being, let's speak in context of the current systems that are commonplace across most countries today. let's keep it simple, and we'll address any complexities as they arise in the comments. with regard our current standardized educational systems, the majority of schools and universities require that a student be present for a certain percentage of lectures in order to pass the course. imo, this is pure fucking bullshit; regardless of whether a student is in middle school, high school, under grad or post grad. plenty of the courses that i've been required to maintain an attendance rate of 85 of over the years have been a complete waste of time, and i could have been utilizing my time better doing countless other things. i just don't understand what the point is in having students attend the courses when they don't feel like doing so. interested in hearing different views on the matter.
auto_conc: Attendance should not be a requirement to pass a course.
gt: well first it's important to know why some states created laws to begin with. in washington it is mandatory to attend school because of a bill called the becca bill. becca was a girl who was taken and killed. despite being gone for weeks, her school never informed anyone that she stopped showing up. the state decided that parents shouldn't be solely responsible for making sure kids are safe, so they created the bill. i work at a school and we must report when kids stop coming or regularly don't attend. usually, yes it's lack of motivation for various reasons, but sometimes it's family or community factors they can't control and letting the courts know about their absences can start the ball rolling in getting the student help. sometimes kids don't come because of abuse, neglect, drug addiction their own or parents . if you took away the legality to attend school, you'd no longer have this safety net.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i disagree with the idea that there is a 'right' way to measure a student's ability to pass the course. i don't think it's a good idea to have a test for every student, but it's certainly not a bad idea. it's not a perfect system, but there are a lot of things that can be improved. for example, if a student is in middle school, they will be required to attend a certain percentage of lectures, and if they don't, they'll have to sit through the rest of the class. i think that's a pretty good idea, but that doesn't mean that it's the best way to do it. i agree that it shouldn't be an issue, but at the same time, i think it should be a good way to ensure that students are able to complete the course, and that they can do it in a timely manner. i'm not saying that everyone should be able to pass
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think mandatory attendance should be mandatory. i think it should be a requirement for teachers to be able to teach students what they want to learn. for example, if you're in a high school class, you're expected to be in the class for a certain amount of time. you don't have to show up to class, but you do have to be there for the rest of the class. if you want to pass, you need to be present for the remainder of the course. i'm not saying that mandatory attendance is a bad thing, but it's not the only thing that should be required.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think attendance should be a requirement to pass a course. i think it should be mandatory to attend the course.

conclusion: Climate change should be the the focus in upcoming elections.
premises: as nations and individuals we really need to act quickly in order to limit the damage. i know saying 'should' can be the wrong word to use but i believe it would would show the candidate to be corrupt or ignorant if they don't address the issue. there are many issues that face us as a society, but climate change is the one most likely to threaten our core way of life if nothing is done. it is on the same level as the threat of global nuclear war, which rightfully received this kind of attention during the cold war when it was especially likely.

auto_conc: I think climate change is one of the most important issues humanity needs to address.
gt: william nordhaus just earned the nobel prize in economics for his work on climate change. if you want to get deep into his work here is a link and some notes: the international target for climate change with a limit of 2 c appears to be infeasible with reasonably accessible technologies a target of 2 c is technically feasible but would require extreme virtually universal global policy measures moreover, notwithstanding what may be called the rhetoric of nations, there has been little progress in taking strong policy measures. for example, of the six largest countries or regions, only the eu has implemented national climate policies, and the policies of the eu today are very modest link 2 the study estimates that the scc is 31 per ton of co2 we show a calculation for constraining temperature to a 2 c limit in two cases: one with a hard cap of 2 c, and the second where that cap is for an average of 100 y rather than a single period. the sccs for the two limit cases are 184 and 107 per ton of co2 amp; x200b;nordhaus' research indicates that holding a 2 c target which is even higher than the new ipcc recommendation of 1. 5 or 2 would cost 184 per ton where the scc is only 31. this does not say that the cost is 0, but that it is overall more expensive to attempt to hold these stated numbers.

conclusion: X-Men is a bad and potentially dangerous metaphor for the LGBT struggle
premises: see, anyone can have lgbt experiences, and what is doing the harm is the categorization of people into neat boxes that you can use to oppress them. boxes that, at the end of the day, don't reflect the reality and the diversity of people's experiences. i think it's better to focus on the fact that the lines people draw in order to be able to oppress marginalized people are inherently blurry, and that you can't effectively separate people into those who you want to oppress and those who are immune. in the case of lgbt people, how strong should your attraction to the same sex be or to what extent should your gender identity not align with the one you were assigned at birth, in order to be excluded from the lgbt community? it's better to be inclusive than to try and accept the boxes that society puts us in. but being a mutant is different. you either are or aren't a mutant. there are no half ass powers. mutants and non mutants are different enough for a legitimate case to be made for separatism. this idea of separatism, that we're so different from non queer people that they're not allowed in our spaces, is something that i see gaining popularity these days, and i honestly feel like it could be dangerous, and it could exclude people who need our help most, young and questioning people who don't immediately adopt a queer identity as a lot of us do.
argument: X-Men is a bad and potentially dangerous metaphor for the LGBT struggle : see, anyone can have lgbt experiences, and what is doing the harm is the categorization of people into neat boxes that you can use to oppress them. boxes that, at the end of the day, don't reflect the reality and the diversity of people's experiences. i think it's better to focus on the fact that the lines people draw in order to be able to oppress marginalized people are inherently blurry, and that you can't effectively separate people into those who you want to oppress and those who are immune. in the case of lgbt people, how strong should your attraction to the same sex be or to what extent should your gender identity not align with the one you were assigned at birth, in order to be excluded from the lgbt community? it's better to be inclusive than to try and accept the boxes that society puts us in. but being a mutant is different. you either are or aren't a mutant. there are no half ass powers. mutants and non mutants are different enough for a legitimate case to be made for separatism. this idea of separatism, that we're so different from non queer people that they're not allowed in our spaces, is something that i see gaining popularity these days, and i honestly feel like it could be dangerous, and it could exclude people who need our help most, young and questioning people who don't immediately adopt a queer identity as a lot of us do.
auto_conc: people in the LGBT community need to accept that everyone is different, and stop trying to categorize people into neat boxes.
gt: as a fan of x men i agree with you that it's a dangerous parallel to draw. i feel like the whole point of x men was to show that powers is not what defines us as people, and it's our actions that define us as individuals. as should real life, i don't care what your orientation is as long as you're a nice guy i'll treat you nicely. however the struggle between the x men and magnito as shown in the movies is how the lgbt community want to be seen so that's how they're going to see it. it's a good metaphor becuse in the movies it shows a group of people that are mistreated becuse they are different and becuse people don't understand them. although thats not how i see things it's how the community sees them. they see it as a 'they don't understand us because they aren't us' which is a dangerous idea to have becuse of how it turns out in the movies and the comics but it is a valid one for what they beleive in. so i'm not saying they're right, but it does seem like a perfect parallel to how they feel. and all we really want is to understand each other so we can figure out where to proceed, but if they don't draw that line like magneto then they're afraid the community will be destroyed.

gt: i am an independent progressive. i've watched the democratic party bash progressives for years while paying lip service to social issues and being center to center right on foreign policy, wall street regulations, and especially on issues regarding all the money swirling around congress. the hot topic right now is how radical mainstream democrats are and how scary and new that is. mainstream democrats have been moving to the right for decades to appeal to moderates and to pad their pocketbooks, and only recently have started to shift back left when they finally started to realize the were losing more of their base than was being gained in new moderate voters. this isn't new, it's a return to a compromise second approach rather than compromise first, and is more aligned with the largest portions of their base. my point is, i'm still an independent progressive. i could have called myself a member of the democratic party the whole time and been more right than wrong on sheer percentage. hell, i'm probably 70 80 aligned at this point in the shift, at least with the rhetoric, and that's pretty damn high. but i'm not choosing a team, i'm not leaving myself open to be burned conclusion: Incels are suffering from mental health issues, but are being held to a double standard compared to other people who suffer from the same mental health issues.
premises: the mainstream opinion of what incels are is that they're violent misogynists. either violent in their actions, or that they entertain violent fantasies in their minds. and the reaction to that is 'they chose to feel this way about things, they don't deserve our help. ' they're selfish assholes. like the alek minassian tragedy. amp; x200b; but i can remember other similar tragedies, from as far back as columbine to as recently as aghdam's youtube assault, where people didn't react this way. instead of reacting with 'what a selfish asshole' the reaction was 'this person is clearly disturbed, not in their right mind, they snapped, they went wrong in the head, they're suffering from a deep personal anguish. if only someone could've helped them before this happened. amp; x200b; we don't condone the atrocities they commit, of course not. but when people like danny ledonne or aaron stark speak on the matter, the people suddenly wanna talk about how love is the answer and how you should reach out to the people who you think might need it. and that's how people reacted to most cases like this. and i don't yet see how these cases differ from cases like minassian or rodger. take cho's atrocities at virginia tech. he was also hateful. he also wrote manifestos fueled by his hate. he also entertained abhorrent, violent fantasies inflicted upon people who didn't deserve but somehow he saw fit to blame anyway. but the reaction wasn't 'cho was a selfish asshole. ' the reaction back then was 'cho wasn't in his right mind, someone should've helped him. ' or ricardo lopez, 'the bj rk stalker. ' incel before 'incel' was really a buzzword. like an incel, he was lonely. like an incel, he felt 'entitled' to a woman. like an incel, he saw fit to punish that woman for being with someone else, even though that woman didn't know he existed. and like an incel, he was very depressed and unhappy with life in general. and like many incels, he eventually ended up killing himself. and what happened? he wasn't seen as some piece of shit like minassian was. bj rk even mourned his passing. because she and many others understood that what he was doing was not acceptable, but his mind was too far gone for him to just stop doing it. amp; x200b; and it wasn't just cho or lopez or aghdam or the columbine kids. there's stack, there's huberty, there's a whole long list of them, who commit extreme unjustified acts, but somehow we're able to see the tortured existence inside. not being able to date bj rk is no reason to actively try and mutilate her. just like not having had sex is no reason to call for the enslavement of all women. but for lopez we understand that while his reasons are unjustified, something's wrong in his head that turns his loneliness into a reason to kill. so why can't we see that in minassian, or rodger, or the many other incels out there? and in aghdam's case, only just slightly before. how did our attitude towards mental health change so drastically between aghdam and minassian?

conclusion: CEO salaries should be tied to the wage of their lowest paid worker
premises: this provides a powerful incentive to a ceo to increase the 'value' of their company as it'll improve their stock. the downside of this is that it creates a massive wealth gap and enforces poor wage for low skill workers, with ceos making, in some cases, over 1000x minimum wage.
argument: CEO salaries should be tied to the wage of their lowest paid worker : this provides a powerful incentive to a ceo to increase the 'value' of their company as it'll improve their stock. the downside of this is that it creates a massive wealth gap and enforces poor wage for low skill workers, with ceos making, in some cases, over 1000x minimum wage.
auto_conc: Companies could use a UBI as a justification to offer lower wages.
gt: first of all, such a thing will immediately result in companies contracting out all the low paying duties. the ceo of a tech company is not going to be held back because the company employs one minimum wage parking lot attendant. hr will be contracted out too. only the employees driving the core revenue of the corporation would remain. now after all the support jobs are contracted out, let's look at two companies. one is the company that was contracted for the low end services of the first company. it's a big company contracting these services to lots of others. say it has 50,000 employees. you have a ceo managing a 50,000 person company and his salary is based on minimum wage. now let's look to that engineering company that contracted out its support jobs. all that's left is a few hundred engineers and managers, and the lowest paid person there makes 60,000 a year. this ceo of a small company is allowed to make over twice the salary of the ceo of the huge company. does that make sense? , finish this off. so now you're a talented ceo type and are looking for a job. you look at these two companies, and of course you're going to go for the engineering company since you can make more money. this will be happening across the nation, so in the end the most talented ceos will be running the high paid companies, and the companies employing most of the minimum wage workers will be run by the less talented ceos. do you think that is a good situation?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a good idea to raise the minimum wage for ceos, i think it should be raised to a minimum wage, but i'm not sure that's the best way to go about it.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a good idea. i think it's a great idea to tie the wages of ceos to the salaries of the lowest paid workers, but i don't see how it would make sense. for example, it would be impossible to tie ceos salaries to the salary of their lowest paid worker. if the ceo's salary were to be tied to the minimum wage of their employees, then it would create a massive wealth gap and enforces poor wage for low skill workers. it would also create a huge wealth gap for high skill workers, with ceos making more than 1000x minimum wage.
auto_conc_attacks: the problem with a ubi is that it's a way to incentivize the ceo to increase the 'value' of their company as it'll improve their stock value. the problem is that if a ceo is making more than minimum wage, they're not going to be able to invest in the company. if they're making more money, then they're going to have to invest more in the business.

conclusion: A flaw with Reddit is that those who post comments early get the most attention.
premises: obviously this is not a die hard rule. often times people come into posts several hours late, but have a great comment, and end up getting enough votes to be seen. this results in them being seen more and, therefore, getting more upvotes simply for being seen. sure, you can see the best comments if you really look hard. i love reddit and really appreciate the vote based system it uses, but the fact that you can have an extremely relevant view or extremely relevant information for a post but that almost no one will ever see makes it flawed. i'm not saying i have a better solution. i did award one delta. i tried to respond to most people and will continue to do so if i see some interesting new view. comment.

conclusion: Work is a generally negative experience outside of covering basic expenses and I should save up as much money and retire as soon as possible.

idea of working until you're 60 years old so my plan is to have about 600,000 saved in retirement accounts and to have a paid off house and then just quit my job i do have a girlfriend wife i'm also do like teach they tell you how to do it and when to do it my job can assign me pretty awful hours at times, but even if the hours were good i still wouldn't like it also the how to do it part is just as bad if you work, will inevitably end up with a night where you don't get enough sleep for various reasons stress from work or home life if you're not working and you have a sleepless night, not a huge deal you'll just have a lazy day if you have to go into work you'll feel tired, groggy, and shitty all day same goes if you're sick now you can of course call in if you have the flu or something else serious, but if you have a cold you should maybe only call in on the worst day of it you'll still end up going into work some days where you're not back to 100 work cuts into hobby and exercise time now there are a lot of people who are overweight and use 'work' as an excuse for not exercising and that's wrong unless they have a really hellish schedule ie 70 hours a week at my job most days i can work out, but i don't like that sometimes i get scheduled for a 13 or 14 hour day and i can't work out unless i want to give up sleep too i like working out every day work prevents that also if it's a small risk, yes, but it's a risk to go to some place i don't even want to be there are risks while at work too, but there are risks around the house as well so i'll just consider those as cancelling out
