gt: consider finding work that is more fulfilling. it's absolutely true that many jobs are awful, and your plan actually sounds pretty good. there's absolutely nothing wrong with saving up and having an early retirement plan. however, once you have those ducks in a row, you may enjoy another kind of work. working, when you don't need to work, negates a number of downsides. you don't have to put up with crap, you can pick the work that seems most interesting, and if a job goes south, you can bail. if you want, you can start your own business, and explore something you enjoy with fairly few limits. it's a bit like having a hobby, but people take businesses seriously in a way that they don't take hobbyists. running a business can be basically a hobby if you want it to be, though. tl:dr: having to work sucks, but choosing to work can be amazing.

conclusion: If there is a universal gender wage gap, it is much smaller than reported.
premises: the commonly cited statistic is '77 on the man's dollar'. i don't think this is a fair evaluation, or evidence for widespread wage discrimination. there are tons of factors it doesn't account for. education, position, hours worked per week, willingness to demand a raise promotion, and willingness to relocate, to name a few. much of the above factors are choice. for example, out of the five best paying college majors, four are dominated by men. out of the five worst paying, four are dominated by women. is this discrimination? is there someone forcing women to choose poorly paying majors? no. a study by the american association for university women a clearly feminist organization found the wage gap to be not 23, but 6. 6 percent. it is entirely possible this is sexism. but it could be any number of other, unexplained reasons. despite what tumblr wants you to believe, there are differences between men and women. this doesn't mean that there aren't wage gaps in certain fields or that certain employers don't practice wage discrimination.
argument: If there is a universal gender wage gap, it is much smaller than reported. : the commonly cited statistic is '77 on the man's dollar'. i don't think this is a fair evaluation, or evidence for widespread wage discrimination. there are tons of factors it doesn't account for. education, position, hours worked per week, willingness to demand a raise promotion, and willingness to relocate, to name a few. much of the above factors are choice. for example, out of the five best paying college majors, four are dominated by men. out of the five worst paying, four are dominated by women. is this discrimination? is there someone forcing women to choose poorly paying majors? no. a study by the american association for university women a clearly feminist organization found the wage gap to be not 23, but 6. 6 percent. it is entirely possible this is sexism. but it could be any number of other, unexplained reasons. despite what tumblr wants you to believe, there are differences between men and women. this doesn't mean that there aren't wage gaps in certain fields or that certain employers don't practice wage discrimination.
auto_conc: I don't think the wage gap is real.
gt: it is factual that women make . 77 of what men make in america. sometimes, people suggest that if this can be 'explained' by things other than discrimination at the point of hiring, it doesn't 'count. ' for example, some of the pay gap can be attributed to child rearing practices. but in a market based society, a person's value and more concretely, their agency and power is fairly directly tied to the dollar amount at the bottom of their w 2. for this reason, the wage gap is a problem. it suggests that the lives that women lead are less valuable to society, or perhaps that they are not capable of much work that is more valuable. people who are interested in closing the wage gap envision a world where men and women share equally in the burdens and rewards of life where women have the economic and social power that men have traditionally held, and men have the domestic and family rewards that have traditionally been given to women.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. the wage gap is not caused by a lack of choice. it's caused by the fact that women are more likely to be in positions of higher paying jobs than men. it is caused by sexism.
known_conc_attacks: i think it depends on what you mean by 'unfair'. if there is a universal gender wage gap, it is much smaller than reported. if there are no gender wage gaps, there is no discrimination.
auto_conc_attacks: it's not the wage gap, it's the gender wage gap. if you look at the study you can see that men are paid more than women, which is why they tend to be paid more. also, i think it's important to note that there are plenty of studies that show that women are paid less than men in certain fields. for example, in the u. s., there was a study that found that there were a total of 7. 6 million women in the field. the study also found that women were paid less in the same field as men, but that was due to the fact that men were paid more in the fields they were in. this is not to say that there is no wage gap at all, but it's not true that there isn't a wage gap between men and women. i'm not saying that there aren't wage gaps, but i think there are a lot of factors that contribute to it.

conclusion: A flaw with Reddit is that those who post comments early get the most attention.
premises: obviously this is not a die hard rule. often times people come into posts several hours late, but have a great comment, and end up getting enough votes to be seen. this results in them being seen more and, therefore, getting more upvotes simply for being seen. sure, you can see the best comments if you really look hard. i love reddit and really appreciate the vote based system it uses, but the fact that you can have an extremely relevant view or extremely relevant information for a post but that almost no one will ever see makes it flawed. i'm not saying i have a better solution. i did award one delta. i tried to respond to most people and will continue to do so if i see some interesting new view. comment.
argument: A flaw with Reddit is that those who post comments early get the most attention. : obviously this is not a die hard rule. often times people come into posts several hours late, but have a great comment, and end up getting enough votes to be seen. this results in them being seen more and, therefore, getting more upvotes simply for being seen. sure, you can see the best comments if you really look hard. i love reddit and really appreciate the vote based system it uses, but the fact that you can have an extremely relevant view or extremely relevant information for a post but that almost no one will ever see makes it flawed. i'm not saying i have a better solution. i did award one delta. i tried to respond to most people and will continue to do so if i see some interesting new view. comment.
auto_conc: i think the rule "you have to post a comment before you can get an upvote" is flawed.
gt: what you're experiencing is partially a product of the individual subreddit rules. for an alternative, look no further than r askhistorians. i don't feel anyone would disagree with the statement that the rules there are strict and enforced heavily and efficiently. the top comment is always the most useful in part because anything which falls short of their impeccable standards is promptly removed. this sometimes means questions can take all day to come in, in some cases as much as a week, but when they do arrive you can be almost certain that the post is accurate and well cited. however, it does come at some cost, they don't tolerate posts which aren't directly related to the question at hand such as jokes and often when a question hits the front page the comment section will have a vast graveyard of removed comments which were deemed irrelevant or unable to satisfy the depth required for answering the question.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you. but i don't think it's the best solution. it's a terrible system.
known_conc_attacks: it seems to me that a flaw in this system is that the only way to see the best comments is to see them first. it's not easy to do this, but i think it's a good thing to have a system where you can see the comments first. if you don't see the comment first, you can't see it in the first place. you can only see the first comment if you look hard enough, but if you do, you'll see the second comment first.
auto_conc_attacks: i agree with you in principle, but i don't think it's the best idea. i think it would be better to have a system where you can post a comment before it gets an upvote, rather than a system that requires you to post it in the first place.

conclusion: Souls don't exist
premises: one thing that i see everyone take for granted is the idea of 'souls'. the idea that everyone has a soul, and that it's distinct from our corporeal forms. usually people use it in reference to the afterlife or reincarnation but that's a religious debate and i just want to talk about who we are here on earth. there's no supernatural part of us that makes us unique. we all have consciousness , which is an interesting topic, but the answers to that question lie in philosophy and psychology and neuroscience, not spirituality. we don't understand everything about the brain but we know enough about it to detect and measure emotions, memories, and personality traits. if those things are determined by grey matter rather than a soul, then what exactly does a soul do? how is it a useful concept whatsoever? the interesting thing i find about this topic is that it's one in which everyone of all backgrounds and political stripes agrees and just assumes must be the case. conservative christians and spiritual chicks on tumblr both agree that we must have souls, despite there being literally no evidence to suggest that. i think it's time that we discarded that antiquated idea.
argument: Souls don't exist : one thing that i see everyone take for granted is the idea of 'souls'. the idea that everyone has a soul, and that it's distinct from our corporeal forms. usually people use it in reference to the afterlife or reincarnation but that's a religious debate and i just want to talk about who we are here on earth. there's no supernatural part of us that makes us unique. we all have consciousness , which is an interesting topic, but the answers to that question lie in philosophy and psychology and neuroscience, not spirituality. we don't understand everything about the brain but we know enough about it to detect and measure emotions, memories, and personality traits. if those things are determined by grey matter rather than a soul, then what exactly does a soul do? how is it a useful concept whatsoever? the interesting thing i find about this topic is that it's one in which everyone of all backgrounds and political stripes agrees and just assumes must be the case. conservative christians and spiritual chicks on tumblr both agree that we must have souls, despite there being literally no evidence to suggest that. i think it's time that we discarded that antiquated idea.
auto_conc: The concept of a "soul" is outdated and irrelevant.
gt: why do you think 'everyone' believes in souls? atheism, one of the fastest growing belief systems in the planet, typically doesn't provide for the existence of anything beyond the material. 'spiritual chicks on tumblr' and 'conservative christians' both share belief systems with a degree of mysticism and external non material parts of existence, in this particular area wouldn't a better mark of comparison be atheists or other areligious people? what do you think distinguishes 'souls' from 'consciousness'? what makes them distinct concepts to the extent that you don't consider them as the kernels of self awareness, critical thinking, and moral reasoning present in most human brains to be the same thing with different names?

conclusion: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem.
premises: corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.
argument: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem. : corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.
auto_conc: The search for the right leader is a never-ending process.
gt: even if you had a system that would prevent corruption, who would prevent the elected people from corrupting that system? it s a bit of a chicken and egg scenario. people may be corrupt going in, or just get corrupted once there. power or access to power will inevitably draw corruption to it. systems are never better than the participants in those systems and they require people to enforce the system. people are corruptible. chicken and egg.
masked_conc_attacks: there's nothing inherently wrong with being corrupt. it's just that we don't really know what it's like to be corrupt. if you don't know what's right for you, then you won't be able to make any real decisions about who you want to be president. it doesn't matter if the person is corrupt or not, because that's how the system works.
known_conc_attacks: the problem is that you are conflating two things. 1. people who say all politicians are the same don't understand how corruption works and are part of the problem. 2. corruption is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. if the incentives are not right, then they are not corrupt.
auto_conc_attacks: the problem with this view is that it assumes that there is a 'right' leader. that is, there is no way to determine whether or not the leader is the right person. that doesn't make it a never ending process. the problem is that you assume that the leader will always be the same person. if the leader has a cult of personality, then it is impossible to know if the cult is right or wrong. it is possible that the cult might be wrong, but it is not impossible that it would be wrong to find the right leader.

conclusion: It is plausible that most jobs in North America and Europe are mostly bullshit most of the time, (inspired in part by David Graeber's thesis in Bullshit Jobs).
premises: he's just the messenger. as graeber points out, 'when someone describes his job as pointless or worthless, he is necessarily operating within some sort of tacit theory of value: an idea of what would be a worthwhile occupation, and therefore what is not. the assumption in modern culture is that markets assess some kind of quasi objective value through pricing. if your labor isn't that valuable, for example, you will be paid less. hundreds of people reported to graeber that they get paid very well to do what appears to be wholly without value to society many of whom work in finance, for example . we can also point to countless activities that are widely accepted as valuable that are unremunerated, like helping neighbors plant flowers, household chores, etc. also, despite being absolutely critical roles for the functioning of society, many careers like education and waste management do not pay very much, and if left to the market alone may not even get done further suggesting there is something off about the market driven theory of value. so on the one hand, we have markets saying the value of a job is worth x gt; 0, while on the other hand we have the people working the jobs themselves saying they're not worth anything at all to anyone. that said, markets are just as susceptible to human error as human beings themselves. think about con artists swindling people out of money. do we say the con artist produced a value to the person swindled just because they convinced them to give them their money? what if some guru or company convinced millions of people to flush some massive portion of their earnings down the toilet every year? because those choices are fundamentally individual choices, they would clearly constitute market choices. but would it be any sign that the real value of those people's decisions? people can and do waste their money. the thing is, many of our primary motivators in life make it difficult to see this kind of waste even when it's right under our noses. in addition, politicians are highly motivated to endorse the expansion of jobs irrespective of whether they produce value. their motivations stem in one part from the lack of saturation of theories about what makes a good life, and in another part because, again, currently the only way to stave off starvation for the people they represent is to get them jobs at all costs bernie sanders' guaranteed jobs plan ring any bells? and just in case you think companies who thrive and flourish in the competitive marketplace are exempt from this problem, consider the fact that our entire economy goes through cycles of boom and bust, with massive hirings and layoffs that indicate that even this system, several times over the course of an average human lifetime, is subject to the same managerial and administrative bloat that government institutions are often rightly charged with. efficiencies take time to develop, perhaps even requiring countless iterations of boom and bust, and bullshit will thrive wherever these efficiencies fail to manifest. now this all might seem like a digression from my claim, but i think it's essential to have in mind for its analysis. there's nothing particularly fancy about the argument. garbage collectors, teachers, nurses, physicians, architects, construction workers: if they ceased to exist, we would be in real trouble. physicians, for example, may spend gt;50 of their day sitting through bureaucratic meetings, and or ticking boxes on endless forms that could be automated away by technology. major researchers report being forced to spend more time on grant proposals than actually performing research or teaching students. so change my view. feel free to use your own experiences. but don't forget i am just making a plausibility claim, and given my extremely flexible definition of bullshit, if you even agree with the simple claim that there's a lot of bullshit in human decision making behavior in the harry frankfurt sense of bullshit , then you might already be a priori on my side. have a good labor day.

auto_conc: I think the idea that a job is worth anything is bullshit.
gt: i don't disagree with your view. however, i don't think there's an easy solution to this 'problem'. if people didn't have bullshit jobs, what would they have? the idea that most people would use spare time productively is a flawed one. some people, sure, but not everyone.
masked_conc_attacks: i think the problem with your view is that it assumes that the market is the only way to determine whether a job is worth it. for example, if you're a construction worker and you're making a lot of money, you're going to have a hard time determining whether or not you're worth something. if you are a factory worker, you'll have to make a lot more money than you otherwise would. this isn't to say that you're not worth something, it's just that you don't have a good reason to do it.
known_conc_attacks: i think the problem with your definition of bullshit is that it's not just a statement. it's also a statement of fact. if someone is saying that their job is pointless, unnecessary, or pernicious, they're not necessarily operating within some sort of tacit theory of value. they're operating within a tacit theory that they are operating on.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. markets are not a theory of value. they are a tool for determining the value of a job. they're a tool to determine whether a job is worth it or not. it's a tool that can be used to determine how much value a job has. for example, if you buy a house, you can sell it to someone who can buy it for you. if you sell the house to somebody who can afford to buy it, you're selling it to another person who can't afford to pay for it.

conclusion: Teachers Shouldnt Assign Homework.
premises: we students go to school 8 hours a day 5 days a week. then we have to spend more hours during our time off doing more school work when we should have been given time during class to do it. with the amount of homework i receive it s difficult to balance sports, school, homework, and spending time with friends and family and when im not doing hw im stressed out about when im going to find time to complete it. we spend 45 hours a week at school and dont get paid just to go home and have more time spent on hw when we could be doing something useful and fun. teachers should use time spent in class more useful rather than giving us tons of hw so cmv.
argument: Teachers Shouldnt Assign Homework. : we students go to school 8 hours a day 5 days a week. then we have to spend more hours during our time off doing more school work when we should have been given time during class to do it. with the amount of homework i receive it s difficult to balance sports, school, homework, and spending time with friends and family and when im not doing hw im stressed out about when im going to find time to complete it. we spend 45 hours a week at school and dont get paid just to go home and have more time spent on hw when we could be doing something useful and fun. teachers should use time spent in class more useful rather than giving us tons of hw so cmv.
auto_conc: I believe that school is a waste of students' time
gt: i'm a teacher and have been for 7 years. i've taught abroad, in a rich private school and at a large urban public high school. when i taught abroad my students came into my class and worked hard for the hour i saw them. we got through a ton of stuff. the jokes and off topic banter was minimal during class and this lead to much more work which is math in my class . i had 11th graders taking the ap calculus test and getting 4s and 5s. when i taught at a rich private school it was similar. i thought middle school and the kids were much younger and less serious, but they came to work. if they were out of line i'd contact the folks and get them in line. we got through algebra 1 quickly and effectively. in both instances i assigned minimal homework. 5 10mins 3 days a week. at my public high school there are seniors in algebra 1 alongside incredibly bright freshman. the fresh show up on time and do work but the class is often derailed by those seniors who stroll in late, take forever to get started, sarcastically respond to me and barely do shit. i wish i could get through everything in the class period allotted but the simple fact that we structure class like this and don't offer a tract for less academically skilled kids to veer off and achieve in a different i am left managing kids. this takes time. a lot of time. i'm good with classroom management and i actively engage my lowest performing kids so they can muster a good grade instead of a 12 or something equally poor. but it is time consuming and difficult to explain a concept to a reluctant 12 grader over the course of an hour when that same freshman learned it in 5 minutes. this means there's a lot of review, many different ways to express the same topic, hands on examples, activities to keep them off of their phones and on the work. i give homework for two reasons: 1. to get those kids that need help to do work independently so i can see what they need to work on. analysis. 2. to push those other kids that should work independently and move ahead.
masked_conc_attacks: if you're going to work 40 hours a week, you should be able to do it. if you don't, then you shouldn't have to.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that a lot of the work you're doing is done in class, not in class. for example, if you're going to be going to class, you have to go to class with your parents. you're not going to have time to do homework in class if you don't want to. if you want to do it, you can do it in class as well. you are going to get a lot more out of it than you would if you didn't have to work in class for it to be done. it's also important to remember that you aren't the only student in the class, and that you are not the only one.
auto_conc_attacks: i agree with you that school is a waste of students' time. however, i disagree that it is. i don't think it is a 'waste' of students time. i think that there is a difference between school and homework. i would argue that homework is more useful than school, but i would also argue that school itself is more valuable than homework.

conclusion: All men are potential rapists
premises: the fact is that the only thing that keeps people from doing 'bad' things like stealing, killing, raping, etc. is the fear of the law. more specifically, the fear of being punished. if you could get away with anything what would you do? you're lying to yourself if you think you would still act like the upstanding citizen you are. absolute power corrupts absolutely. if you had the power to do anything and get away with no punishment, you would do unspeakable things. the law is only thing that keeps men from raping. certain species of animals have been known to rape. it is not out of the question to say that rape is human nature. history has proven this. what happens when soldiers can get away with anything? you get the rape of naking. the rape of berlin. go back even further in ancient times when rape would occur during the sacking and looting towns villages. furthermore, why was martial rape legal for so long? why do we still live in a rape culture? if humans had a innate sense of good evil, none of this should be. clearly morality is not objective, but is based on what society wants. society has chosen that rape is wrong, and has ingrained that in us ever since we're young. but really, it is in man's nature to rape. this logic does not just apply to men. it's just that in lawless states it doesn't happen this way. has there ever been a female on male version of nanking? also the reason i focus on rape is because people generally admit they would steal money if they could get away with it. rape is a more touchy subject though.

auto_conc: I believe that the law is the only thing that keeps people from doing 'bad' things.
gt: human beings are social animals everything that we've accomplished, we've done through cooperation and by forming groups. society is just a ritualized version of primitive group formation, and the laws are a formalized version of what society has deemed necessary in order to continue the smooth functioning of what has been formed. it is very much in our nature to cooperate and form social bonds. in fact, some of the examples you provide such as rape and murder during wartime are the byproduct of our natural tendency towards forming social groups, as once we form them, we tend to aggressively defend them. turns out human nature is complicated, and is not wholly one thing or another!
masked_conc_attacks: what is your definition of rape? do you mean to say that rape is a crime, or that it is not a crime?
known_conc_attacks: i think you are misunderstanding the definition of rape. rape is a crime committed by someone who is in a position of power. it is not a crime against a person, it is an act against a group of people. if you are a rapist, you are not a rapist.
auto_conc_attacks: the law is only thing that keeps people from doing 'bad' things. it is the fear of being punished that keeps them from doing bad things.

conclusion: I don't see how morality can be objective
premises: it's abstract. unless you believe rational thoughts can appear without any humans present, it's subjective. the reason things like trees are objective is because if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there. but you can't say the same for something that exists in head. so yeah, that's my argument. i'd prefer no theological attempts at changing my view god exists and his morals are objective because that'd completely shift the focus of the discussion, and i'm an apatheist.
argument: I don't see how morality can be objective : it's abstract. unless you believe rational thoughts can appear without any humans present, it's subjective. the reason things like trees are objective is because if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there. but you can't say the same for something that exists in head. so yeah, that's my argument. i'd prefer no theological attempts at changing my view god exists and his morals are objective because that'd completely shift the focus of the discussion, and i'm an apatheist.
auto_conc: I don't believe in an all-knowing and all-seeing.
gt: i generally believe that morality is subjective for the most part, but i think it is possible to construct a non theological framework for objective morality. tell me if you disagree with my definition of morality, but i'm going to use one of the first ones i found with a quick search: a system of ideas of right and wrong conductthe first step is to decide on some goals, some purpose for having morality. this step is a bit subjective, but i think theoretically you could come up with a few baseline points that a large amount of people could agree with for example, we want a system of morality that minimizes suffering, while maximizing enjoyment and quality of life. all of those terms might have to be defined a bit better, but lets imagine we sit down with a bunch of people and decide on some metrics that we can agree on to determine quality of life, suffering, etc. at this point, i think i can believe that there is some objectively optimal morality that we could choose to adopt, which if we all followed would fit the criteria layed out in the previous step. without a god to deliver that morality to us, we might not ever discover it, and even less likely that everyone would choose to follow it, but it probably exists, independent of whether we know about it or not.

conclusion: James Cameron's Avatar is Underrated
premises: but by now the circlejerk about 'pocahontas in space' or 'fern gully in space' or 'dances with wolves in space' have come so far that i feel that this movie has gone around to being pretty dang underrated. let's knock that first big criticism right off the bat: yes. the plot is derivative. but to be honest, there are a lot of derivative movies out there, so i don't think that's as huge a knock against the movie as other people do. and honestly, the plot structure makes a lot of sense: you have a big crazy world you've developed, what's the best way to get the audience to appreciate it? take an audience proxy character and put them through a protracted fish out of water narrative. now on to the movie's good points firstly, it's one of the only movies, and especially one of the only not completely animated movies, to get a really really good result out of 3d. i've seen the movie 4 times since it came out in 2009: twice in theaters, and twice seeing the extended cut at home protip: the extended cut really does improve the plot quite a bit . and if it came back into theaters in 3d, i would watch the hell out of it in that format, and i'm not normally one to shell out extra for movies in 3d secondly, the movie is technically and visually very well executed outside of 3d: the creatures are all interesting and cool; the ecosystem is dramatic and visually stimulating, mixing tropical rainforest, influences from undersea structures, and karst style rock formations; the near future style human technology is all interesting and gives a good sense of purpose and feels used and lived in. the opening interstellar spaceship did the really cool semi plausible long distance spaceship design that the martian did, but years before that film. and to be honest, the cast is pretty excellent, especially in the roles they're given. stephen lang is awesome as a villainous version of r. lee ermey rip gunny . michelle rodriguez continues to do michelle rodriguez things, which imho is never bad, though it's always a little bit campy. sigourney weaver is good. sam worthington and zoe saldana are both pretty decent as well. so yeah, i think the 'derivative plot' circlejerk has gotten so strong that people ignore the good things about a movie that did a few things wrong and a lot of things right. i don't think it's a 10 10 movie, but it's a solid and entertaining film that stands up to rewatching.
argument: James Cameron's Avatar is Underrated : but by now the circlejerk about 'pocahontas in space' or 'fern gully in space' or 'dances with wolves in space' have come so far that i feel that this movie has gone around to being pretty dang underrated. let's knock that first big criticism right off the bat: yes. the plot is derivative. but to be honest, there are a lot of derivative movies out there, so i don't think that's as huge a knock against the movie as other people do. and honestly, the plot structure makes a lot of sense: you have a big crazy world you've developed, what's the best way to get the audience to appreciate it? gt: it's not underrated if anything it's overrated. for being the highest grossing film of all time i doubt there's been anyone thats seen the movie more than a couple of times. good movies are ones you can watch whenever and are gone back to repeatedly. avatar isn't really the movie for that. i'm on mobile so i can't find this article, but there was one that polled people on how much of avatar they remember and it was a large amount of people not remembering a large portion of the movie. personally i think it's gorgeous, but the content of the movie its pretty forgettable.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a bad movie, but it's not a good movie.

auto_conc_attacks: i agree with you that the movie is derivative, but i don't think it's as good as you think it is. i think the plot structure makes the movie better, but it doesn't make it better.

conclusion: Contemporary Feminism is sexist
premises: ok so first of i think of everyone as equal and i don't think any race or gender is better then the rest. it's sexist for both men and woman actually. so they get stuff handed to them. a small example of this is a female adaptation for every movie. if hollywood was truely feminist they would make their own movie with a female lead that is both empowering to woman and actually a good movie. now on the male end of this. so a man can't make a valid point without being called priveleged white scum or what have you. yes i know all men aren't white but you see my point. i truely think it's coming from a good place. however they need to become more self aware and realize they are who they hate. so yeah that's it. change my view
argument: Contemporary Feminism is sexist : ok so first of i think of everyone as equal and i don't think any race or gender is better then the rest. it's sexist for both men and woman actually. so they get stuff handed to them. a small example of this is a female adaptation for every movie. if hollywood was truely feminist they would make their own movie with a female lead that is both empowering to woman and actually a good movie. now on the male end of this. so a man can't make a valid point without being called priveleged white scum or what have you. yes i know all men aren't white but you see my point. i truely think it's coming from a good place. however they need to become more self aware and realize they are who they hate. so yeah that's it. change my view
auto_conc: i think men are always the "bad guys" in society.
gt: the best way that i ve been able to describe modern feminism is with the analogy of a race. normally, everyone begins at the same starting block, and when the gun goes off, everyone goes on a runnin. however, due to inequality, there are very few races in the world that have everyone on equal footing, if they could even be let in to start the race in the first place. in short, some racers don t even get to start at the start. in this specific case, we ll focus on women. the first wave of feminism brought western women up toward the starting line a whole bunch! the right to vote, divorce, etc, moved women s rights forward and gave them more of a fighting chance at equity. however, they still were not starting as far forward as men. next game advancements in attitudes toward female sexuality and reproductive freedom, equality in the workplace, each step bringing women a bit closer to the starting line. however, we are still not there. now, let s tackle modern examples that you ve given, like female representation in the media. this is, to some including me , a comparatively small step forward when it comes to getting to the starting line. however, it is still a step forward. think about it from the prospective of women in this race we see ourselves pushing closer and closer to the starting line, more and more toward equity. some people may see this, however, as their chance at the proverbial first place being threatened. technically, yeah. the more people there are in the game, the more likely someone else will win out. however, this is where i like to make things a bit bigger picture. yes, human nature is self preservation. we want the best for ourselves, and this is not always a bad instinct. however, it s entirely possible to want the best for yourself and want the best for others as well. that is why feminism has also fought to ensure that male rape victims are treated fairly in society and in law, that fathers have an equal chance in custody cases if they choose to pursue it, that men do not suffer from the same generalisations and stereotypes that harm women. i will not deny that every movement has its fringes that must be challenged when they make harmful statements, generalisations, and accusations. feminism is no different. however, it still holds the equity of sexes at its heart, and that means getting everyone to the same starting line. cassini.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're trying to say here, but i'll try to change your view in a few ways. firstly, you're conflating 'feminism' with 'racism' and 'white privilege.'i'm not really sure what your view is, but you seem to think that there's some sort of distinction between 'feminist' and the 'white' side of things, and i don't think there's one. if a white person is white and a black person is black, it's not as if the white person isn't white. it's like saying, 'i don't like black people, so i can't make a movie about black people.'or 'i hate white people because i'm white.'but that's not the case. i'm sure there are plenty of people who are white and black, but that doesn't mean that they're 'white.'you're saying that white people shouldn't be
known_conc_attacks: feminism isn't about equality, it's about equality of opportunity. it's not about equality for women, it is about equality between men and women. you can't make a movie with a female lead, but you can make a film with a male lead that is both empowering to woman and actually a good movie.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a bad thing that men are the 'bad guys' in society, it's just that it's not a good thing for society.

conclusion: I don't believe that 'non-binary' or 'genderfluid' people is a real thing, and that the people who claim these things are mostly doing so because it's trendy.
premises: i want to preface this by saying that i'm not anti gay, or anti trans, or anything like that so that's not what i mean when i say this.
argument: I don't believe that 'non-binary' or 'genderfluid' people is a real thing, and that the people who claim these things are mostly doing so because it's trendy. : i want to preface this by saying that i'm not anti gay, or anti trans, or anything like that so that's not what i mean when i say this.
auto_conc: I'm starting to think I'm anti-gay.
gt: i'm bisexual, fully down the middle. there are different 'roles' that women are expected to play in relation to their sexuality. straight women are expected to be coy and reject male advances to prove their 'worth', which is trash, and leaves me feeling ashamed about my body, sexual desire, and sense of self. gay women are expected me to resent all things straight, which leaves me feeling ashamed about my body, sexuality, and sense of self. obviously these are generalizations, but they run deep and have had real effects on my life. the reasons that i'm mentioning this is because people always make assumptions based on gender, and being bisexual made me hyperaware of this. i tried to kill myself at 14 because the thought of becoming a woman not physically but socially was unthinkable. so, yea for me there's something deeper than 'i can use this to look cool'. side note: people are surprised i choose to be nongender because i'm i've got a 'classic' female body ie 5'8'', white, big tits, small waist, blond hair, blue eyes. i think the reason me as nongender confuses folk is because they, like you, connect nongender to 'desperate' gay lesbians who are confused about their identity, or people wanting to be 'trendy'. just because can easily and perfectly fit into the idea of what 'femininity' should be doesn't make it any less toxic.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're confusing the word 'anti' with 'anti'. if you mean 'anti gay', then i don't see how that is any different than 'anti trans' at all. i mean, i'm pro gay, but i'm not anti trans. i'm anti gay because i think that's what it means to be anti gay. it's like saying 'i don't care about gay people, i just care about straight people.'it's not about being anti gay, it's about being pro trans.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a real thing, but i think it is trendy. it's not trendy because it's trendy.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think you should be anti gay. i think you need to define what you mean when you say 'anti gay. '

conclusion: People who had abusive non-supportive parents do not have the same chance at success as people born into good circumstances.
premises: hello all! this is my first cmv post, and i'd like to start by saying i would really like it if my view ends up being changed! to be clear, i define success as personal self actualization and fulfillment, not necessarily as wealth. however, being abale to attain a living wage and pay into a savings account seems like a reasonable part of this definition. they will not be able to learn as much from the curriculum and from the social aspects of school. they likely have no good role models growing up model support, self love, kindness, and emotionally intelligent behaviors. as an adult, they will have to teach themselves these things, if they can. while their peers might feel confidence and trust in themselves as adults, children who grew up without support come into adulthood without these positive attributes. they are more likely to make mistakes like engaging in destructive behavior that will set them back even further. without having someone support them in creating positive experiences when they were are young, it is up to luck to create positive experiences that build self esteem and self trust. the thinking they grew up with and lack of properly fostered self esteem will cause them to feel limited in what they are capable of. they will be very likely to close themselves off to oppurtunities thinking they can't do it. the pattern of failure started in childhood is mostly beyond their control.

conclusion: Star Wars the Last Jedi is bad except for in visuals.
premises: warning: this post will contain spoilers for tlj. if you hadn t watched it and don t want it be spoiled, then click off this post now. you have been warned now, i am of the camp, who, gasp, wasn t a big fan of tlj. now unlike most people i can see some good in it, and i think that those few good points are what makes up the positive camp. so this why tlj is not good. 1. that has to do with the character rey. rey is a mary sue sue . she is great at everything she tries. she s an amazing pilot, mechanic, gunslinger, jedi, force user, who can stand toe to toe and even beat much more experienced jedi and sith lords. now, in fa, i was able to ignore it more due to the fact that i thought that it would be revealed in lj, that she was connected to someone or something important. in tlj, it s decided that her backstory, that thing teased about by jj abrams and his mystery box, is unimportant. she s just the child of some drunk hobos. she s a no one. this infuriates me. there is no reason this character should be this powerful without any training. it took luke months before he became a tenth as powerful as her. ben spent all of his life training with a jedi legend, easily defeated by a girl who didn t think the force was real just a few days ago. it also doesn t help that rey expresses less that the lovechild of bella swan and jimmy stewart. i mean, does she even smile in this movie. at all. 2. another hole in wall do even have to state this. superman leia are so many plot holes in this movie. so. instead of talking about them in long ranting detail, i will just create a list. 1. how did the order get everyone together. 2. where did they get the resources to fund them. 3. why didn t holdor tell them about the plan. she risked a mutiny because she didn t tell them about it. 4. how did the hacker know that they were using escape pods. 5. how do spaceships run out of fuel. this is the first time we ve heard about this risk. 6. why didn t the fuel up earlier. 7. how do bombs fall in 0 gravity. 8. why did ben kill his master. wasn t the point of killing his dad to prove his loyalty to him. 9. why would luke create a map to him if he wanted to be left alone. 10. if lightspeed could destroy a ship like that, why didn t one x wing flying into the death star in iv and cut it in half. 11. when did luke get the jedi texts. 12. how did luke die? 13. how can leia fly through space! ? ! 3. clutter my third big problem with the movie was that it felt cluttered. new important characters have been introduced into the movie that we have never heard of and for the most part didn t care about. rose: token asian who adds nothing to the plot. she only exists to be the token. holdor: she could ve should ve been replaced by admiral akbar and the movie would have been better for it. dj: hacker who could have been interesting had he been given more time on screen. only character you will actually even passingly care about. now. many might argue that i am being heavily judgmental. here is my proof that these characters suck. quote one line they said. any line. this movie is also very cluttered, despite being near 2 hours and thirty minutes. this is mostly due to the casino plot point. it was mostly a drag and a bore. they spend multiple minutes talking about how capitalism is evil. in my opinion, instead of the c plot, we could should have seen a rise of factionalism rise in the resistance. with no cleat leader, many pretenders, and faction groups rise. some thinking they should flee and regroup later. and others saying that they should stay the course. that would have been much more interesting than the bland casino scene. 4. deus ex machina and a lavk of this is my 4th and last problem with it. that and they fail to answer the real questions we have. why can leia fly? she just can. she s just chosen. how does rey learn the force so quickly? cuz movie. how do they know the rebels are escaping in the pods. cuz movie. questions we wanted answered. who s snoke? who cares. who re rey s parents? i dunno, junkies? how did fin join the stormtroopers? who cares! how does luke use to force to project himself? who cares. who were the knights of rin? who cares. in summary the biggest problem is that the movie fails to give us satisfying answers to the biggest questions and fails to create compelling stories or characters. so, cmv that tlj is bad.

gt: i will disagree somewhat. pretty much all those issues can be papered over, or have reasonably sounding answers. the problem with the movie to me is more straightforward: it fails in its execution. i can believe rey is an amazingly powerful and competent individual but the movie failed to convince me that this makes sense. i can believe holdo might have had reasons to conceal information but the movie failed to convince me of this. i can believe leia could have jedi powers but the movie failed to set this up. i can believe luke could have had a moment of doubt instanity fear and considered killing ben for a second but the movie failed to give a proper reason. that, to me is what it all comes down to. the various problems are not necessarily inherently nonsensical or horrible. they could have worked if well done. the problem is that the movie failed at making them work. to give an example: the idea is that the movie has a theme of failure. but it never actually goes through with it. poe gets a lot of people killed and nothing happens really. nobody bashes his face in for killing their friends. nobody resists his mutiny because he's a maverick that already screwed up before. nobody demands him to be shot out of an airlock. he feels zero guilt at getting lots of people killed. holdo seems to feel zero guilt at how her handling of the situation resulted in a lot of deaths. the movie doesn't actually go through with what the actual results of those failures would be. if you're going to write a whole movie around failure, you have to actually do it, not chicken out instantly.

conclusion: Fact cannot possibly exist.
premises: all fact is based on repeatedly similar results from the same act. this is invalid in two ways. firstly, ad antiquitatum is the argument that you cannot predict the result based on past observation. if every time you have smacked a table with your fist it has made a loud noise, that does not necessarily mean it always will. 100 of all past observation is 0 of the conceptualised infinite possibilities. this applies to all instances of scientific observation of any kind. secondly, all past observation is based on individual human perception. nick bostrom argues that all perception has the capacity to be simulated. scientific recordings of temperature, physics, any instance of proposed scientific fact is refutable.
argument: Fact cannot possibly exist. : all fact is based on repeatedly similar results from the same act. this is invalid in two ways. firstly, ad antiquitatum is the argument that you cannot predict the result based on past observation. if every time you have smacked a table with your fist it has made a loud noise, that does not necessarily mean it always will. 100 of all past observation is 0 of the conceptualised infinite possibilities. this applies to all instances of scientific observation of any kind. secondly, all past observation is based on individual human perception. nick bostrom argues that all perception has the capacity to be simulated. scientific recordings of temperature, physics, any instance of proposed scientific fact is refutable.

conclusion: Cultural Appropriation is largely misidentified, and should be addressed on a case-by-case basis
premises: some background: i'm a cis, white, liberal woman. this particular opinion i hold is one that tends to clash with the general belief systems of many of the communities and political sects that i consider myself a part of, and that's why i'm coming here to hopefully gain insight into aspects of this phenomenon that i, as a white person, may not realize or understand. i feel like an example scenario may be the best way to explain what i mean, so here we go: jenny is a 16 year old white girl. she lives and goes to school in an area that has a fairly equal population of black people and white people. she has seen black girls online and in school that wear box braids, and she thinks they're beautiful. she regularly compliments all kinds of women on all kinds of hairstyles that she thinks are pretty, and gets inspiration from them all the time. eventually, she decides to go get box braids for herself. she posts a picture on social media and some guy named richard comments 'so hawt! ! ' or something. a look back through richard's post history shows that a week ago he made a post disparaging natural hair hairstyles, calling them 'ghetto', 'trashy', 'ugly', what have you. as annoying sounding a term as it is, i truly do believe that 'cultural appreciation' is a genuine thing although i hate saying it because i feel like it has the same connotation as 'all lives matter' or some shit . anyway, my point here is that jenny loved a certain hairstyle, and acted out of nothing but admiration and respect. had she been the one to previously condemn such a hairstyle when worn by a black woman but gone on to decide that it was 'okay' if she did it, then she certainly would be guilty of ca. in this instance, the only person at fault is richard, who also didn't commit ca, but was absolutely a massively problematic bigot. regardless of whether jenny's hairstyle was what incited richard's hypocrisy, she is not the one responsible for his skewed stances or more accurately, the larger societal views that he represents in this situation . basically: there's no doubt that in many instances, society vilifies an aspect of a certain culture simply for the association with said culture, but then glorifies it when it presents itself among 'white culture'. this is absolutely problematic, but attacking well meaning individuals is the wrong way to deal with it.

conclusion: Animals should not have rights, animal cruelty (especially if it's necessary for scientific reasons) is fine and vegetarianism/ veganism is pointless.
premises: first of all, i don't think that there are such things as natural rights not even for humans rather rights are derived from morality which i think has no natural basis like a god i'm an atheist other than basic empathy and that it just sometimes feels good to do 'good stuff' which feelings have evolutionary origins. so there is no such thing as one true morality. my philosophy is 'don't die and do whatever the fuck you feel like doing' and that we should construct our morality around this statement. so there is no logical reason to give animals rights because rights are defined by humans and giving animals rights doesn't help us to survive and usually makes doing things that we feel like doing a lot harder or impossible. for example eating meat, because you like the taste of meat; conclusion: Jesus never existed

conclusion: Avoiding partisan hackery does not mean compromising your positions, nor does it mean being some sort of centrist who wants to meet in the middle. It simply means that you shouldnt allow your position on one subject, dictate your position on another non-related issue.
premises: your position on abortion policy should not be a good predictor for your position on climate policy. if i can guess your position on abortion, gun control, healthcare, education, affirmative action, capital punishment, drug laws, minimum wage, and corporate taxes, simply by you telling me your views on climate change policy, then odds are you re just a victim of tribalism and group think, and you haven t actually come to many of these conclusions through objective research. it is because i d be all the way left on some issues, all the way right on some issues, in the middle on some, mixed on others, and uncertain some as well. it s possible that going all the way in one direction for every issue just so happens to be correct, but i d say it s rather unlikely. i don t want to give away any of my positions, since they aren t relevant to my point.
argument: Avoiding partisan hackery does not mean compromising your positions, nor does it mean being some sort of centrist who wants to meet in the middle. It simply means that you shouldnt allow your position on one subject, dictate your position on another non-related issue. : your position on abortion policy should not be a good predictor for your position on climate policy. if i can guess your position on abortion, gun control, healthcare, education, affirmative action, capital punishment, drug laws, minimum wage, and corporate taxes, simply by you telling me your views on climate change policy, then odds are you re just a victim of tribalism and group think, and you haven t actually come to many of these conclusions through objective research. it is because i d be all the way left on some issues, all the way right on some issues, in the middle on some, mixed on others, and uncertain some as well. it s possible that going all the way in one direction for every issue just so happens to be correct, but i d say it s rather unlikely. i don t want to give away any of my positions, since they aren t relevant to my point.
auto_conc: i think if you s pro-choice or anti-capitalism, you s probably wrong about a lot of policy.
gt: participating in party politics isn't necessarily about engaging in tribalism or group think, and it certainly doesn't mean agreeing with the party line on every single issue. there is far from consensus on many issues in either major us political party, even among elected officials. just look at the voting records of us representatives or senators, almost none of them vote along the 'party line' 100 of the time. parties aren't about dogma, they're organized coalitions of groups with often vastly different views that are willing to compromise with each other on certain issues to see change they want on other issues. the main reason most people choose to engage in party politics on one side or the other by which i mean registering with one party, voting in primaries, donating to candidates,favoring candidates of a specific party, etc. is because it's by far the most effective way to actually see meaningful change on issues they care about. voting in primaries or engaging in party activism can dramatically change the platform of that party on certain issues. donating to candidates or volunteering will help elect a candidate that aligns with you on issues you care most about. i'm not trying to say there aren't issues with political parties in this country, or that there isn't often a valid reason to not want to support either party. i'm just saying that, as a citizen, refusing to engage in the party system is robbing yourself to influence issues you care about. it is often easiest to enact change within a system than outside of it.

'healthy' options at a lot of restaurants, namely salads and similar, are not at all healthy and often worse than the regular menu options, like burgers, at least in terms of raw calorie content. obesity, for the vast majority of people, is and always has been from consuming far more calories than you burn. you can do this with healthy food, you can do this with unhealthy food, healthy food can be cheap or pricey, unhealthy food can be cheap or pricey. all it takes to avoid obesity is self control, regulating calorie intake to be less than or equal to what you burn. i don't even think convenience is that great of an excuse. i can order two jr. chickens for 4 cad, and that's 740 kcal. perfectly adequate as a meal in terms of calories at least , and very convenient. i don't have to get the quarter pounder w cheese with upsize fries and coke for 1,390 kcal.

conclusion: Divorce is not a Tragedy; a tragedy is staying in an unhappy marriage.
premises: and i am not going to address marriages that contain abuse, drug use, or financial irresponsibility. i'm just referring to marriages that have become roommate situations at best, daily fights at worst. 1 you will not grow. it should be a place of mutual respect and support. but if you are in a marriage with a disconnected, unsupportive, nagging, etc. , spouse, any growth you make will be survival skills. 2 you will likely become depressed. people often assume that someone is lonely if they are alone, but i'd argue that sometimes the feeling of being alone when you are with someone is much worse. that feeling of knowing things shouldn't be this way, that you've tried and tried and you are still stuck and have no means of making the marriage work and just pass each day as co managers of shared life logistics is depressing as h ll. the inability to fix a marriage will make this worse, and while there are thousands upon thousands of counselors and books and classes and talks about fixing your marriage, in truth they rarely work. 3 you will have a negative impact on your kids there's so much to tackle here, so i'll just cover the most salient points. kids will learn what marriage looks like from you. some say that they don't fight in front of the kids, so it's not hurting them. well, kids pick up on the negative emotions in the room. you don't have to raise your voice or slam a door to know mommy and daddy can't stand one another. and if you grow up in a family where the parental foundation is really a shaky facade, the kids will be raised feeling insecure about their family and their relationships. 4 one of you is likely to cheat on the other it's happened so much around me in the past few years it's sad, and that is one or even both spouses cheating. whether it gets discovered or not, it's happening a lot. if you cheat, you made that decision with free will. 5 very few people have what it takes to fix a marriage if you and your spouse have spent years being unable to communicate and resolve your issues, if you have reached the point where you nitpick each other in front of your friends, etc. , i think the marriage is dead and can't be saved. this last item is probably the biggest one that someone may be able to change my view on. what seems to happen, though, is that one or maybe even both parties in the marriage is unwilling and or incapable of doing what is necessary to fix a bad marriage.

conclusion: The next James Bond must be non-white
premises: not for the sake of representation, but because the series has nowhere else to go. rations continued well past the war, the big changes in society were inward universal healthcare, declining heavy industry, pop cultural awakening, migration from former colonies changing the social makeup . the uk s power to project colonial strength by hard power pretty much ended with the suez crisis. a form of soft power to say: we re still here. the uk is not like this today. the empire as it stood has completely ended. the younger generation has no clue what this colonial outlook is like. the capital is one of the most ethnically diverse places in europe. brexit happened. the fantasy of the sophisticated colonial gentleman is a symbol with nothing to signify. while daniel craig salvaged the character from the cheesy nonsense of the later brosnan years, he s also showing his age, and his bond specialises in being a broken, shattered, deconstructed version of the sean connery ideal. after casino royale, not much about the character has been added beyond the eternal metatextual isn t it time you retired? that s why the new bond should add a totally different perspective. it shouldn t be like kingsmen a crass send up of the old bond style but something that acknowledges the shift to different, more fractured ideological conflicts and the post colonial age. the new bond shouldn t be a colonial tourist, but someone who can navigate apocalyptic ideologies nationalists, fascists, jihadists and complex identity politics with ease and understanding. the new bond shouldn t be casually waltzing into a cold war type super villain lair that has cold war fantasy weapons like space lasers, but uncovering networks of ideologically linked cells that work on makeshift means and exploit political conflicts. he shouldn t have all technology handed to him by q, but understand how the internet works as a field of conflict and be somewhat digitally savvy. most of all, he shouldn t be a fantasy figure from the late colonial age. he should be a product of that era s consequences. there s no better way to embody that than with an ethnic minority bond. it shows a globalised, not formally colonising uk. it imbues the character with an intrinsic understanding of navigating different worlds and cultures. it forces the filmmakers to not lazily retreat to retreads of past films. it makes bond going to exotic locations meaningful and difficult, because it can no longer be taken for granted that a colonial gentleman can just swan around the rest of the world like he owns the place. it raises the stakes of the character and the films to match the stakes that exist in our world today.

auto_conc: I believe the US government spends too much money on the military.
gt: the us military is a global force that works to protect not only the us, but us allies. the us military's role is not just to defend against military threats like russia or china, but also to defend trade routes ex. somali pirates , aid in troubled countries ex. exert soft power , train allied militaries i. e. nato , develop new technologies ex. the internet was invented by the us military , etc. the us military does a lot beyond just simply invading third world nations. moreover, the entire global economic system is dependent on western military power. if we were to start slashing our military budget, a country like china could come in and grow their global footprint, thus giving them more soft power diplomatically, as well as hard power militarily. it would threaten capitalism to shrink our military footprint.

known_conc_attacks: the military is not the only one that needs money. it is also the only organization that has a budget of that size. the us military is one of the largest corporations in the world. it has the largest military budget of any other country. the military is just one of many, many organizations that make up the vast majority of the world's military budget. nasa and the education system are the only ones that have a budget that doesn't include nasa or education.
auto_conc_attacks: the us military spends a lot of money on training, equipment, and training. this is not to say that the us government doesn't spend that much money, it's just that the military spends more on training and training than it does on military equipment.

conclusion: It's stupid to join a High IQ Society like Mensa
premises: high iq societies are clubs that typically only allow members with a certain iq percentile. people who join these clubs typically do so to indicate that they're intelligent and to socialize with peers who are as intelligent. the reason i think it's stupid is mainly because i believe these people put way too much value into their iq. and iq score is typically a very narrow indicator of intelligence, excluding things like emotional intelligence, creativity and social skills. not to mention it's outdated, since the iq of the general population has been steadily growing, but the average is still set to 100. meaning that and iq of 140 is less impressive than it used to be. which brings me to my main point in that his members overestimate the value of iq, a lot of them probably take much pride over it because they lack other significant achievements in their lives.
argument: It's stupid to join a High IQ Society like Mensa : high iq societies are clubs that typically only allow members with a certain iq percentile. people who join these clubs typically do so to indicate that they're intelligent and to socialize with peers who are as intelligent. the reason i think it's stupid is mainly because i believe these people put way too much value into their iq. and iq score is typically a very narrow indicator of intelligence, excluding things like emotional intelligence, creativity and social skills. not to mention it's outdated, since the iq of the general population has been steadily growing, but the average is still set to 100. meaning that and iq of 140 is less impressive than it used to be. which brings me to my main point in that his members overestimate the value of iq, a lot of them probably take much pride over it because they lack other significant achievements in their lives.
auto_conc: I believe that iq is a stupid measure of intelligence.
gt: i think that if you join any kind of society for the express purpose of being able to brag about your eligibility, you probably have some insecurity to work through but this is hardly unique to members of mensa. another example that comes to mind is paying to be listed in who's who directories and the like. on the other hand, there are people who join societies like this because they enjoy the activities and social programs therein. many older people in particular, who may be lonely, might look for any kind of group or society they are eligible to join. i've never heard a bragging word leave my elderly neighbor's mouth, but she goes to mensa meetings every week because she likes to simultaneously have human interaction and keep her mind sharp by doing brain games with other people who enjoy them. anytime she mentions mensa, it's usually because she want to share a cool puzzle she got there. in brief: if your motive for joining mensa is to brag, then you have issues with insecurity. but that is not the only reason people join mensa. so i think that to say the organization itself is stupid because a certain subset of its members join only for status is not a tenable argument. societal attitudes toward praising intelligence or other heritable traits is a separate issue entirely, of which certain individuals' mensa membership is at most a byproduct.
masked_conc_attacks: if iq is a measure of intelligence, then iq should be judged by the iq of the members. if it isn't, then it shouldn't be judged at all.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's stupid to join a high iq society like Mensa. i think it is stupid to be a member of a club that only allows members with a certain iq percentile.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a stupid measure of intelligence. i think it is a useful measure of a person's intelligence.

conclusion: (Theoretical) physics is no longer beneficial and should be defunded
premises: in past eras, advanced physics helped humanity develop by explaining the world around us. it helped us understand orbits, advance our knowledge of how atoms function, leading to developments in many fields, and enable our technology to take advantage of more mechanics of the universe than before. however, recently the amount of useful results to come out of the physics field seems to have dwindled. now, most of what is produced seems to deal with highly conceptual research, such as string theory and quantum gravity. other avenues of research, such as particle physics research, produce information with little to no practical uses for humanity. the large hadron collider alone cost 4. 75 billion, and annually requiring approximately 1 billion to continue operation. although the collider was instrumental in proving the existence of the higgs boson, the particle has no uses. other experiments involve not investigating anything new at all, merely proving and re proving what we already know about relativity and its related research. instead of continuing to pour money into a field which has extremely limited benefits, i believe funding should be taken out of the physics field and used to solve real problems in the world. the money used to build the lhc could have been used for things like feeding the poor, fixing the education system, or advancing medicine. if the lhc's annual budget was taken away, there would be an extra 1 billion dollars every year dedicated to solving tangible real world problems.

conclusion: The left is more fascist than the right in America.
premises: contrary to what reddit would have you believe fascism doesn't 'racist' or 'far right'. fascism just means gt; a governmental system led by a dictator having complete power,forcibly suppressing opposition and criticism, regimenting all industry, commerce, etc so there's three main components of fascism. 1. government has complete power 2. they forcibly suppress opposition 3. they regiment industry and commerce so let's start with 1. trump's administration is deregulating at an incredible rate and deregulation is one of the core republican policies. positions of the republican party deregulation significantly decreases both the size and power of a government. now number 2. forcibly suppressing opposition doesn't necessarily have to be done through murder. censorship is also extremely effective at this. this is made evident from the widespread censorship of conservative view points from all major social networks. you could make the argument that the left only calls for censorship of speech that incites violence. the right has fewer circumstances in which they believe their opposition must be censored. you could also argue that these are private companies completely within their rights to not give a platform to anybody for whatever reason. but that situation is very comparable to when street owners tried to censor demonstrations from people they didn't agree with politically. this was dangerous because the street owners had an oligarchy on the means of free speech. they could censor any idea they disagreed with. this is a perfect comparison for social networks today, with one judge going as far as to say gt; in coming to this holding, the court emphasized that streets and parks are the quintessential forum for the exercise of first amendment rights and while in the past there may have been difficulty in identifying the most important places in a special sense for the exchange of views, today the answer is clear. it is cyberspace the vast democratic forums of the internet in generally, and social media in particular . the major social networks have an oligarchy on the means of free speech. it is censorship when they ban opposing views from their platform. and finally 3. this one is pretty cut and dry. it's pretty much half of their platform but that doesn't mean the democrats are worse. both parties are so so far from actual fascism that it's pointless to call either even remotely fascist. anyone who does so doesn't understand the definition of fascism. which is understandable considering how the democrats on this site have overused the word to the point that nobody seems to.

definition from dictionary. com except for the part about key parts about nationalism and racism. you simply cannot have a meaningful discussion of fascism without talking about nationalism and a racialized view of the nation. this is well summarized by kevin passmore in a short introduction to fascism: fascism is a set of ideologies and practices that seeks to place the nation, defined in exclusive biological, cultural, and or historical terms, above all other sources of loyalty , and to create a mobilized national community. fascist nationalism is reactionary in that it entails implacable hostility to socialism and feminism, for they are seen as prioritizing class or gender rather than nation. this is why fascism is a movement of the extreme right. fascism is also a movement of the radical right because the defeat of socialism and feminism and the creation of the mobilized nation are held to depend upon the advent to power of a new elite acting in the name of the people, headed by a charismatic leader, and embodied in a mass, militarized party. fascists are pushed towards conservatism by common hatred of socialism and feminism , but are prepared to override conservative interests family, property, religion, the universities, the civil service where the interests of the nation are considered to require it. fascist radicalism also derives from a desire to assuage discontent by accepting specific demands of the labour and women's movements, so long as these demands accord with the national priority. fascists seek to ensure the harmonization of workers' and women's interests with those of the nation by mobilizing them within special sections of the party and or within a corporate system. access to these organizations and to the benefits they confer upon members depends on the individual's national, political, and or racial characteristics. you seem to be talking about authoritarianism, not fascism. that's a fine conversation to have, as long as we're clear we're not talking about fascism. your points, one by one:1. the left wants a more democratic economy, whereby the people are able to control the economy through democratically legitimate institutions. american left style regulation is not total power, because power is always subservient to the electorate. 2. aside from censorship of hate speech and speech that violates different networks terms of service, there is no censorship of the right wing. there is absolutely no evidence that mainstream right wing voices are silenced in america. in fact, they have their own loud speakers, like breitbart or fox news. none of this compares to the way that trump has delegitimized the media. in fact, his war on truth bears many resemblances to the fascist technique called 'the big lie. ' 3. i'm not really sure what work 'regiment' is doing in your definition, but this is the part that seems to least relevant to fascism. economic interventionism, the left most certainly is. but that does not make them any more or any less fascist than the right. amp; x200b;
