conclusion: Not everyone should be allowed to have children
premises: the three main bases of assessment would be: 1 financial economic, 2 psychologically, 3 criminal history. 1. economically financially: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they will be able to provide for the child's basic needs housing, food, reasonable estimate of healthcare etc. , and education at least through high school . this would be based on a holistic assessment of the person's and or couple's current income both active and passive , earning potential, availability of fairly liquid capital; the total earning potential should be able to cover the benchmarked costs for the above mentioned necessities without incurring excess debt i haven't calculated exactly what that'd be, but it'd be leveraging themselves up to a certain percentage of their current income 2. psychologically: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they pass a psychological evaluation that deems them fit to be parenting. i haven't completed figured out what the guidelines would be yet, but it would basically have to demonstrate that the person or couple doesn't have any severe mental disorders nor a recurring history of disorders . 3. criminal history: the person or couple cannot have a lengthy or recurring history of criminal activities this would be based on a has a lengthy history of criminal offenses; not civil offenses their past would need to be evaluated and indexed based on severity; e. g. first degree murder would pretty much rule out your chances, while involuntary manslaughter would be need to be further examined . ultimately, i think successfully implementing these measures would: increase gdp per capita, increase household income per capita, increase household expenditure per capita, decrease income inequality, increase literacy rates, reduce violent crime, decrease household debt, reduce underemployment and unemployment note: unemployment is different from underemployment . these quantitative changes would also qualitatively lead to a 'better society' with a higher quality of living. this is still a developing view, but it's a rough idea that i've been thinking about recently. i did a lazy job of fully fleshing out my thoughts because there're just way too many changes and causal links to list, but feel free to pick something and question it. you won't be able to cmv if you talk about how this isn't feasible in terms of implementation.

conclusion: Infinity War was not that good.
premises: spoilers, obviously. also standard first time posting and on mobile disclaimers. at the time of writing, the movie has an 84 certified fresh rating on rotten tomatoes and the poll on r movies has a mean rating of 8. 81 i'd link it, but again, mobile . and despite wanting to love it, i came out of the movie largely disappointed. here are my complaints. 1. thanos is not a great villain. his rhetoric rings empty: the whole 'ultimate solution' schtick is never once challenged directly and never has an alternative solution proposed. sure he 'loves' his 'family,' but that's told to us, not shown, really. 2. the fights look good, but were ultimately nonsensical. strange's only use of the time stone ends up being pointless as he doesn't follow through unless that's part of the setup for how the avengers 'win' later in the follow up, which still rubs me the wrong way 3. in a 2 1 2 hour movie no one, with the very minor exception of vision, got any character development. i understand this is a consequence of the ambition of the project, but that's no excuse. and here's where i'm going to put a secondary super spoiler warning 4. literally erasing 50 of the cast was incredibly lazy. i understand this was an attempt to pare back the frankly unmanageable number of characters but it came off as an obvious plot device. having no rhyme or reason to who got dusted may have made plot sense but it's no coincidence that the characters lost were a. not the super main main characters ie tony and steve or anyone with whom they have unresolved plots ie black widow and b. were actors who likely had to be paid disproportionately to their screen time ie sam jackson, idris elba . the only outliers here to me seem to be starlord and strange. i have more minor complaints but this post is long and pretentious enough. cmv! i am admittedly a movie only person. that being said, i prefer to evaluate the experience in only that context.

conclusion: Most recreational drugs should be legalised.
premises: the subject of drug usage can sometimes be a somewhat taboo subject. some people are very conservative about this and others are not. why? well when any society attempts to control the consumption of any substance by banning it, we get black markets. that is essentially all strict drug laws do, they create a black market. that black market fuels organised crime and demonises certain persons from society. my second reason, is that if you legalise certain drugs people are consuming anyway you remove the taboo of them seeking help if they become addicted. as it currently stands there is help for those who want to quit smoking tobacco or quit consuming alcohol. these drugs are arguably far worse than most other substances available on the black market. my last reason is i fully believe that a lot of people can take other substances responsibly, in the same way one consumes alcohol. not every user is an addict. i think we need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable. i welcome any counter arguments here, in which may change my view.
argument: Most recreational drugs should be legalised. : the subject of drug usage can sometimes be a somewhat taboo subject. some people are very conservative about this and others are not. why? well when any society attempts to control the consumption of any substance by banning it, we get black markets. that is essentially all strict drug laws do, they create a black market. that black market fuels organised crime and demonises certain persons from society. my second reason, is that if you legalise certain drugs people are consuming anyway you remove the taboo of them seeking help if they become addicted. as it currently stands there is help for those who want to quit smoking tobacco or quit consuming alcohol. these drugs are arguably far worse than most other substances available on the black market. my last reason is i fully believe that a lot of people can take other substances responsibly, in the same way one consumes alcohol. not every user is an addict. i think we need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable. i welcome any counter arguments here, in which may change my view.
auto_conc: I believe all drugs should be legalised.
gt: i would say yes, ideally most recreational substances would be legal, however, each place has different histories with recreational substances, different laws, different societal beliefs, that would significantly impact the way they would be received. in a significantly religious state, there may be more of a backlash, people may interpret the state supporting the legalisation as a move against the grain or the tenets of the major religion. a state with a significant drug problem, may abuse the legalisation of such substances and temporarily regress into a self indulgent binge, while states with less prominent social problems may be relatively unchanged by the move, with those that partake in recreational consumption of drugs no longer threatened hindered by the laws that previously restricted use and possession. really subjective, no one knows what will happen. while some countries have had notable success in the legalisation of some or all substances, in conjunction with controls against the production, acquisition and resale or substances, this is not necessarily the result other countries would experience. whatever countries decide to do is a risk. countries that permit more freedom in regards to all aspects of illicit substances are taking a significant risk. whether a given country is willing to take on such a risk is subject to so many variables that are beyond the bounds of discussion of this post.

conclusion: Of all the men (rightfully) accused in the wake #MeToo, Louis C.K. deserves a second chance.
premises: let me say at the outset that what louis c. k. did was wrong and morally reprehensible for a variety of reasons. this post is in no way a defense of what he did; it is, however, trying to put it into perspective of other forms of abuse. i understand this opinion is a unpopular one, but am truly looking for people to cmv in this post, and explain to me their viewpoints. i want an honest discussion about a very sensitive issue. i also want to say that i am a man, but my family has been affected by sexual abuse. at the end of the day, while i believe louis c. k. should be punished in the court of public opinion, i do not believe that punishment should include a lifetime ban from entertainment the same way i feel it should for people like kevin spacey, bill cosby, and harvey weinstein, for the following reasons: 1 degree of the accusations: i believe that 'bad things' have degrees. unwanted exposure and lewd questions are horrible and deserve consequences; but physically violating someone through physical contact is far worse. i don't believe it is fair to equate louis exposing himself to someone physically violating another person's own body, as was the case with cosby, spacey, and weinstein. i think that the physical violation of another person's body is one of the most vile acts human beings can do to another person, but that is not what louis c. k. did. of the 3 instances reported in the nyt article, none of them involved physical contact. there is one anecdote about louis possibly shoving a women into a bathroom , but as of now we don t know if this actually happened nor the circumstances involved. no woman has come forward to directly accuse louis of this. 2 a reasonable explanation: in his response to the ny times article, i am sympathetic to c. k. 's claims that he did not fully understand how much power he wielded over these individuals because of his celebrity. to his cr, in every one of these instances, c. k. did ask before committing these acts. these instances seemed to happen at the time when his career was first starting to really flourish. i take him for his word when he said he didn t understand how, in his newly found celebrity, asking wasn t really asking. that is in no way an excuse for what c. k. did because his behavior was still wildly inappropriate, but i am still somewhat sympathetic to his explanation, which leads into my third point 3 lack of predatory nature: louis c. k. made bad judgments, but his behavior does not seem predatory to me the same way cosby's, spacey's, and weinstein s were. he never threatened to ruin a woman's career for not allowing him to expose himself in front of them, and based on the information we currently have, it seems as if this behavior stopped at some point. now, it is alleged that c. k. s agent david becky may have made vague threats on louis' behalf to the women who accused him, but i don't think that is enough to put that blame on louis. it is possible becky was acting without c. k. s knowledge. furthermore, when the ny times article was published, i found louis c. k. 's response to be a no bs acknowledgement of both the accusations and the hurt he caused. i think we have to give c. k. crfor that. 5 a learning moment: undoubtedly, the importance of metoo is that it finally gives victims of sexual assault a voice. but perhaps also we should hear from truly contrite men who have behaved inappropriately in the past to understand their reasoning and learn from their thoughts and regrets. i don t believe we should give predatory monsters like cosby, spacey, and weinstein a voice to explain their actions. it may be too soon for c. k. to make a comeback , but i think some day he should be allowed to.

gt: louis c. k. deserves a second chance once he's made peace with his victims, and those victims have given their blessing for louis c. k. to have a second chance. look at what dan harmon did: and his victim, megan ganz, accepted the apology: dan harmon deserves a second chance. once the same happens in the louis c. k. saga, he'll have deserved his second chance as well. when louis c. k. went on stage, unanounced, after a mere 9 month exile, he made a rape joke. i think a few more years of time out are justified. he clearly has a lot more to learn.

conclusion: The movie/films/games/software industries lost the fight against piracy. Instead of trying to find ways to make it harder to pirate stuff, they should introduce a tax/fee on electronical devices, that will go to content creators - and make the content then "free".
premises: honestly i am not too sure how big of a problem piracy is nowadays, but i still see companies governments coming up with new ideas to combat it. like filtering uploading content, forcing gamers to stay online at all times, etc. despite those efforts a quick glance on piratebay shows us: pretty much everything is available. that money then gets distributed to public tv radio but also private stations proportionally to the consumption of those stations. along those lines this 'content fee' would also get introduced, just that its not a yearly fee, but a device bound tax fee. like the share microsoft gets when someone buys a laptop on which windows 10 is installed. when buying a new iphone you would pay number totally made up 10 of the price additionally, but then you gain access to any distribution service, that provides licensed products. spotify, netflix, photoshop, website of your local garage band, download harry potter e book. com, watch hollywood movies. com, you name it. some independent, publicly funded group then controls the numbers and then distributes the money gained from the tax or fee proportionally. i think netflix and co have proved that money isnt the main issue when pirating, but convenience. so if you have everything available when buying a laptop, then no one would even bother to seed a torrent simply because there is no demand. and by buying a laptop you also payed for the series you will be watching. also netflix proved that its possible to prevent dns or proxy servers from working. this means its possible to block non participating countries out. content that is free anyway, like youtube videos would get nothing of this fee, since ads would still be a thing. also merchandising of any form is left out. this means if you want a blu ray you also still pay for the physical copy. i am aware that bots would be a problem and that implementation would be tricky, but those seem manageable details if the industries and authorities really commit to this idea. maybe not, no clue about the technical difficulties would love to hear some stances about this idea. so, what did i miss and why is this idea shitty?

conclusion: If I am an oppressor, it is in my interest to remain one.
premises: i am a straight white male. for many, this means that i am not only in a position of privilege in relation to several other groups, but also that i hurt the interests of those groups by unconsciously exhibiting certain views and behaviors. for the sake of the argument, lets grant all of that. let's also assume that everyone is equal, regardless of sex, genetic background etc. and the only source of outcome variation is historical injustice and various structures and ideologies that support oppression. even if all of the above is true, there is no reason for me to actively seek to empower groups that i don't belong to. power is relative, so every bit of power that women, immigrants, minorities etc. gain, i lose. in fact, all of these groups have a proven record of actively trying to take my power away. not only that, but some of them openly declare so just enter the term 'white men' into google news. women's rights are a good example of this. 99. 93 of humans are born biologically male or female. that makes me concerned, because again, i want to be in a position of power, no matter what. perhaps men have oppressed women, that doesn't concern me. what concerns me is that we're not oppressing them now. even if we, just for the sake of the argument, assume that women are superior to men in some significant way, it would only make oppressing them all the more necessary. based on this reasoning, i support all political action that hurts the groups that i don't belong to. this has led me to having political positions that would be seen as extremely disagreeable by the absolute majority of westerners at least that's what i'm assuming . and i should probably emphasize here that this is not an ideological choice. more power is better than less no matter what. even if i was benevolent, i would still rather be benevolent from a position of power. now here you might say 'hey, this power stuff is weird, who thinks like that? ' and perhaps you're right. however, i have only about 80 years to live and i intend to extract maximum utility out of those 80 years. every millimeter matters. that's not to say that i go out there and engage in some kind of violent activism i still gain much more by just working towards my goals on my own. still, that doesn't stop me from feeling a little bit of joy every time i hear a complaint about women's reproductive rights or how the police in the us apparently hate black people.

gt: it sounds to me like that kind of view is sociopathic. if you have no human empathy then you have abnormal emotional responses to things, which may lead you to improperly define your interest. im sure many powerful people felt like their interests were secure until the people they were opressing got ahold of them. concepts of self interest that see it as separate from social interests are too narrow to capture the big picture.
masked_conc_attacks: if you are in a position of power, then you have a lot of power. you have the power to do whatever you want with it. you can do what you want. if you don't want to do it, then don't do it.
known_conc_attacks: i don't know if i can change your view, but i would like to point out that you are not the only person in the world who has been oppressed by groups that you don't belong to. if you were a member of a group that you did not belong to, you wouldn't have the power to do anything about it. you would have the right to do whatever you want with your life, but you would not be able to do what you want to do with your own life.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure why you want to be in a position of power, but i don't think it's fair to say that you're in the position of being a victim of oppression. if you don't believe in oppression, then you're not going to be able to fight against it. you're going to have to fight for your own interests, and that's going to take a lot of effort.

conclusion: The rich should pay more for a traffic infraction than the poor
premises: i recently stumbled across the idea of progressive traffic fines, which work in a way similar to progressive taxes. i came to agree with the notion, though i've found few arguments to the contrary. c a progressive traffic fine based on the income of the violator would punish violators more equally, and thus be more just. i am willing to entertain other ideas about this, and change my view where merited!
argument: The rich should pay more for a traffic infraction than the poor : i recently stumbled across the idea of progressive traffic fines, which work in a way similar to progressive taxes. i came to agree with the notion, though i've found few arguments to the contrary. c a progressive traffic fine based on the income of the violator would punish violators more equally, and thus be more just. i am willing to entertain other ideas about this, and change my view where merited!
auto_conc: I believe that fines for speeding should be based on the income of the driver.
gt: right, what makes them think they're entitled to their own money? they should give it to me! because reasons
masked_conc_attacks: if you're going to pay someone for something they didn't do, you have to pay them for it. if you're not paying for it, you're paying them for something that they did not do.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i disagree with the idea that the rich should pay more for a traffic infraction than the poor. i don't think it's fair to say that the poor should be punished more harshly than the rich. i think the problem is that it's unfair to punish the rich based on their income. if the rich can't afford to pay more, then they shouldn't be punished at all.
auto_conc_attacks: the income of the person who is driving is not the same as the income of those who are driving. if you are speeding, you are paying more in taxes than the person driving you.

conclusion: Addiction is a choice not a disease
premises: at least initially. there is a time in everyone s life where they may be offered the opportunity to engage in excess drinking, smoking, etc. you choose to either take or not take the pill. you choose to either inject the needle or not inject that needle. you choose to drink that alcohol.
argument: Addiction is a choice not a disease : at least initially. there is a time in everyone s life where they may be offered the opportunity to engage in excess drinking, smoking, etc. you choose to either take or not take the pill. you choose to either inject the needle or not inject that needle. you choose to drink that alcohol.
auto_conc: Taking drugs is not always a victimless crime, as drug users can harm others.
gt: do you consider diseases to be only those things with tangible representations in the real world? meaning something which can be isolated and examined on some level, like a bacteria or a virus or a patch of cancerous skin cells or a particular brain formation even the absence of something like a depressed person missing their correct balance of neurotransmitters? because a great deal of mental disorders psychopathologies would not meet that criteria. there are many debilitating conditions which have no physical representation in reality. it would be nice if you could take someone with ocd, put them in an mri, and say, 'you see this bump right here? that's your ocd. ' unfortunately most conditions like this don't work that way. also . . . if someone is regularly taking a substance drugs for a long time, then goes off that substance, the nerve dendrites which normally recieve the neurotransmitters produced by taking the drug can actually start to grow seeking more of the drug. imagine the dendrites are like garage doors that drugs use to park their cars. if you deprive those garage doors of cars, they will start making more garage doors in the hopes of enticing more cars to park in them. it's a literal ramping up of the craving for more drugs that someone who has not been taking a lot of drugs wont feel. and when the next time there's a big flood of cars, well look at all these nice new garages to house them all.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're trying to say here, but i don't think it's fair to say that there is a 'choice' between taking or not taking the pill. for example, if you're in a situation where you're going to take the pill, you're not going to be able to take it. it's not like you can't take it, you just have to take a pill.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're confusing 'choice' with 'disease.'if you have a choice, it's not a disease. it's a choice.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a victimless crime, but i do think it is a responsibility of the individual to be responsible for their own actions. for example, if someone is a victim of a crime, they are responsible for the consequences of their actions. however, if they are a victim, then they have a responsibility to take responsibility for their actions as well.

conclusion: If male privilege exists, then so does female privilege
premises: off the top of my head, here are a few examples. girls tend to outperform boys in school. males are much more likely to be victims of violence. male parental rights are significantly less. many sharehouse rental accommodation is female only. there are female only scholarships and grants.
argument: If male privilege exists, then so does female privilege : off the top of my head, here are a few examples. girls tend to outperform boys in school. males are much more likely to be victims of violence. male parental rights are significantly less. many sharehouse rental accommodation is female only. there are female only scholarships and grants.
auto_conc: Men and women are biologically different and thus they play different roles in society.
gt: i m curious about your definition of female privilege. are you saying that there is at least one instance in modern western society where women have an unfair advantage over men? if that s the case, i think it d be hard for anyone to disagree with you. or, are you saying that the privileges that women have are the same amount of privileges that men have, and therefore are disproportionally not talked about? i m not trying to change your view, i m just wondering where your goalpost is, whether it s that females have any privileges men don t have, or that females have the same amount of privileges unique to their gender that men do. lastly, in the majority of the world, females are still very much disadvantaged much more than male counterparts. if you agree with that statement, then i think it d be worth it to refine your op to being confined to western societies. my family is from china, for example, and i think it d be very hard to claim privilege of being female as something that needed to be talked about.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think this is the case. there is a huge difference between men and women in high school, and there is also a large difference between women and men in college. i think it's fair to say that women are more likely to be victims of violence than men, but that doesn't mean that women aren't victims of domestic violence.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that the term 'privilege' is used to refer to the lack of male privilege in america. for example, in the united states, there is no'male privilege' or 'female privilege' in the sense that there is a'male' privilege in the u. s. that is, it is not a 'female' privilege. it is a term used to describe a group of people who are more likely to be victims of violence than the group of individuals who are less likely to have violence. this is not to say that there isn't male privilege, it just means that the group that is most likely to suffer from violence is the one who is the victim of violence.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'different roles in society. '

conclusion: In the next couple of years Amazon will buy Valve, buy Steam from Valve, or make their own software to become the primary PC game distributor.
premises: amazon is rich as fuck and it won't be long until they're the largest retailer in the world. they're currently 3rd behind walmart and cvs. their purchase of whole foods shows they're interested in expanding into new markets. they're also not ignorant to the world of gaming, having purchased twitch in 2014. you can find lots of complaints online about operations administration at twitch but they have undoubtedly expanded its audience in the last 4 years, and i think the amazon higher ups view it as a financial success. it certainly seems like a more reliable way to make money. making games is financially risky. but it could also be super rewarding: see pubg and fortnite . nobody really knows, but googling shows that valve is maybe worth about 5bil. that's not an unreasonable purchase price for amazon, having previously spent 1bil for twitch, and 14bil for whole foods. you can also find a few reports online from various ex employees that describe valve as kind of stagnant. they say it's lost the innovation and motivation it used to have. some even point to gabe newell specifically and say he's no longer motivated, and spends most of his days just playing dota. this implies that he could be receptive to buyout offers.

auto_conc: Amazon is going to blow up the gaming industry.
gt: and in 2500 we will see a conan sent by amazon cyberlife
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by'stability.'i mean, i don't think valve is stagnant, but i do think it's stagnating.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about, but i don't think that's the case. i think you're underestimating the amount of money that valve has in the hands of amazon, and how much money they have in the pockets of their employees. it's not like they're going to be able to make their own software to become the primary pc game distributor.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'blow up the gaming industry'. it seems like you're talking about the industry as a whole. i think you're going to find a lot of people who think that the industry is going to blow up. i mean, i don't think that's going to happen, but i do think that it will happen.

conclusion: Instead of teaching youth to "not judge" we should be teaching them *how* to judge with kindness, mercy, logic, and fairness.
premises: let me start by explaining what i mean when i say judge in this context. i am a father of a 5 year old girl and as anyone who's spent a lot of time with babies and young children, i want to help guide her through life and give her the tools to interpret the world around her. when we see a child behaving very poorly in public there are times when i choose to speak with her about what's happening. at the onset of this moment, when we are going to voice our thoughts about the behavior of others, whether it's my daughter and i, you by yourself in your head, or anyone in really any circumstance, we are entering a judgmental space by it's literal definition. any way to frame, or speak about some else's actions requires judgments to be made. our society has made the word 'judgmental' have strong negative connotations, and i believe people are uncomfortable with using others as teaching opportunities for fear of being 'judgmental' here's an example of what i'm talking about. daughter and i see a child screaming in the market, jumping up and down creating a massive scene, hitting their parent ect i'll ask my daughter 'why do you think they're being so terrible' i insert the view i'm teaching, that the behavior is terrible, so judgment is made but begin a dialogue. normally she'll say 'they're mad' or something like that, and we'll talk about things that make us mad, what might have this other child mad, i'll say something like 'i get mad, you get mad, everyone get's mad sometimes, it's ok to be mad but that's not how we act when we're mad right? ' i believe we should be creating a template for judgment to exist, where it's where the person's identity isn't attacked, but their behavior and actions content of their character are understood and discussed. the person who could change my view would do so by showing me how this style of parenting causes more harm than good and i shouldn't have a conversation with my daughter making judgments about the misbehaving child. after reading lots of really amazing responses i have learned a few things. firstly that framing things this way with some of the specific language could be bad for my daughter because when she steps out of line, she inserts herself as the 'terrible' child, or that she is doing 'terrible things', which may be true by whatever definition we have for terrible, it can damage self esteem and doesn't promote healthy learning. 2ndly there is a problem with syntax and semantics with the term judgment, and while none of those arguments swayed me, they are still very much relevant. lastly, it's friday afternoon, and i'm going home. be well.
argument: Instead of teaching youth to "not judge" we should be teaching them *how* to judge with kindness, mercy, logic, and fairness. : let me start by explaining what i mean when i say judge in this context. i am a father of a 5 year old girl and as anyone who's spent a lot of time with babies and young children, i want to help guide her through life and give her the tools to interpret the world around her. when we see a child behaving very poorly in public there are times when i choose to speak with her about what's happening. at the onset of this moment, when we are going to voice our thoughts about the behavior of others, whether it's my daughter and i, you by yourself in your head, or anyone in really any circumstance, we are entering a judgmental space by it's literal definition. any way to frame, or speak about some else's actions requires judgments to be made. our society has made the word 'judgmental' have strong negative connotations, and i believe people are uncomfortable with using others as teaching opportunities for fear of being 'judgmental' here's an example of what i'm talking about. daughter and i see a child screaming in the market, jumping up and down creating a massive scene, hitting their parent ect i'll ask my daughter 'why do you think they're being so terrible' i insert the view i'm teaching, that the behavior is terrible, so judgment is made but begin a dialogue. normally she'll say 'they're mad' or something like that, and we'll talk about things that make us mad, what might have this other child mad, i'll say something like 'i get mad, you get mad, everyone get's mad sometimes, it's ok to be mad but that's not how we act when we're mad right? ' i believe we should be creating a template for judgment to exist, where it's where the person's identity isn't attacked, but their behavior and actions content of their character are understood and discussed. the person who could change my view would do so by showing me how this style of parenting causes more harm than good and i shouldn't have a conversation with my daughter making judgments about the misbehaving child. after reading lots of really amazing responses i have learned a few things. firstly that framing things this way with some of the specific language could be bad for my daughter because when she steps out of line, she inserts herself as the 'terrible' child, or that she is doing 'terrible things', which may be true by whatever definition we have for terrible, it can damage self esteem and doesn't promote healthy learning. 2ndly there is a problem with syntax and semantics with the term judgment, and while none of those arguments swayed me, they are still very much relevant. lastly, it's friday afternoon, and i'm going home. be well.
auto_conc: it's ok to be judgmental when raising a child
gt: while teaching kids, i get lots of utterances like 'this song is shit', and that's very tiring after a while. on the other hand, i respect everyone's freedom of speech and thinking. so i try teaching them to distinguish between blatant judgements and justified opinions. the latter ones 'i find this song shitty because' using the lines of argumentation that you described are acceptable for all. the former only for professionals in a given area.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're looking at it from the wrong angle. you're talking about a child who doesn't understand the world around them. it's not that they don't understand what is going on, it's that they aren't fully aware of what is happening around them, and they're trying to figure out how to deal with it. if you want to talk to your daughter about it, you're going to need to talk about it with her, and you're not going to be able to do that with your daughter. you aren't going to have a conversation with her about what's going on around her, because she's going to judge you for it. you can't just talk to her and tell her that it's ok to be mad, because that's what she's supposed to be doing. you don't have to tell her why she's mad. you just have to talk with her.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a good idea to teach your daughter how to be a good parent. it's not a good thing to teach her how to act in a manner that's kind to the individual, not attacking their identity that's with mercy understanding we all experience these things with logic and fairness by being honest about how those behaviors impact others around us.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think there's anything wrong with framing things this way with some of the specific language you're talking about. the problem is that it's hard to make a judgment about the behavior of a child. you can't make a judgement about a child because you don't know what they're going to do. it's like saying you're not going to tell a child what to do because you have no idea what they'll do. there's nothing wrong with telling a child to do what they want, but that's not what it's supposed to be about.

conclusion: Voting isn't actually productive or necessary
premises: however, i just can't shake the feeling that it doesn't really do anything. my singular vote doesn't mean anything. the electoral college and what my state is held by matters. like, i'm in texas so my vote for beto isn't gonna matter because my district is so gerrymandered that my liberal section of the state is partioned out with smaller, conservative west texas. i have voted democrat in every past election and it doesn't matter because the state is held by republicans. i'm not here to debate republican vs democrat by the way. cmv.
argument: Voting isn't actually productive or necessary : however, i just can't shake the feeling that it doesn't really do anything. my singular vote doesn't mean anything. the electoral college and what my state is held by matters. like, i'm in texas so my vote for beto isn't gonna matter because my district is so gerrymandered that my liberal section of the state is partioned out with smaller, conservative west texas. i have voted democrat in every past election and it doesn't matter because the state is held by republicans. i'm not here to debate republican vs democrat by the way. cmv.
auto_conc: i don't think my vote matters in this election.
gt: everyone seems to feel this way when it comes to election day but we so easily lose track of the link to the the actions behaviors of these officials throughout the rest of the term. lets assume you are super cynical about politics and you feel that all politicians are cheats and liars. they are still elected officials and and the end of the day have to pay lip service to the voters and make it look like they care about their constituents. that need to put on the air of caring for the people will influence the way that they are writing legislation and making deals which actually benefits people. maybe it is a 80 greed 20 social benefit kind of deal but imagine if those same people did not have to care about voters then it would be 100 greed all the time in which case you lose that 20 benefit. knowing that people are at least generally watching does have an effect. so even with a cynical view of the government it is super important to maintain voting as a healthy institution. the less that people care about politics the less that politicians will care about people and the most direct avenue for expressing care about politics is voting. if you are less cynical about politics then the rate of return for the value of voting only goes up.
masked_conc_attacks: the electoral college is meant to be a check against the power of the states. your vote doesn't matter because it doesn't really matter. it matters because you don't have the power to influence the outcome of a presidential election.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you. however, i think it's important to remember that there are a lot of people who don't vote, and that they don't have the means to vote. for example, if you don't want to vote, you're not going to vote in the next election. you're going to have to vote for the next president, and you're also going to be voting for the people who have the power to do so. it's not just a matter of whether or not you vote, it's about how you vote. if you're in a swing state, you can vote for whoever you want, but you can't vote for who you want to represent.
auto_conc_attacks: you don't have to vote for beto. you can vote for any candidate you want. you just have to make sure you vote for the person you want to represent.

conclusion: The Lefts impression of Trump would be a lot better if he would just shut up and get on with it.
premises: i'm no expert on american politics, and i live in new zealand, so i'm pretty far removed from everything that is going on. but it appears to me that people who identify with 'the left' have demonised trump i think rightly based primarily on his seemingly poor work ethic, and his tendency to speak out of turn or at unnecessary targets. trump is flawed, yes, but i think any elected official is going to be his views are no more obscene than those held by any number of politicians around the world. it's the way trump vocalises them that is a problem.

gt: i think you are missing a bit of the american perspective. trump not the illness, but the symptom. our country trips over its own outrage too much to ever have the proper focus on actual policy that you will find in other democracies.
masked_conc_attacks: i think the problem is that trump is not the most qualified candidate for the job. he's not the least qualified for the position. he has a lot of baggage, but he's a decent candidate. he is not a good president. he doesn't have a good record. he isn't a good leader. he can't be a good politician. he will be a terrible president. but he can be a great president. and that's what makes him a great leader.
known_conc_attacks: i think the problem is that he's not going to change how people think of him. he's going to have to change the way people think about him. it's not like he'll just shut up and get on with it, it's that he'll have to convince people that he is a good person. that's not a good thing.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're misunderstanding what trump is. he is not a bad person, he is just a different person. i don't think he is as bad as people make him out to be, but i do think he's a good person.

conclusion: The mainstream (US) Left and Right are both equally divisive.
premises: i would first note that i'm specifically talking about the mainstream dialogue, not the radicals on either end of the perspective. also, i am apolitical partially due to my career and do not favor either party or vote. i've noticed as several recent pieces of literature state the right wing is the source of political division as if it is axiomatic. i'm not talking about low hanging fruit types huffpo, salon, etc but legitimate academic works including straight talk on trade by dani rodrik president of political economy harvard and a world in disarray by richard haass president of the council on foreign relations . that said, historically, it's very clear that the right has been the perpetrator of division on race and every other aspect. but lately, it sure seems that the liberal wing is resorting to identity politics on the level of the early 20th century. there is division between urban and rural that smells like the pre holodomor period in ukraine, white supremacy living in the ether like alleged schemes of jewry in the northern european plain, and an attack on religious attitudes that resembles the ideas that led up to the early 1900's christian armenian genocide in turkey. i'm not positing that we're on the brink of a catastrophe. it can't be quantified necessarily, but it's definitely there: paul ryan has identified as such. change my view. i would also add that from my experience on reddit only been here for about a month , the left wing is brutal to the point of downvoting moderate ideas that exist in law today, or the current state of the economy, such as employment figures. as someone who pays attention to political polling, i'm aware that this isn't the state of the country at large.

gt: first i ll address the points you ve made. iq tests have lots of intraracial diversity. serbia is an almost entirely white country. their average iq is 89, much closer to the american black average of 85 than the american white average of 102. why would we see this if it s racially based? in addition to this, the american black iq of 85 is much higher than the african black iqs, which delve low into the 70s, yet american blacks on average have a european admixture of about 20 , not nearly enough to bring up the iq 15 points. second, the civilization argument is unconvincing. why didn t asians dominate if iq is directly related to civilization? whites did way more with lower iqs. calculus, space travel, atomic bombs, colonizing the world, creating industry. how did this happen if asians have higher iqs? and let s look at the middle east. iraq created mesopotamia with an iq of 87, why can t blacks do the same with 85? saudi arabia has the same iq as uganda 84 . india created thriving civilizations with an iq of 82. shouldn t ugandans be able to make the same civilizations as india? what s your response to the following counter points? 1. the flynn effect. intelligence actually increases over time despite genes remaining the same, implying that environment plays a much larger role than previously thought. 2. gender iq gap once existed, no longer does. let s debate anything said above or anything i didn t include mentioned in your op.

known_conc_attacks: i don't think you can really argue that there are significant, genetic differences in intelligence between races. i think you're making a false equivalence. there are genetic differences between races, but they are not necessarily genetic. for example, there are differences in iq between asians, whites, hispanics, and africans. this is not because of genetic differences, but because of the fact that there is a very strong correlation between iq and intelligence.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm going to try to change your view by saying that i don't think you have a good reason to believe that racial differences in iq are the result of evolution. the reason that iq is so high is because iq isn't correlated with race, it's correlated with socioeconomic status. there's a lot of evidence to support that, but i'm not sure if it's a good argument or a bad one.

conclusion: Defining sexuality as "attraction to sex" is an unhelpful way for people to label themselves: it should instead be "attraction to gender".
premises: small background: argued this point in another post, but the discussion was pretty cancerous and got nowhere, so i won't bother linking it; but feel free to look it up in my post history if interested the big comments, basically . i am very interested in legitimate counter arguments, so i posted this here. words have definitions, and are used to describe the world in useful ways. definitions cannot be proven wrong because they are axiomatic: they change overtime when a new definition for word x is better , not when the old definition is 'wrong'. this is not a good argument, as i see it. it's the rhetorical equivalent of 'it's wrong because it's not right', when the debate isn't about right or wrong, but more vs less useful, and definitions are never estabilished fact they change along time, locale, context, even between dictionaries . also: reminder that gender is, in pragmatic terms, gender identity expression, independent from sex. and for those unaware, 'trans woman' means male to female transgender, vice versa for trans men. just to avoid potential confusion. onto the real point: why is my definition more useful? as you can probably deduce from the title, the proposed 'change' has a lot to do with trans people. let's take a cis male attracted to cis and trans women. under the old definition, he is bisexual. however, why should he ever label himself as such? since he doesn't like men, cis or trans, he is not interested in showing availability to them: by labeling himself as bisexual, he is opening himself to that dating market, which he does not want to do. trans women generally view themselves as women, so they wouldn't show more interest towards a man who showed availability to other men; that is irrelevant to her. let's take another example: a cis male attracted to only cis women, 'straight' on the old definition: the change makes absolutely no difference. a potential counterargument is that he doesn't want to be open to dating trans women, but he can reject them, just as he would any other woman he doesn't like. an obvious counter argument to this counter argument, is that under the old definition, i could similarly say he is opening himself to trans men like buck angel someone a straight man is most likely not attracted to, so the argument is self defeating. deltas to whoever makes me rethink anything about this

'

conclusion: There should be no choice when it comes to organ donation after your death

free life for every person without a need for them to survive. ideally currently unrealistic , people just would survive. i don't know how i'm sure we're hundreds of years away from this solution and it would take more than just me to figure it out but it's beside the point. some believe that i think that things are just going to appear but throughout, i've only referenced resources necessary for survival. just a world where your basic needs are met. that doesn't mean tv, or movies, or anything that you don't absolutely need. those other things are wants not needs. so if you wanted something, of course you'd work for it. but if you needed something, that's different.

conclusion: its good to correct peoples grammar.
premises: i ve been seeing it more and more lately. people using fewer instead of less or people using are to refer to groups instead of is . i m not an english major. i haven t even taken more english classes than the average person. so please don t mistake this as an english major trying to strut their stuff and feel superior. i understand that it s just the internet and people have argued that proper use only really matters if you are writing a paper or an email to a boss or a colleague. but over a long enough period of time, improper usage of basic skills leads to the proper usage becoming forgotten. right? now if i m just being overly picky about these i m more than happy to hear why. just be nice about it.
argument: its good to correct peoples grammar. : i ve been seeing it more and more lately. people using fewer instead of less or people using are to refer to groups instead of is . i m not an english major. i haven t even taken more english classes than the average person. so please don t mistake this as an english major trying to strut their stuff and feel superior. i understand that it s just the internet and people have argued that proper use only really matters if you are writing a paper or an email to a boss or a colleague. but over a long enough period of time, improper usage of basic skills leads to the proper usage becoming forgotten. right? now if i m just being overly picky about these i m more than happy to hear why. just be nice about it.
auto_conc: i think people who use "in a day and age" as a way to refer to something are just lazy.
gt: i think it depends on context. for the record, i was an english major and i am an english teacher so, literally, part of my job includes correcting grammar . however, i think in addition to tone how you do it, when you do it matters a lot. sometimes it's better to focus on what people mean and correcting their grammar makes them feel less heard. so if the person is saying or writing something serious, address the content, not the style. make them feel heard. even in the classroom, it's important to separate revising content based workshops from ing grammar and spelling because people naturally get lost in pedantic issues rather than truly improving their expression. at the end of the day, meaning should be highly prioritized over style which should be prioritized over grammar. i'm fine with grammar bots, and i'll answer grammatical questions. people love to ask english teachers grammar questions. honestly, i love talking the finer points of grammar sometimes, as well as linguistics in general. but i see a lot of derailment from truly communication happening when someone chooses to nitpick grammar instead of looking at meaning. grammar rules exist to facilitate meaning in the end.

conclusion: The USA is too litigious and strict with law, and it negatively impacts a lot of us.
premises: from invention creation on patents to multi million dollar lawsuits against medical companies, it seems to me that those who want to change our nation, often for the better, have to worry an unreasonable amount about the legal implications of their desires. from wanting to cure people the best you can, or in a way more similar to eastern medicine, to wanting to improve technology it seems there is often a law that restricts or regulates a person's ability to really get as far as they otherwise could. secondly i believe the desire to go to court over so many things creates an amount of hostility and fear in others. it limits many of our amendments, because you can sue someone over nearly anything we become afraid to say and do things we have every right to do. yet, the better lawyer often wins, not the actual person in the right, or in the wrong. i'm not saying we should dump lawyers as a profession, or litigation as a means of correcting a wrong. i am saying that billboard signs suggesting you take something to court is over the top, and measures should be taken to make this society more responsible and interactive. certainly some good arguments for having our court system and litigation as a means of compensation, protection, etc still searching for the point that would make america seem balanced in this aspect, though. u oneshomeisonescastle has brought up a very good point that there is no real way to go about changing how things are, i offer nothing in the way of 'fixing' the issue i bring up, and because of my general lack of experience on the topic, any fixes i'd suggest would likely break the system more i. e. people would have less access to legal services when it would be much better if they need them i don't entirely concede my original point, but somewhat digress there's nothing better i can offer.

conclusion: Marrying younger is a great option. (Not child brides but 19-early twenties, at least finish high school first!)
premises: my wife f25 and i m27 got married young. i was 21 and she was 19. i didn t have any engrained habits that needed to be reconciled with another person. i don t have a certain way that i load the dishwasher, budget my money, fold towels, soap preference, side of the bed i sleep on, etc. small things aren t an issue because we both came up with them together. 2. we developed as adults together so we formed to complement each other. i often joke that we are a one hermaphroditic blog with one mind because we have similar stances on issues. we don t have irreconcilable differences because we didn t have any engrained stances. no rvsd debates in on our house! i also always had someone to call me out on my youthful bullshit still do! 3. being married doesn t mean that i can t developer as healthy a individual. we have separate hobbies interests, viewpoints and tastes. there are plenty of things we can do separately. 4. also, i don t have the fomo fear of missing out about sowing my wild oats because i have an automatic sex buddy! 5. it s a better financial situation for broke young kids. now i m finishing up engineering degree and i have a sugar mama ; we also got tax breaks from an early age. there are more write offs for both being students at some point and there s a tax break for being married. there are many more minute points but the main ones are 1, 2 and 5. i think couples who get married young have a greater potential to do great.

auto_conc: i think getting married young is a good thing.
gt: aged 20 to 30 is arguably one of the most transformative times in ones life. yes, people can and do get and stay married during this time, but the risk factor is high because of this reason. the ideals and goals one has at 20 is almost always a very far stretch from where the ones arrives at 30 with, and because of that, binding your life with another person is not exactly the wisest thing to do. im not saying it can't work, i'm just saying it typically doesn't work and this is the main reason. marriage stands a better chance once both parties have moved through this period of growth. for some, they can grow together and find they want the same things out of life, but the reality is that most do not. i speak as someone who started dating my husband at 20, married at 26 and were still happily married at 35. so i know what's possible, but for every couple like us, there's 5 others who had the opposite experience.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think you're wrong, but i think it's important to realize that you're not the only person who got married young. if you're the only one who was married young, you're probably the least likely to get married young in the first place.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. if you're married young, you're likely to have a lot of different hobbies, interests, viewpoints, tastes, etc. you're probably going to have more hobbies and interests than you'd have if you were married young. you might also have a few hobbies that you've developed as adults, such as cooking, reading, and listening to music. you may not have a certain way that you load the dishwasher, budget your money, fold towels, soap preference, side of the bed i sleep on etc. but that doesn't mean you don't have hobbies or interests that need to be reconciled with another person. it's not like you're going to get married young and you're not going to be able to do anything with your life without a partner.
auto_conc_attacks: you seem to be conflating two very different things. i don't think it's a good thing to get married young because you don't have any engrained habits that needed to be reconciled with another person. it's not a bad thing to be married young, but it's also not a good idea to be in a relationship with someone who doesn't have the same interests, viewpoints and tastes as you. there are plenty of things you can do separately that you can't developer as healthy a individual, but you can develop as healthy as you developed as an adult. i think you're missing out on a lot of things that you could develop as a healthy individual. i'm not saying that you're a one hermaphroditic blog with one mind because you have irreconcilable differences because you didn't have an automatic sex buddy, but i think that's an important distinction.

conclusion: The US needs a Constitutional Convention
premises: hopefully this isn't too common a topic on cmv; the last post to put it this way was 2 years ago and more recent ones were more narrowly defined and are nearly a year old themselves . it had a great run it's the oldest constitution in continuous use, but most modern constitutions are written to be updated more frequently and actually are. ours is only really updated by supreme court decisions, with only 2 amendments being ratified in the last 50 years one of which was first proposed in 1789! til . the founders could not have imagined the world we live in today or its challenges, and the document is written as such. flawed solutions like the electoral college were created to solve problems of the 18th century that are irrelevant in the 21st. the founding fathers saw tyrannical government as the biggest threats to the rights of individuals, and wrote the constitution to protect those rights. that was logical in their day, but that is not the threat that those of us in modern democracies face. tyrannical companies taking from an article that's currently on the front page are the primary threat to individual rights and freedoms, and our government and constitution is not equipped to deal with that threat. i'm sure i'll get into more specific critiques in the comments, but that buildup of history and precedent makes justice incredibly difficult to come by in many instances and needs revision. if you haven't, i'd urge you to read the text. it takes like 20 minutes for the main text; probably 40 60 with amendments and is available everywhere. one of the main arguments that will likely be raised that will not change my view is the political will difficulty argument. i know it would be hard or impossible to make happen, especially given current politics.

auto_conc: I think affirmative action is wrong and should be abolished.
gt: i have 2 point. 1 is that it's used as a statistical tool. where they want to know how many of a specific race or gender is applied or attending so that info can be used for various things. one thing that info is used for is to make sure that an equal opportunity is presented for all. like a collage that leans toward accepting students of a particular race. this information would make it harder for schools to selectively pick from highschool's using the methodology that you can dertermine within reasonablity a persons race economic level from the school they went to that have a higher chance of giving them a student of a race economic level that they want. 2 it is used for pr. one of the main things that collages love to talk about is how diverse they are. to avoid the 'then they are picking them for there race' argument that could stem from that line of thinking it would be best to put it in terms of value to the other students. a student who can bring in firsthand knowledge of another culture and share that knowledge with other students would be more beneficial to the school to have them enrolled there. colleges are a business first so it makes sense for them to do what helps them the most.

conclusion: A joint account with a percentage-of-income (with a few other considerations) is the best way to split money
premises: i know this can have a lot of exceptions. please don't make your arguments about pointing out 2 or 3 exceptions that are technically true. i'll list a few to save the trouble: a person with reckless spending or addiction gambling issues should not have this split. significant inheritances should not necessarily have this split the extremely rich or extremely poor should not necessarily have this split massive debts massive differences in work time lots of other exceptions but for most people, i think this split is the best method. money has an economic value. if you compare the salary of a strategic consulting manager and a veterinarian assistant, you're going to get 200k versus 40k or something crazy. but in a relationship, i don't think economic value should necessarily be considered, unless the difference in income is so vast that one person's income is literally chump change i. e. 500k vs 30k . in a relationship, especially that of a marriage, the 'most important value' is time and effort of the individual. person1 makes 80k after taxes; person2 makes 40k. person1 would input 40k into their joint account, while person2 inputs 20k. as a result, in real money, person1 is providing more. person2 is also providing 50 . caveat. please read this caveat. let's say for example i make 100k and my partner makes 20k. i put in 50k and keep 50k while she puts in 10k and keeps 10k. unfortunately, that means that i get to live it up and have a pretty damn good life whereas she has to keep both savings and expenses under 800 per month. so why this view? 1. 2. provides freedom to both people and rewards high earners in exchange for providing more this allows both parties to win. 3. this makes their life much more difficult and makes them less capable of affording more. 4. gifts are more meaningful in a fully shared money situation, gifts are important but also become difficult to justify. makes for a difficult situation. 5. use your own money. no problem! want to buy a ps4? no need to ask me, go for it! want to go out and treat 10 people out to drinks? go for it! not my money, not my problem. again this is basically the freedom argument. caveats i know there are exceptions to this rule. i'll try to list out as many as i can. and yes some of this repeats from the beginning of the post but i thought mentioning it twice makes it more likely for everyone to see it. here's a real life example. i make 80k and my girlfriend makes 30k post taxes. but neither of us works harder than the other. she makes 30k because she chose a career that's important for the world, but pays very very little. if we do a 75 75 split, then i end up keeping 20k per year. she gets 7. 5k. maximum retirement contribution is 5. 5k. so now i have 14. 5k left and she only has 2k. 2k for a whole year is nothing. she can barely afford anything for herself. i keep 20k, she gets 15k. now it's more even, now it's fairer. cmv

auto_conc: i think the most sensible split of money in a relationship or any relationship is: "you get what you deserve, she gets what she can afford."
gt: while i haven't personally dealt with large scale financing with a long term partner, i have been on many multi day dates or trips with friends that involved some amount of covering who paid for what, or people paying up front for rooms and getting paid back by the group later, or whatever. what i noticed was that there were two very distinct philosophies regarding payment. some people wanted extremely equitable payments, keeping track of most all expenses and the relative amount owed by most everybody. they would be very upset if they felt transactions were 'unfair', or if people failed to remember even minor exchanges who went on a donut run in the morning, or w e . another group of people, while obviously not willing to cover everything for people, would basically just take things as they went and expect all the little expenses to even out over time. if they noticed a trend e. g. they're paying for every donut run , they'd bring it up and ask somebody else to cover, but not try to figure out how much anybody 'owed'. to this group of people, not only did they not need to have everything turn out 100 equitably all the time, it was actually deeply unpleasant to deal with the sort of exact tallying and scorekeeping and reminders that were part of keeping things equitable. to use an analogy, it's the difference between the people who keep track of whose turn it is to buy a round at the bar, versus the people who figure that rounds at the bar will even out in the long term. relationships are no doubt the same way. some people might really want things to be equitable and to figure out exactly how much is appropriate to spend and who pays for what from the get go. if that's what works for you, more power to you. but plenty of people don't want that, and in fact find that sort of tallying to be a tremendous and unnecessary burden when a combination of trust not caring about exact quantities spent works out well enough.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you in principle. however, i don't think it's the best way to split your wealth. i think it should be split between two people, but that's not the same as splitting it between a man and a woman. there are plenty of ways to split money, but i think there are a lot of different ways to do it.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to look at the pros and cons of a joint account. if one person makes 80k and the other person makes 20k, it's a huge difference. if the two people make a 50 split, they're going to have to pay the same amount in taxes. if they don't, then they're not going to be able to afford to have the joint account at all.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the argument. if you're going to have a relationship, you have to make sure that you're both in the same financial situation. if someone is making 100k a year, and you're making 10k a month, then you're probably not going to be able to afford to have that split. but if you are going to make 100k, you're also going to need to make 10k, which is a lot of money. it's not like you're giving 100k to the other person, but it's still a lot more money than you're supposed to be giving to them.

premises: watch this video to get a basic understanding of this discussion amp; x200b; here is my brief response: 1. there's a reason for dominant and recessive traits in our dna. genetic traits develop as we evolve to survive in our specific ecosystem. superior traits in male adults physical strength, endurance, intelligence, skin tone, etc attract females they can't help but be attracted, they're coded this way because they have a higher chance of survival in that specific part of the earth. he chooses the equally genetically desirable female. 2. regarding aggressive behavior, adam misrepresents the traits of the dominant male. the meek rule the earth. listen to the world's most powerful people speak. the last thing they are is aggressive because it displays a weakness in their ability to control their own emotions. being kind also actually takes more balls than being an asshole, simply because we are socially conditioned to think 'asshole she will let me fuck her', and if you go against the grain to be a man of honor, you will encounter resistance, but reap huge rewards as your character is revealed. change my view!

gt: your premises correct me if i m misrepresenting you :1 some traits in men are more preferable2 these preferable traits are genetic3 women s desire for these traits is also geneticto take each point in turn:1 no contest, if your talking in generalities2 some preferable traits are also environmental being born into a wealthy family and learned knowing how to cook 3 if we only wanted things for genetic reasons, women would idealize the same sorts of men over every time period. similarly, what kind of women men prefer changes in the 1700s, it was full figured women, in the 1970s it was narrow waisted women. if sexual desire is hardwired, it wouldn t be malleable. that it changes overtime suggests it s at least partially a software thing, as opposed to a hardware thing. evolutionary psychology is interesting, but it sometimes borders pseudoscience when it makes causal claims. usually, evolutionary psychology presents a theory that explains human behavior however, unless a theory is tested, it is just a hypothesis, a hunch. moreover, as this hypothesis does not explain all the facts, such as why our conception of the ideal man changes over time and culture, it s not even that good a hypothesis.

conclusion: I would have a happier, more fulfilled life if I didn't have to work.
premises: this belief dives into many parts of my life so i'll go through each. to me, working makes us slaves. people are forced to get jobs just to survive. everyday feels like a fight for my life. i feel as though if people were told that they could have food, water, a house, car and education for free, then we would have no worries to just do what we wanted to do with our lives. personally, if i could just spend my days carving wood, writing a book, or anything leisurely by myself, i would do it. don't confuse that sentence with 'i want to make a business out of those things i love' because i don't. if someone told me i could carve wood as my job, i'd be upset because then it loses the leisure. that once leisurely activity then becomes a means of my survival, the root of my fight or flight response, my anxiety and i don't want that. it's become clear that many are focusing on the 'needing some work for fulfillment' and the 'liesure leading to depression' answers. so i feel the need to expand my post to include that i'm more referring to working to survive. generally, i'm a busy body but working to survive is awful. maybe the cmv is actually 'the need for money survival prevents me from living a fulfilling life'. some have confused my desire to live a life without a need for survival as a desire to have anyone else help me survive and in that you'd be wrong. a stress free life for every person without a need for them to survive. ideally currently unrealistic , people just would survive. i don't know how i'm sure we're hundreds of years away from this solution and it would take more than just me to figure it out but it's beside the point. some believe that i think that things are just going to appear but throughout, i've only referenced resources necessary for survival. just a world where your basic needs are met. that doesn't mean tv, or movies, or anything that you don't absolutely need. those other things are wants not needs. so if you wanted something, of course you'd work for it. but if you needed something, that's different.

gt: depends on how you mean. if you mean live in the current society but without working and everyone else does, with you being unaffected, or society doesn t truly exist and everyone is free to do whatever. either way, you can look at it from this pov. the human brain naturally gives incentive to progress, weather its building shelters, eating food or getting money, the brain rewards good actions that help the body. but the world has changed since we truly had to hunt food. so many replaced that with there jobs. and money being the prey. the brain rewards you for progression at work, like a raise. because the brain loves to work on big projects that take a ton of time. without the jobs, you wouldn t get the reward. this is where a lot of rich people get depression. they have reached the peak and can t go any farther up. obviously find a job your interested in and can stick with so your brain can make you happy.

conclusion: It's unethical to accuse someone of sexual assault after 4 decades
premises: a great example of this rush to judgement is chris hardwick, who was actually removed from his show at amc based on allegations from his ex girlfriend chloe dykstra. so now we have a woman coming forward nearly 40 years later to accuse a supreme court nominee of groping her while in high school. aside from the fact that the timing makes her political motivations interesting and aside from the fact that her story does seem credible and aside from the fact that she apparently isn't willing to testify about it which is perhaps the worst part amp; x200b; there is a reason most criminal charges have a statute of limitations. for someone in brett kavanaugh's position, how could he reasonably be expected to defend the allegations in a meaningful way, in a way where he can clear his name with certainty? where were you on this day 36 years ago? who were you with? do you have an alibi? there can be no physical evidence collected or pictures taken, or detailed police reports of the events. the accuracy of of the statements of potential witnesses of an incident evidence shows eyewitness testimony isn't as accurate as we thought, and it gets worse over time. christine ford doesn't even know for sure when the assault took place, but she thinks it was 1982. amp; x200b;

gt: it seems that a large number of children were sexually assaulted by priests over an extended period of time in their lives. some children were even given a special crucifix so that other priests could recognize them and molest them too. given the special nature of a trusted father figure, the purposefully instilled belief that you somehow caused the sin in the first place, the fact that people really do lose their memories of such traumatic events and only remember them much later in life, the need to stop someone from ever doing such a thing again no matter their age, and potentially stop others from molesting by showing them they can be charged at any time of their life, i'd say there's a fairly ethical reason to allow people to come forward 40 years later.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the judicial system. it's not about protecting innocent people from prosecution, it's about protecting the people who are innocent. if you're going to prosecute someone for sexual assault, you need to do it in a way that protects the people that are innocent, not just the ones who are guilty. that's why we have a criminal justice system. there's no such thing as a perfect system. we don't need to protect innocent people. we just need to make sure that innocent people don't have to go to jail for their crimes.
