auto_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the law. there is a law that says you have to prove that you are a sexual assault victim, and that you should be able to prove your innocence. the law also says that you can't prove that someone committed a crime, but that you cannot prove that they committed it in the first place. this is the same law that has been applied to rape cases since the civil rights act of 1964. it's not that there isn't a statute of limitations, it's that there are a lot of things that need to be done to prove a person's innocence. that's why there are so many cases in which we don't have a standard of proof.

conclusion: Poe Dameron was not simply just wrong for questioning Admiral Holdo and taking action, nor was he the "true villain" of TLJ.
premises: i think i maybe should've made this 'cmv: holdo should have done something to inspire all members of the resistance to trust in her and not come up with a plan of their own especially considering poe's history . ' poe obviously made some serious mistakes previously, but i believe that in regards to the chase and their plans, he and holdo were both right and wrong in some respects. i recently had a discussion with someone where they told me that they thought that he should have just trusted her and done as he was told, that all in the military should always follow their orders without question though i'm not trying to open another rabbit hole with that , and that the scene was meant to illustrate how men need to just shut up and listen to women. she may have had a plan and it may have worked and by that one could argue that she was right; i see this as a parallel to the jedi at large. i believe this ties in with luke's saying the jedi need to end and all of that to illustrate how even if one group may be in some way right, if they can't effectively communicate why they're right or something else to get people to trust in it enough to actually implement it, it's not going to succeed or produce the desired change or outcome regardless. like how much anakin was preached to about the evils of the dark side but was never communicated the realities of it well enough to successfully instill in him what it would take to get him to have not gone down that path. holdo failed as a leader by failing to instill the faith in her needed for her plan to work successfully. it's 100 fair for her to not have wanted to divulge specific details in an effort to safeguard the plan, but given what she thought of poe as a person i think it's completely fair to say that she definitely should have at least simply told him that she did have a plan and that she wasn't just going to let them all die without even trying to do anything, which is what she led them to believe was happening. she didn't even have a look of confidence when saying what she said to the crew, again that could have been intentional in an effort to keep the plan secret, but she should have said something more to, at least, poe. what good is a leader who knows exactly how to fix all our problems if they aren't actually a leader and can't get people to actually do the things to make those changes happen? poe was faced with a situation where he was basically told that they were just going to fly til they ran out of fuel and the enemies caught up and killed them, without even trying to do anything about it. he was given, so far as i perceived, no reason to support this order other than the fact that she was of superior rank. he made the call in his mind that since they were just going to let them all die that he would at least come up with a plan to try and do something about it, a plan which a black guy and an asian woman both also supported and helped to come up with but no one seems to talk about the black guy or asian woman who also didn't follow holdo and supported taking action on their own . this whole thing seems to be getting reduced to being about sex, or more specifically, the evils of white males and the patriarchy, and the fact that a black guy and asian woman also opposed holdo doesn't fit in with that notion very well. the other person also said how if he just would have followed his superior's order how the plan would have worked perfectly. one could, perhaps fairly, say that this wouldn't even be a factor or a point for me to make if he had followed orders, but i can also, i believe fairly, say that if finn and rose had followed orders and gotten the right person at the casino instead of deciding that they could make due with the option that presented itself as opposed to the one they were ordered to find that then poe's plan would have worked. really, both plans could have actually simultaneously worked. if finn and rose had gotten the right person and managed to covertly board the enemy ship and disable their shields, anyone not necessary for the fight could have escaped in the landing pods and just a few could have stayed back to try and destroy the enemy ship; in which case they would again already be facing death and if the battle started going south then they could have still simply flew lightspeed through it as holdo did on her own. i may be wrong but i think it's also fair to speculate that it would have taken fewer people in the ship for the battle than the number that died in the pods in the failed escape attempt. the last jedi, to me, was about how much more complicated these things are than any of us generally like to contend with. about the problems with the mindset of 'i'm right so you just need to shut up and do what i say because i'm right. ' they may damn well be right but that is certainly not an effective way to act because it will not inspire people to come to follow you. we must demand more of our leaders and we must be more sympathetic to and have more empathy for those we view as being in opposition to us, if not out of care for them out of care for actually advancing your own correctness instead of just ranting about how smart you are and how dumb everyone else is and how the world would be so much better if we just listened to you continuously because no matter how much you rant it doesn't cause the change you wish to see. yoda told luke that the best thing he may have to offer as a teaching are his mistakes, and from that he tells leia that no one is ever really gone. they can't give up on kylo, ben is still there. luke can't try to kill his nephew because of a dream he had and we can't declare people to be evil and delete them from our lives because they voted for trump. if we actually are so much ' poe obviously made some serious mistakes previously, but i believe that in regards to the chase and their plans, he and holdo were both right and wrong in some respects. i recently had a discussion with someone where they told me that they thought that he should have just trusted her and done as he was told, that all in the military should always follow their orders without question though i'm not trying to open another rabbit hole with that , and that the scene was meant to illustrate how men need to just shut up and listen to women. she may have had a plan and it may have worked and by that one could argue that she was right; i see this as a parallel to the jedi at large. i believe this ties in with luke's saying the jedi need to end and all of that to illustrate how even if one group may be in some way right, if they can't effectively communicate why they're right or something else to get people to trust in it enough to actually implement it, it's not going to succeed or auto_conc: poe and finn were both right in some respects
gt: i think your view can boil down to yes and no . as an enlisted service member, i can tell you that poe was 100 wrong. and if he had pulled that stunt in the armed forces, he would have been tossed in jail and court martialed. there are two levels in the battlefield; tactical and strategic. poe, as a fighter pilot directly albeit the best in the resistance is at the tactical level. his technical knowledge is incredibly strong, he can think on his feet, and he can be relied on to win any battle. admiral holdo is at the strategic level. she s not focused on the battles, though winning them is important; she s focused on the war. a consequence of that is what leads to a lot of lower ranking officers and enlisted personnel not thinking very highly of anyone with stars on their shoulders; generals and admirals are often not seen as being very in touch with their junior personnel. holdo has the entire resistance to think about, not just the ego of the hot shot fly boy who just cost them their entire bomber fleet. but this is where the resistance itself comes into play. the resistance is not a military. they have ranks, but not uniforms, and a very loose chain of command which can beat be described as tldr; leia s in charge. i would honestly classify them as more of a guerrilla unit than an army. without those reinforced chains of command, you open yourself up to a situation where a junior officer leading others into a mutiny could happen. you could argue that this is a good thing, but at the end of the day you have a situation where poe jeopardized the escape plan holdo put together because he didn t trust his leadership.

auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that poe didn't have a plan, but i do think she did have a very good reason to believe that she had a plan.

conclusion: Casual dating (and casual sex) is inherently dehumanizing
premises: for instance, if you date someone just to make your ex jealous, you're clearly using and dehumanizing your partner. that example's pretty clearly wrong, but there are lots more that seem pretty innocent at first: if you're just dating around to find out what you like, aren't you just treating the other person as a means to an end? if you're dating someone casually because you just went through a tough breakup and feel like you deserve something light and fun, aren't you using that person as a substitute for a feeling? if you pick someone you wouldn't ordinarily date because you're sick of being single, are they just an emotional crutch? if you date someone in school you know will be moving away in a couple of years, are they anything more than a placeholder for a person? if you feel sorry for your nice single friend and go out with them to boost their self esteem, are you treating them as you would want to be treated? it seems to me that in each of these cases, you'd be guilty of using your partner. i can't think of any. a good rule of thumb might be: if your partner asks, 'why did you decide to go out with me? ' and you're reluctant to tell them the real reason, you're probably using them and you should probably break up with them. response 1: 'as long as it's between consenting adults, there's nothing wrong with it and we shouldn't judge them too harshly. ' consent is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for an action to be ethical. that is, for a relationship to be ethical, it must at a minimum be consensual, but it takes more than that. it must also be genuinely good in the long term for all parties involved. for instance, it wouldn't be ethical for two completely incompatible people to date each other just because they're both terrified of being alone, even if they both consent to it. they could even hurt others if they have children. response 2: 'as long as you're upfront about your motives, you're in the clear. ' few people are willing to be so upfront, precisely because they're aware of how much it makes them sound like a sociopath. 'i had a bad breakup and i'm just looking for a rebound. you cool with that? ' few people say that sort of thing upfront. and if you are upfront, sure, it may lessen your burden of guilt, but that doesn't mean you should be doing it in the first place. if you sell someone placebo drugs, and you tell them upfront, 'hey these drugs probably won't do a damn thing. i'm just trying to make a cheap buck. ' and they buy them anyway, sure, that's better than lying to them about it. but isn't it even better not to sell placebo drugs at all? similarly, if someone's just a rebound for you, it's better if you tell them that upfront rather than make them think they're special, but isn't it better still not to use someone that way in the first place? besides, our motives are often obscure even to ourselves. we may not realize someone was a rebound until the relationship is over. if you're not really, truly excited about someone after a few dates, then what are you still doing with them? response 3: sex is no big deal. it's just our messed up society that puts such an unhealthy emphasis on it. our society probably does have an unhealthy attitude toward sex. but sex is a big deal, and it's not just another activity like skiing. otherwise, we can't explain why forced sex is a special kind of crime. here's what i mean. rape is a serious crime, one that can potentially cause serious psychological damage. likewise, it's a serious crime for an adult to have sex with a child. part of the reason is that they can't meaningfully consent to sex. but why is meaningful consent necessary in this case? young children can't meaningfully consent to getting their hair cut or being taken skiing, either, but that's no crime. rape and sex with children are evil because it's a particularly heinous type of violation, perhaps a violation of something that should be sacred. it's not just an activity that our society places too much emphasis on. sex is intimate in a way that can cause lasting psychological damage if forced upon someone. presumably this is because sex is so deeply rooted in our biology that we can't help but have certain psychological reactions to it. sex does something to you, and you can't necessarily help it no matter how enlightened you are. or even if you can completely separate sex from all the messy emotions, you can't know if your casual partner is capable of doing the same, because you don't know them well. if sex is special, perhaps even sacred, we're playing with fire if we act as if it's no big deal. we risk hurting ourselves and others psychologically, even if it's all perfectly consensual. addendum: there's some part of me that still feels like i'm being ridiculous and unrealistic about my approach to dating, but my conscience won't be clear unless i can see why. or if i'm not being ridiculous, then at least i'll feel more confident about refusing to date anyone for any reason who doesn't meet my possibly unrealistic standards. i can't seem to settle this on my own, so i would appreciate some outside perspective and wisdom.

conclusion: Card games like Magic The Gathering are not gambling
premises: you generally know what you are going to get for your money using mtg as the example, you're going to get 15 cards, with a rare, 3 uncommons, and the rest commons. sometimes you get a foil card, sometimes a mythic rare, but it's always the same number of cards. these cards ostensibly all have the same value they can all be used to play the game they are for, and it's up to you, the player, to determine which cards warrant a place in your deck. the game's producer makes no claim about which cards are more valuable deciding which cards work better in your deck is a core part of the gameplay, and the producer would not want to break that by telling you which ones are better. any secondary market for the cards should not be taken into account. how is it the company's responsibility that other people might be willing to pay you money for what you got in your card pack? if you are opening a box of lucky charms, and i say i am willing to pay you a quarter for every unicorn marshmallow you give me, does that mean general mills is now engaging in gambling? even if dozens of websites spring up for the purpose of buying and selling lucky charms marshmallows, general mills is still no more responsible for the market value of any given marshmallow than it is now. sight unseen auctions are legal, and i see no reason to prevent them from being so. i think this same logic extends to digital card games like hearthstone, and even to loot boxes themselves, but i'll leave that for another post.

auto_conc: general mills is no more responsible for the market value of any given card than it is now.
gt: gambling can be defined as either 'play games of chance for money; bet. ' or 'take risky action in the hope of a desired result. ' . cracking packs of magic cards fits both of these criteria. by your logic, scratch cards would also not be gambling. you are buying a product without fully knowing what it contains, likely not to make your money back, but with the possibility for a large pay off. packs of magic cards are obviously a lot lower risk as you always get something and a lot lower reward unless you are cracking alpha beta , but it is still present.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know if this will change your view, but i'd like to point out that there is a difference between buying and selling cards in a game and buying them in an auction. for example, if i buy a rare card and sell it to someone who wants to buy it, that person could buy it from me. if i sell the rare card to someone else and they want to buy the rare, that's fine, but that's not the same as buying the rare. the only difference is that the person who buys the rare is buying it from another person, and the other person doesn't.
known_conc_attacks: it's not gambling. it's gambling because you know what you are going to get for your money using mtg.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're misunderstanding the purpose of general mills. they're not gambling. they are just making money off of the cards you buy. they aren't gambling because they're making money from the cards they buy. it's gambling because the people who buy the cards are the ones who are making money, not the people buying the cards.

conclusion: Suicide should not be prevented if the person has the capacity to make decisions. The right to die should be a basic human right.

conclusion: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem.

conclusion: Too many people go to college in the US.
premises: tl;dr: i believe that the obsession with telling everyone to 'get an education' is misguided and has been incredibly harmful to our society. close to 70 amp; 37; of graduating high school students are now attending college of some sort directly after graduation. this has had a number of unfortunate results: 1. when 70 amp; 37; of the population excluding high school dropouts wants to go on to higher education, it means that there will be a mathematical guarantee that a significant amount of individuals with below average academic skills, intelligence and education will be attending. the result is that schools either must admit students that they know can't handle the workload or reduce the academic rigor in order to accommodate less capable students. 2. employers can no longer use a bachelors degree as a meaningful discriminator because they are way too common. when having a bachelors degree in a field not directly related to your job i. e. non stem was less common, an employer could infer that whoever had it was at least of an above average intelligence and academic ability, even if they didn't go to an elite educational institution. essentially saying, 'even though an english degree isn't really directly related to this job, this person still must be reasonably capable to have gotten a degree at all. ' now that degrees are handed out left and right, this is not longer useful. it is also very damaging to capable people who didn't get a degree and has forced people to take on more debt to attend graduate school or accept lower salaries in order to be competitive. 3. someone with 40th percentile intelligence is not going to be able to complete a degree in organic chemistry or mechanical engineering, so the result is they study largely useless degrees, wasting their time and money learning stuff they will never use on any job. while i certainly believe that having academics in a society has value, there is a limit of how many history and psychology degrees can be given out and still have marginal value to society. spending 4 years of your life and going deep into debt had better improve your employment prospects, and i really don't believe it does for most people of average to below average ability. go into a retail store or restaurant in a major city and odds are that multiple non management employees will have degrees. 20 years ago, this would have been unheard of. 4. it kill innovation and entrepreneurship. because so many young people come out of school with a ton of debt and no real skills even if you have a more useful degree , it kills entrepreneurship. someone of middling intelligence who has a ba in psychology isn't going to be able to start any business that they couldn't have out of high school. they certainly won't be as capable of starting a business as someone who spent those 4 years in trade school and or an apprenticeship learning how to do a real world skill. even if they have the ability, being saddled with debt means that they are less willing to take the risks required to be an entrepreneur. this is all well and good, but for something that costs as much as it does, it just doesn't make sense for the majority of people.

gt: i see how in our society we are putting way to many people into college and how that is running our economy, but the more educated workers we have in our economy the better jobs become like how in the mid 1900's many manufacturing jobs stated to go away due to the higher amount of educated people although the did not completely disappear because we still need to manufacture things the thing that ended it was automation, but you see that with an higher educated work force we get better jobs.

conclusion: As a young white man in America, I feel worthless, disconnected from and hated by women/minorities, and  though I want equality  unwelcome in the conversation.
premises: hey, r changemyview i'm struggling. sometimes, i even feel scared by it. i don't need you to convince me that equality is important, or that inequalities still exist. of course they do. nor do i need to you to explain how, as a white dude, i'm privileged. believe me, i know. but i am hoping you can help me see a better way forward than self flagellation and guilt, which doesn't help me and certainly doesn't help anybody else. everywhere i look, i see articles about how terrible people who look like me are, and i feel ashamed. but proud of who i am, deep down, as an individual person. it's hard because everywhere i look i see positive role models from other genders races, and i want to be positive, too. but white men are pretty vilified and there's not a lot of examples on how i can be a decent person and actually help. the message i get is that i should just shut up and bask in my privilege, because society is done with me. i think a part of me feels like i should suffer, because of my privilege. so i read social justice news frequently. but i'm exhausted enough so that small things are starting to get to me. today, for instance, i saw an article about whether or not 'people of color' is an acceptable term to use and i kind of lost it internally not because i don't care if the term is acceptable or not, but because i feel like i can't be this perfect white man who never offends anyone accidentally. there are so many angry articles i've read and i'd like to say that we could all be angry about the problem but it feels like we're angry at each other. and it's making it hard for me to see myself and others as individuals the exact opposite of what i want. these days i walk around feeling like people hate me, scared that even if they're nice to me they're just thinking the same things these articles say. it doesn't really feel like the narrative of equality today is, 'let's build a better world together. ' it feels more like, 'white men have caused all of these problems so you guys just go sit in a corner. ' and it makes me angry, because i want to help, and i don't believe that the best way for me to help is just go bask in my privilege and die. i want to say, i'm here for this, and i want to help, but you have to let me be an individual who is imperfect and not just 'an evil white dude'. ugh. i know this is rambling and probably incoherent the more i type, i'm getting emotional. anyway, please try to change my view. i don't want to keep feeling shitty and wind up a bitter, trump voter in 2020 lol . ps: i'm going to be here for the next few hours because i'm taking this seriously and will reply in good faith. i've got to step away for a little now but i'll check back in a few hours and reply some more.

conclusion: #BelieveAllWomen-type views on sexual assault are bad and possibly harmful.
premises: well i'm sure we all know what prompted this cmv. left leaning comments and subs all over reddit and other social media sites seem fully convinced that ford is telling the truth about kavanaugh, often citing their rationale along the lines of 'i believe women when they say things like this' or 'why would she lie? ' all despite the fact that at this point it's basically a she said vs he said and he said and 65 women said. i think this is bad and toxic. on one hand estimates of how many sexual assault claims pan out to be false only account for a rather small portion of the whole. i've seen estimates as low as 0. 5 and as high as 10 well in truth i've seen 90 , but i take issue with the research methods in that one case . 2 5 seems to be a fairly commonly accepted range. and to bolster the fact that we do know that women lie about these things from time to time, even in very high profile cases, we have cases like the duke lacrosse team thing, beale, or mattress girl. so yeah. maybe if you had to place a bet on the truth of one of these claims, the smart money might be on the woman telling the truth. if there's a statistical 95 98 chance she's telling the truth, roll those dice, baby. but playing at statistics is quite different than asserting 'belief' in the outcome as if it's a truth. of all the ford supporters i've heard, not a one has framed their support in terms of statistical likelihood. they frame it as 'i believe women because i believe women. ' i think this is a toxic and unhelpful view that, if embraced more fully, has the potential to wreck lives. y'all know what to do. cheers. amp; x200b;

auto_conc: i think soccer players should be punished for embellishing goals.
gt: one of the big issues with soccer is that there is such a high premium on scoring opportunities. it isn't uncommon for a game to only have 1 or 2 goals, and those goals coming on only a handful more scoring opportunities. with the premium on goals 1 goal can easily be deciding, particularly if the leading team adopts an all out defense strategy , the incentive to try and draw penalties either free kicks or penalty shots which can be scoring opportunities without any additional effort by the kicking team is massive. the best way for soccer to deal with this would be to reduce the benefit of flopping. that might mean taking steps to increase scoring so that 1 goal won't necessarily be deciding. that might mean reducing the benefit of free kicks e. g. you can dribble out with possession, but not organize a set piece . that might mean moving back the penalty kick so it isn't nearly as valuable in it's own right.

conclusion: Alcohol prohibition is good.
premises: we also have comparable evidence from the ussr, where health complications caused by alcohol where significantly reduced along with crime, violence, and work absence 1990 11 3 p246 252. pdf;jsessionid 4a22a021eef33eabbb444cfc66bf6aab? sequence 1 .
argument: Alcohol prohibition is good. : we also have comparable evidence from the ussr, where health complications caused by alcohol where significantly reduced along with crime, violence, and work absence 1990 11 3 p246 252. pdf;jsessionid 4a22a021eef33eabbb444cfc66bf6aab? sequence 1 .
auto_conc: Alcohol and tobacco are more harmful drugs yet remain legal
gt: ethanol has industrial and scientific uses too. to stop people from using that ethanol to drink, you must put adulterants in it to make it undrinkable. the government murdered 10,000 people through this method during prohibition. a repeat now would be maybe 30,000. and then of course you have the issue that alcohol is the result of a natural process. enforcement would be an insane impossibility. you only need a cooler to make beer and wine. if you think it was hard to catch the moonshiners of old, just wait until people are 3d printing stills. people will still drink. only now you've pushed it underground. i buy a bottle of whiskey now, i know it is safe to drink. i know the exact percentage of alcohol because regulation requires it. once it's underground all of that is lost. i won't know what's in the whiskey, and i won't know what percentage it is. people will also start to drink more as they did during prohibition, because when you score some booze you're going to drink it all up. alcohol consumption only went down overall because the casual drinkers stopped drinking, and those aren't the people who are going to have the health and social problems related to alcohol.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know about you, but i don't think it's a good idea to say that alcohol is the primary cause of death in the us, or that it's the only cause of the death of people in general. i think you're underestimating the impact alcohol has on society. for example, in the united states, alcohol is a major contributor to the death rate of people who die from lung cancer. in the uk, it's more common for people to die from cancer than from heart disease.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that alcohol prohibition is good or bad for society. i don't see how it's good for society at all.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think there is any evidence to suggest that alcohol and tobacco are more harmful than cigarettes or tobacco, but i do think that there is some evidence that they are more dangerous than cigarettes and alcohol.

conclusion: College coding classes should be more focused on mobile & web app development.
premises: so i just graduated with my computer science degree back in april and after reflecting on what i learned in my coding classes, it seems like we are working with antiquated technology. as an example, i wouldn't consider my algorithms or theory of computation courses as 'coding classes,' because while some code was done, it was largely more theoretical stuff. my java and python classes however were just all about learning those languages. we dipped into php and sql in my databases class but that's about it. the first time i ever did a web app was when i learned . net myself working on my senior project. every other code class besides sysadmin if that counts never really touched on any networking topics. so what we learned through school for the most part was how to make an offline desktop app. you code something in java, you run a . jar file, and you're good to go, no coverage of rest api usage or anything. in reality, this isn't too relevant anymore. people don't use desktop apps in large quantities anymore, bar video games. the average person probably uses: chrome firefox, discord, steam, itunes spotify, and maybe 3 other programs of their choice a couple adobe products, maybe a few ides, etc. . mobile apps have largely replaced the usefulness of desktop apps. if you want a budget tracker for example, you'll likely just do it on your phone so you can punch in numbers whenever you need to. if there's a desktop app that isn't too fitting for mobile, typically it works better as a web app so people don't have to download specific software. of course i listed some desktop apps above that are still relevant and still useful, but they are much lower in popularity compared to mobile or web apps since they are typically less portable on a pc or require downloads and setup. and especially with every app being connected to the internet nowadays it seems downright outdated that we don't even so much as cover simpler web connectivity things like rest apis in these coding classes. i couldn't tell you how to integrate an api into a java application, and i used it for several years throughout highschool and college. cmv.

auto_conc: Most of my coding classes were in Java and didn't cover web development.
gt: i work with lots of people who write code but never studied computer science. none of them ever really 'got' core computer science and software engineering best practices. i never formally learned web or mobile dev. it takes me about a day of effort to get useful in a web framework the one a year i think i'm going to actually finish one of my side project ideas. mobile isn't special. it's not different and it's not hard for someone who knows the fundamentals. note: embedded and low resource environments not included.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know if you've seen the comments, but i think you're missing the point. it's not that coding classes aren't useful, it's that they're not useful. if you want to learn how to make a web app, you need to know how to do it on your phone. you can't do that on a desktop app.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're confusing 'coding classes' with 'computer science classes.'i'm not sure what you mean by that, but i think it's important to remember that coding is not just about programming, it's also about learning how to code. for example, if you're a web developer, you need to learn how to write a web app, and how to do that on a mobile device. if you want to learn about web development, you're going to need a lot of programming skills, not just programming skills. but you also need to know how to run a web application on a desktop.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm going to take a different tack and say that most of your coding classes were in java and didn't cover web development. if you're not familiar with java or python, i don't think you're going to be able to tell me how to use a web app in a java class.

conclusion: Liberals have lost the desire to convince conservatives.
premises: i recently went to a talk on free speech and hate speech. one of the biggest take aways i got was the amount of applause a line from someone when they said something allong the lines of 'who are you the oppressor to define what hate speech is for us the oppressed . ' while i absolutely understand and empathize with where this sentiment was coming from, the end result of this line of thinking is disastrous for liberal democratic societies. it leads to a presumption that all those who differ from your definition of oppressed are either worthy of silencing, or that they are not worth listening to. what has been very surprising to me is the unwillingness to try engage and convince those with opposite viewpoints. i understand why it has gotten so much harder. the realities of people who self select information sources that confirm their worldview are constantly being reinforced into a deeper and deeper dillusion where alternative facts live. i know this has been rambling and unfocused, but i guess i am just looking for some silver lining or hope that liberals are trying to beat bad ideas with better ideas, and not a political correctness or censorship.

auto_conc: Liberals have lost the ability to convince conservatives.
gt: was there a specific oppressed group that made that statement? it wasn't just 'hillary voters' oppressed by 'trump voters. '
masked_conc_attacks: the problem with this is that it's not just about free speech, it's also about the ability to say whatever you want without fear of reprisal. i don't think it's a perfect solution, but it's an important one. if you want to talk about how free speech is a good thing, you have to be able to say what you want, and what you don't want. the problem with free speech isn't that it doesn't exist, but that it isn't a good idea. it's that it is a bad idea, and that it can't be tolerated. i think the problem is that free speech doesn't work that way. i'm not saying it's bad, i'm just saying that it shouldn't be allowed, and i think it should be allowed.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think liberals are losing the desire to convince conservatives. i think liberals have lost their desire to persuade conservatives. it's not that they don't want to convince liberals, it's that they want to change their views.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. conservatives are trying to convince liberals, they're trying to persuade conservatives to not listen to them. that's not to say that they have lost the ability to convince conservatives, it's just that they've become less effective at convincing conservatives.

conclusion: Alcoholics Anonymous is heavily flawed from a scientific perspective and hasn't tried to improve it's system since it's inception
premises: i have a friend who has been attending aa meetings recently because he was ordered to do so in some fashion after getting a dui for the record i don't know if that means he was given a true option or made to attend or 'choose' jailtime and the whole thing has got me thinking about whether or not aa works and if sobriety is even the intended outcome of the program. below i've listed the famous 12 steps and below that are my relatively disorganized thoughts on the program having looked into it for the first time in any in depth manner. this means that i m still in the early stages of my views and can be very much subject to change. 1. we admitted we were powerless over alcohol that our lives had become unmanageable. 2. came to believe that a power greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity. 3. made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of god as we understoodhim. 4. made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves. 5. admitted to god, to ourselves, and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs. 6. were entirely ready to have god remove all these defects of character. 7. humbly asked him to remove our shortcomings. 8. made a list of all persons we had harmed and became willing to make amends to them all. 9. made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others. 10. continued to take a personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it. 11. sought through prayer and mation to improve our conscious contact with god as we understood him, praying only for knowledge of his will for us and the power to carry that out. 12. my current view is that because of the lack of change of the steps over the years since the 30 s suggests a lack of improvement that would be unacceptable in any other field of treatment for diseases. here are some of my thoughts on the matter. first up, as many have pointed out, there's a whole lot of god involved throughout the 12 steps 6 direct references and 7 if you count 2 , i'm not sure how this is supposed to appeal to athiests such as my friend. if a person does not believe in god they will be put off from the program from the start making it much harder to reach their goal of sobriety. if alcoholism is a disease then why does aa treat it simply as a matter of will power? i wouldn't try to treat cancer with prayer alone, and for the record there are various medical treatments for alcoholism. there is also a stigma of personal failure when people relapse which doesn't make sense for a couple of reasons. first, if it's a disease then people are sick which means that blaming them for not being able to control their health adds a layer of shame which can only do harm to the person's primary goal of getting sober. in turn this will increase the time to get sober because it will add time to get over that shame before starting again. shame does nothing to help get a person back on track as far as i can tell. second, you would never assign blame to a person with cancer who has gone into remission and then had the cancer come back, why would we do the same for literally any other illness? we wouldn't accept that from any other sort of treatment. if we didn't collect that information we would still have the same poor treatment of hiv that we did in the 80s and 90s, same goes for cancer, and just about any other illness you can name. finally it seems that aa believes it s program is a one size fits all program when we know that many ailments require different treatments for different people. this is especially true for ailments that affect people mentally which i think it s safe to say that addiction falls under that same umbrella. people deal with various addictions in different ways, why aa treats alcohol as a one size fits all approach i can t say, maybe i m wrong, but based on the text of their twelve steps and twelve promises that doesn t seem to be the case. instead they seem to say that the only reason people fail is because the fail to give themselves over fully to the program which seems to be very very odd.

gt: the core of aa is community and loving, understanding community may be the most important medicine ever devised.

known_conc_attacks: the problem with aa is that it's not really a program. it's a way of trying to get people to stop drinking and become more sober. the problem with the program is that you're trying to convince people that alcohol is bad, and that they shouldn't drink. if you want to get rid of alcohol, you're going to have to convince them that it isn't bad, or that it doesn't help them at all. you're not going to convince someone that alcohol isn't a bad thing, but you're probably going to get them to change their mind about it.

conclusion: Laissez Faire is the ideal Governmental/Societal Structure
premises: as morality cannot be imposed, and the smart, or selfish, or rich will always have advantage any system, however vetted, will produce unintended consequences. the more complex the regulation or system, the harder it is to evaluate the success. welfare, government oversight, banking and industry regulation, healthcare and similar policies inevitably fail to produce better results than the self correcting selfish incentives of competition. for example: the recent fiduciary rule attempted to standardize compensation for advisory services on asset management. this was meant to be a more strict policy compared to a disclosure based, potentially conflicted, model in which suitability was the standard. the problem which was attempted to be addressed was: broker has fund a and b which are both suitable, but picks a for revenue purposes. the solution was, fund a and b must pay the same. simply put . the reality was that the industry broadly increased fees holistically, to maintain revenue levels but collect it another way. average fees went up. in the chaos of the administration change, the standard was ultimately struck down. it seems to me, that ultimately, people learn from experience, and in the learning process even systemically, many problems self correct from individual incentive. a social darwinism of behavior, as evolution has shown us the impact of selective competitive advantage with iteration, why can that not apply also to society? us spending on welfare is comparatively high compared to international spending on a proportional decrease in standardized poverty levels can t vote on my phone directly, but a 2012 study was referenced on wikipedia s welfare page . my view could change with appropriate statistical evidence. it seems most of the research on these concepts are highly partisan, and the results are hard to take at face value. to be honest my current view is how i was educated. i would appreciate a differing, well supported viewpoint.

us spending on welfare is comparatively high compared to international spending on a proportional decrease in standardized poverty levels can t vote on my phone directly, but a 2012 study was referenced on wikipedia s welfare page . my view could change with appropriate statistical evidence. it seems most of the research on these concepts are highly partisan, and the results are hard to take at face value. to be honest my current view is how i was educated. i would appreciate a differing, well supported viewpoint.
auto_conc: I believe that in the end, morality cannot be imposed, and the smart will always have advantage.
gt: so you want to return to a laissez faire form of food safety for example? won't that have adverse outcomes for people with allergies, it every just salmonella eggs?
masked_conc_attacks: i'm going to take a different approach to this. i think you're underestimating the power of the government. the government is not the only entity that has the power to regulate and regulate the behavior of people. it is the most powerful entity in the world, and it is one of the largest and most powerful entities in the entire world. it has the ability to regulate all aspects of the economy, including all of the people who make up the vast majority of the world's population, and the amount of money that is spent on things like education, healthcare, etc.. the government has the authority to regulate, regulate, and regulate all of those things. this is the way the government works. it's the government's role to regulate those things, and to ensure that those things are regulated and regulated. if the government can't regulate these things, then there is no reason to regulate them.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's possible for a laissez faire system to be the ideal governmental society structure. i think it would be better to have a system where everyone is able to make their own decisions, and that would allow for a fairer society.
auto_conc_attacks: the problem with this view is that you assume that morality cannot be imposed and the smart will always have advantage. that's not true. morality can be imposed, but that does not mean that it cannot be applied.

conclusion: There is nothing wrong with the encouraging/ reinforcment of masculinity.
premises: i often see people criticizing phrases such as 'man up! ,' 'be a man! ,' etc, and claiming these are bad for young people men and women to hear. historically and biologically, men have been and are more combative than women so if a woman needs to be combative to accomplish something, i see no problem is saying 'be a man. ' this also applies to other traits such as independence. as an aside, some may argue that ideas of masculinity and femininity are purely socially construed and that people only act certain ways because of societal influence. i wholeheartedly disagree masculine and feminine traits largely have to do with the presence of sex hormones acting on the nervous system. so the idea that phrases like 'be a man' need to go away because it's keeping together a negative social construct are unfounded. if anything is unclear, i will be happy to elaborate on any ideas in the comments.
argument: There is nothing wrong with the encouraging/ reinforcment of masculinity. : i often see people criticizing phrases such as 'man up! ,' 'be a man! ,' etc, and claiming these are bad for young people men and women to hear. historically and biologically, men have been and are more combative than women so if a woman needs to be combative to accomplish something, i see no problem is saying 'be a man. ' this also applies to other traits such as independence. as an aside, some may argue that ideas of masculinity and femininity are purely socially construed and that people only act certain ways because of societal influence. i wholeheartedly disagree masculine and feminine traits largely have to do with the presence of sex hormones acting on the nervous system. so the idea that phrases like 'be a man' need to go away because it's keeping together a negative social construct are unfounded. if anything is unclear, i will be happy to elaborate on any ideas in the comments.
auto_conc: I believe there is nothing wrong with being a man.
gt: would you agree that generally human beings can do things that are irrational and potentially harmful? masculinity and i would argue femininity as well are both sets of human behaviours that can be good or bad. and in some circumstances are definitely bad, you don't want people acting independently in a surgical operation, you want people working together in a very strict fashion. this is a conclusion that came about from comparing surgeries where people worked independently with ones where people used set checklists and protocols to coordinate, and finding that the latter had lower levels of mistakes made. i guess my main point is that masculinity is a good tool for when you need to be competitive or combative, but those situations are occasional for most people, and outside of them masculinity needs to be controlled. it's something that needs to work for you, not the other way around.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's necessarily a bad thing to say 'be a man', but it's definitely not a good thing to do for young people. i think that saying'man up!'is a good way to say that young people are more combative than women because it's keeping together a negative social construct.
known_conc_attacks: there is nothing wrong with the encouraging or reinforcment of masculinity. there is just something wrong with it.
auto_conc_attacks: i agree with you that there is nothing wrong with being a man, but i don't think there is anything wrong with saying 'be a man' or 'be masculine'. i think the problem is that it is often used as a way to make people feel like they are a certain way. for example, if i were to say'man up!'i would say that i would be a little more combative than a woman. i would also be a bit more assertive than a man.

gt: the cornell law 'article' linked is actually the full text of the supreme court's opinion. it's a fascinating read, rich in historical context and i thank you for sharing it as it shines a light on the question that news stories fail to adequately capture. here's the money paragraph from the opinion:the real object of the fourteenth amendment of the constitution, in qualifying the words, 'all persons born in the united states' by the addition 'and subject to the jurisdiction thereof,' would appear to have been to exclude, by the fewest and fittest words besides children of members of the indian tribes, standing in a peculiar relation to the national government, unknown to the common law , the two classes of cases children born of alien enemies in hostile occupation and children of diplomatic representatives of a foreign state both of which, as has already been shown, by the law of england and by our own law from the time of the first settlement of the english colonies in america, had been recognized exceptions to the fundamental rule of citizenship by birth within the country. so there it is, the supreme court, explaining after painstaking review of the law and history of the matter their conclusion that the phrase 'subject to the jurisdiction thereof' refers to three exceptions:1. members of certain indians tribes2. children of alien enemies in hostile occupation; and3. children of diplomatic representatives of a foreign state. that's it. the holding of the case is really that straightforward. if you are born in the u. s. and fall outside of these three exceptions, you are a citizen.

conclusion: Rap is lower quality music and is overrated.
premises: before i get into this, let me be clear what i'm not trying to say : all rap is bad. rap takes no talent. people shouldn't listen to rap at all. people who listen to rap are less intellegent. all the problems i list are exclusive to rap and not other genres of music. ok, now let's get into this : 1. rap uses less people to create, which does not always indicate, but usually indicates less effort overall . obviously, the more people working on something, the more hours that can be put into something. that doesn't mean one person can't create something good, but the likelihood of an individual creating something good is statically less than that of a group. 2. most rap songs use rhymes, which can alter what the creator wants the song to mean . the creator of a song might want to portray a message, express an emotion s , or cause the listener to critically think in some way. since many rap songs rely heavily on rhyming their lyrics, they have to alter the words of the songs in order to rhyme. while this can be entertaining, the meaning of the song is often lost, misunderstood or not taken seriously. 3. rap relies too heavily on vocals and not a variety of instruments . that's not to say that rap never uses anything else, but vocals are always at the forefront; everything but the vocals is just background noise, vocals are emphasized. this means that rap as a genre lacks variety within artists and between artists. it becomes more difficult to distinguish between rap songs, and they start to blend together. this begins to ruin the perception of what's good and what's bad. on top of that, if the vocals are bad, the whole song is bad vs. if one instrument were bad, the entire song is not necessarily ruined. 4. rap is easier to learn than other genres that use other instruments, and most anyone can do it if try tried. there's no hand eye coordination with vocals as with a guitar or piano. on top of that, traditional vocals require the singer to use certain pitches consistently and at loud capacities and to a beat. this makes it easier to learn than other interments or vocals. meaning, people without natural talent can start rapping, and lesser quality songs can be made in abundance. of course, a rapper can spend an equal or greater amount of time practicing as any other musician. but remember, people can also get really good at sitting down and standing up, that doesn't equate to quality. i try to be objective, but i obviously wouldn't be making this argument if i didn't have a bias. i do enjoy some rap, i'm not completely adverse to it. other genres have similar problems, i would say the same of a lot of pop or country music. let me know what you guys think, am i way off base? thanks for reading, i look forward to your responses.

premises: let's just disregard the fact that 'average voter' generally means the white voter, in this case. it starts with these communities that collectively complain about their problems. my issue with this is that this seems to be a very ahistorical view. blacks were enslaved based on their identity. women weren't allowed to own their land based on their identity. it's incredibly troublesome to me that people ignore this. because it certainly wasn't for no reason. and it isn't like the fight is over on any of these fronts. blacks are still facing issues with police brutality. women are dealing with sexual harassment in the workplace and not finding adequate help when they want to come forward. ice are literally asking mexican people for their papers. why should they not band together and advocate for each other? i don't see why that's bad. so now let's focus on the right. do you think that's just a coincidence? of course not. democrats have a more diverse voter base because they picked up the slack that republicans weren't willing to pick up. that isn't the fault of democrats. it's the fault of republicans those demonized those identities to begin with. it's their creation. first off, the implication here is that, somehow, the lgbtq community, black people, hispanic people. muslims, etc. can't be working class. that's incredibly problematic. secondly, they say this because they feel that advocating for these groups is off putting to white voters. i'm open to all discussion. if i need to be more clear in a certain area, please let me know. this is my first time doing this, but i'm curious to see your opinions on this.

gt: few probelms to consider. by stating that all republicans or conservatives play identity politics is an identity politics statement. obviously not all do it. secondly your assumption that dave rubin and jordan peterson are conservatives isn't really true, that is also an identity politics view that assumes anyone who opposes some parts of the far left must inherently be alt right. considering a sizable number of bernie sanders and 2 term obama voters voted for trump, simplifying the argument to them being alt right is pretty ignorant. ben shapiro is conservative but neither of the 3 play identity politics except perhaps attacks on the far left who are by definition a group with and ideology they disagree with so not really identity politics all 3 agree there are many agreeable moderate liberals who have differing views but are reasonable. lastly just because both sides are potentially hypocritical doesn't mean they aren't both aiming at the right goal. the vast majority of people on both sides of the political spectrum agree that we should have equal opportunity and rights for all individuals, historically opressed minorities don't want to be judged by the group identity rather judged in the content of their character to paraphrase dr martin luther king jr , and men, whites, conservatives, straight people don't want to be blindly lumped into a group of people who are just viewed as opressed who need to pay for actions they didn't take. but the problem is we are viewing the loud voices of the extremes as representative of the whole. all conservatives are nationalist bigots of the underrepresented and all left wingers are misinformed bigots of the status quo, but these where the views of the fringes but by playing identity politics we have had to pick a side and defend it and our political views have move further and further to the edges over the last 15 years and our mediating reasonable center has shrunk to the point where no one will believe you're a centrist. if you argue a right winger you'll a communist if you argue a left winger your a fascist. so yes everyone is playing this game and they have fucked it up for everyone but extremes will take over.

conclusion: Sometimes attacking someone's "character rather than their ideas" is unavoidable
premises: i read this nyt article about facebook's conservative workers feeling like they can't express their opinions. we do this so consistently that employees are afraid to say anything when they disagree with what s around them politically. ' even though i'm very liberal, i'm not unsympathetic. to take an extreme example, if someone is a holocaust denier and wanted me to discuss this with them, i personally feel like there's nothing to talk about. if they pressed me on it, i would have to say they're either woefully delusional or anti semitic, or both. the facebook employee's complaint also strikes me as tone policing, asking folks who have had to endure countless arguments with bigots to use language like 'that's a bigoted idea' instead of 'you're a bigot. ' i do believe there's a difference between a good faith and bad faith argument debate. but even if you're arguing a racist or sexist idea in good faith, i think it's unreasonable to ask the people you're talking to not to think that you're racist or sexist. it reminds me of people who bemoan how heated political debate get for a lot of people, politics aren't 'just politics,' they have real world consequences. and the topics we're talking about these days are really personal. many of us have trans friends whose lives are in serious jeopardy because of policies. many of us have immigrant parents. fifty percent of us are women who are affected by anti choice laws. i frequently lurk on r asktrumpsupporters to try to get a sense of what people who support trump think about these topics. i've seen some posts that i disagree with but i can sense empathy and the fact that they genuinely believe their way is the best solution for everyone involved. but i've also seen many more posts that are rooted in racist ideas, particularly around immigration. i can't help but feel like these ideas stem from these posters being racists themselves rather than having some inexplicably complex worldview.

conclusion: If abortions were not an option, then everyone would agree that fetuses are human lives.
premises: they have human dna distinct from their parents. they have organs which, while they are still developing, are self contained and distinct from their mothers organs. they respond to external stimuli independently of their mothers. the most prevalent arguments for the idea that fetuses are merely a part of the mother s body seem to be these, so i ll address them here: 1. the fetus is entirely dependent on the mother. it certainly is. however, newborn babies are also entirely dependent on the mother. not just financially, but in a very literal sense. they, like fetuses, get food directly from the mother s body. is it ok to kill babies because they re inconvenient to the mother? 2. why? because human beings don t stop developing until their early 20 s. we don t spring out of the womb as fully grown adults. i don t even have to argue that this argument is illogical on principle. i only have to point out that the line demanded by this logic is far later than birth. so is it ok to kill teenagers? 3. the mother has a right to control her own body. she surely does. yes, women have the right to control their own bodies. they can chop off their own legs if they really want to. what they do not have the right to do is kill children. it merely assumes the answer to the question and moves on. so what arguments am i missing? change my mind.
argument: If abortions were not an option, then everyone would agree that fetuses are human lives. : they have human dna distinct from their parents. they have organs which, while they are still developing, are self contained and distinct from their mothers organs. they respond to external stimuli independently of their mothers. the most prevalent arguments for the idea that fetuses are merely a part of the mother s body seem to be these, so i ll address them here: 1. the fetus is entirely dependent on the mother. it certainly is. however, newborn babies are also entirely dependent on the mother. not just financially, but in a very literal sense. they, like fetuses, get food directly from the mother s body. is it ok to kill babies because they re inconvenient to the mother? 2. why? because human beings don t stop developing until their early 20 s. we don t spring out of the womb as fully grown adults. i don t even have to argue that this argument is illogical on principle. i only have to point out that the line demanded by this logic is far later than birth. so is it ok to kill teenagers? 3. the mother has a right to control her own body. she surely does. yes, women have the right to control their own bodies. they can chop off their own legs if they really want to. what they do not have the right to do is kill children. it merely assumes the answer to the question and moves on. so what arguments am i missing? change my mind.

gt: you are making the assumption that 'human life' is a binary concept. biologically, this is false. human life comes into existence gradually and it also ceases to exist gradually. if somebody's brain is destroyed but their body is kept alive in an icu, that person is still dead for all practical purposes. switching off the icu machines does not constitute murder. but what if only 90 of the brain is destroyed, and the person is capable of some basic reflexes but otherwise a vegetable? are they dead or alive? the answer is that they are more alive, because human life is a continuum. but still barely alive. the legal system treats life as binary, not because this reflects reality, but because practically , it would be impossible to run a legal system where life was expressed in terms of percentages. it would also have some nasty side effects. living in a society where you constantly have to prove the degree of your aliveness in order to gain protections would be a terrifying experience for most people. in short, binary life is a legal fiction, but a useful legal fiction. but once we have acknowledged this we also have to acknowledge that we have to draw a line in the sand somewhere, and that where exactly we draw that line is arbitrary. however, we can use biology to give us a meaningful ballpark . drawing the line at conception is silly from a biological perspective, because we know that a person's 'essence' resides in the brain, and the brain doesn't develop until later.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure why you think it's ok to kill a baby when it's already a human being. it's not the same as killing a fetus because it's a human, it's the fact that it is a human.
known_conc_attacks: i would argue that fetuses are not a separate human life from their parents. they are not independent of their mothers body, but they are independent of the mother's body. therefore, the fetus is not a human life.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. the mother has a right to control her own body. she doesn't have the right to kill a baby. i don't think you can argue that the fetus is a part of the mother's body.

conclusion: Tipping should be optional and restaurants should just be subject to the same minimum wage laws as every other industry
premises: seriously, wait staff get paid literally pennies, after taxes and everything. i've had friends who only make 2. 13 an hour. now, i get that you can make a decent amount of money with tips, but it honestly is just so random and unpredictable. think about it. some days the customers you get may be generous and give you a healthy tip, but another day, you could get nothing but cheapskates, regardless of how well you do your job, some people still tip crap. i don't think someone's income should be based on factors they literally have no control over. plus, it puts a lot of pressure and stress on wait staff to be as friendly and helpful as possible. and everyone knows, when you're stressed out, you make mistakes. plus, tipping itself, there's so much debate on what the correct amount is. i've hear 15 percent, 18 percent, and, unless you are relatively skilled with math to figure it out or have a calculator you'll never figure it out. it doesn't need to be a project. i mean, i just don't get why it's the customer's responsibility to make sure the staff can have an income. i mean, every business follows that motto. when you pay for something else, like books, you're just buying a book. there's no obligation to pay the employees a small amount too for what the company should be paying them to do. i mean, japan does this well. in fact, in japan it's considered disrespectful and rude to tip. i think it's actually considered bribery. i just don't see who tipping benefits? can anyone change my view though? i personally just can't see who the system benefits.

conclusion: Sex before marriage is to be avoided. Marriage is good (especially if you want to raise children). Legal marriage is pragmatic.
premises: i was raised a christian and still follow much of the guiding wisdom of western evangelicalism. i m also aware of recent studies which indicate that the number of sexual partners across a lifetime and cohabitation before marriage both correlate to higher rates of divorce. i realize marriage isn t for everyone but it does have long term affects on health and happiness measures. with growing recognition of long term cohabitation, i m not sure legal marriage has many benefits but my intuition is that it reduces paperwork travel visas, medical next of kin, taxes . i m unmarried but consider it a possibility within the next few years. better to think it through now than cmv after the fact!

Legal marriage is pragmatic. : i was raised a christian and still follow much of the guiding wisdom of western evangelicalism. i m also aware of recent studies which indicate that the number of sexual partners across a lifetime and cohabitation before marriage both correlate to higher rates of divorce. i realize marriage isn t for everyone but it does have long term affects on health and happiness measures. with growing recognition of long term cohabitation, i m not sure legal marriage has many benefits but my intuition is that it reduces paperwork travel visas, medical next of kin, taxes . i m unmarried but consider it a possibility within the next few years. better to think it through now than cmv after the fact!
auto_conc: i think i should get married before i have kids
gt: what do you mean when say 'marriage'? is it the formal commitment you make in front of others or does it refer to the long term, monogamous relationship you create with a partner? if it's the former, then this discussion seems somewhat arbitrary because you're glorifying a single moment. if it's the latter, then you have to think of the relationship in its entirety. that long term relationship doesn't begin at the ceremony unless it's an arranged marriage where the individuals haven't met yet . it begins when you started dating. when you start to think about the relationship in its entirety, it seems silly to assign an arbitrary date to engage in sex or cohabitation. to me, it seems like you're adding a lot of undue stress to plan a big celebration the wedding ceremony where you're announcing to you're closest friends family that you are going to take both of these steps at the same time. imagine the vows, 'hey everyone, just wanted to let you know that up until now we were both virgins who have never lived with a romantic partner, but starting tonight we're going to have sex and live together! ' instead, both partners should engage in these activities when they both feel that they are ready for them. they should get married when they're both confident that this is the partner they want to spend the rest of their lives with. to me, a wedding is simply an opportunity to celebrate that love commitment you've created with friends and family. ultimately, marriage is a long term relationship that needs to be worked on and managed forever. it's not like you get married and start with a new relationship or you get married and all the relationship work vanishes. instead, you get married and a week later things should go back to being how they were before the stress of the wedding.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about, but i'm going to try to change your view here. first off, you seem to be conflating the benefits of marriage with the costs of cohabitation. if you don't want to get married, you're going to have a lot of trouble getting a divorce. secondly, i think you're missing the point of marriage. marriage is a social contract. it's not a contract, it's a contract.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to remember that marriage is a contract between two people. it's not just about sex, it's about marriage. if you want to raise children, you're going to have to go through a lot of paperwork, and that's going to be a lot harder to do.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think you should get married before you have kids, but if you're planning on having kids, you should do it before you get married.

conclusion: It should be made illegal for parents to buy their children video games with "mature" age ratings
premises: video games are rated by the country's age ratings board whether it's esrb in the us, pegi in europe or another regional system , based on the content they contain, such as violence, sexual content, bad language or drug use. many violent video games are almost photo realistic and contain graphic depictions of blood and gore, as well as often having the option to brutally kill innocent civilians gta v is an example of this . at young ages children cannot clearly distinguish fantasy from reality in the same way as an adult. i'm sure the thought of a 6 year old sitting in front of a screen shooting people through the head in a video game should make most people very uncomfortable. this would be difficult to enforce, but in my country it's also illegal for an adult to purchase alcohol for somebody under the age of 18, and whilst this doesn't eliminate the problem of underage drinking, it adds a certain weight to the action and reinforces the idea that it's punishable if discovered by the authorities.
argument: It should be made illegal for parents to buy their children video games with "mature" age ratings : video games are rated by the country's age ratings board whether it's esrb in the us, pegi in europe or another regional system , based on the content they contain, such as violence, sexual content, bad language or drug use. many violent video games are almost photo realistic and contain graphic depictions of blood and gore, as well as often having the option to brutally kill innocent civilians gta v is an example of this . at young ages children cannot clearly distinguish fantasy from reality in the same way as an adult. i'm sure the thought of a 6 year old sitting in front of a screen shooting people through the head in a video game should make most people very uncomfortable. this would be difficult to enforce, but in my country it's also illegal for an adult to purchase alcohol for somebody under the age of 18, and whilst this doesn't eliminate the problem of underage drinking, it adds a certain weight to the action and reinforces the idea that it's punishable if discovered by the authorities.
auto_conc: I believe violent video games should be illegal for people under 18.
gt: do you know why it is illegal for shopkeepers to give the games to children? it has nothing to do with any effect on the children, it was about the children doing things behind their parents back and the parents getting really angry about not being involved in that decision. if it's the parents buying the games then they are involved. if there was an epidemic of people converting 10 year olds away from their parents religion for example, you would quickly see a similar reaction against those people.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're trying to say here, but i'm going to try to change your view in a different way. if you're going to ban video games, you need to do so in a way that makes them more acceptable to adults. you can't force people to buy alcohol. you have to make them pay for it. you don't have to force them to pay for alcohol.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it would be illegal to sell video games to children under the age of 18. i think it should be illegal for parents to buy their children video games that they are not old enough to play. i don't know if it's illegal to buy video games with'mature' age ratings, but i do think it is illegal for a parent to sell their child a video game that contains graphic depictions of blood and gore, as well as often having the option to brutally kill innocent civilians gta v is an example of this.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that violent video games should be illegal for people under 18. i think they should be legal for anyone under 18, but i don't see any reason why it shouldn't be illegal.

conclusion: All stable currency throughout history has been backed up by force, at a minimum. Therefore, fiat currency is the best and most efficient kind of currency that could possibly exist.
premises: throughout history, we have gone into debt with each other. not all debts, however, are created equal. as we began to store large quantities of commodities that we found useful, we would record debts of the quantities that we owed using valuable metals that would not tarnish and were hard to reproduce, and found valuable. gold and silver, in this process, began to become a more and more widely accepted medium of exchange. eventually, because gold was such a heavy thing, and after the invention of the printing press, printing began to become such a cheap thing that now the creation of banks and the creation and circulation of banknotes became very popular. banknotes were, ultimately, backed up by force, because they were an agreement by the bank to give the holder of the banknote their gold back upon the return of the banknote. fast forward hundreds of years. and we are at the end of the bretton woods system. then, the u. s. took its dollar off the gold standard. and this is entirely because of taxes and the force behind them. currency acts as a medium of debt that someone owes to you. in the past, it was a debt of gold. and gold was only valuable to most people because the government and the rich interests who had a stake in it, would denominate tax debts in gold. this same logic applies to fiat currency today. any resource standard demands that you store quantities of that resource indefinitely, where it can not be utilized in the production of goods and services valuable to peoples desires. no matter what, if you are storing a fungible resource that has no uses for basic utility for most people, and only produces utility in advanced production, either as a conductor in electronics, or as jewelry, most people do not have use for gold.
argument: All stable currency throughout history has been backed up by force, at a minimum.
