conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

auto_conc: people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational.
gt: here's the deal. you are right that an individual vote doesn't pick the president. but the election does pick the president. i'm gunna use people who ran in 2016, because i've been drinking, and it'll make it easier for me to keep straight, but assume this point is broadly applicable to elections generally. now, in 2016, you had clinton, trump, johnson and stein. and everyone who isn't retarded knew it was either going to be clinton or trump as president. now, you're correct, if you voted stein or johnson, you didn't change who the president is today. but the way an election works, people who voted third party, as in all of them, arguably did change the results. its been talked about endlessly that more people voted for stein then clinton lost whisconson by. as in, if they'd voted for clinton instead of stein, clinton would have, at least, won that state. so here's the major point. you have to act like your vote is the deciding vote, while keeping in mind only one of two people have a shot of becoming president. let's say every voter had a prefered candidate who polled at one percent a day before the election. each voter thought of this person as the best president we'd ever have. but because that voter knows that person is only polling at one percent, that voter knows for a fact that this person won't become the president. further, this voter understands that the differences between the two people who have a shot are vast. if you put a gun to the average stein voters head the day before the election, and said, unless the next word out of your mouth is either clinton or trump, i'm blowing your brains out all over your fucking tofu, now who do you want to be president, most stein voters would have admitted the answer was clinton, and then they went ahead and voted for stein. so what they were doing was deciding they were above it all. they'd vote for stein, and count on the rest of the suckers to vote for hillary, and then hillary would be president and they could complain about her for four or eight years.

auto_conc: Voting by mail removes the concept of a secret ballot.
gt: one negative effect of voluntary voting is that candidates campaign with the goal of motivating their base over wooing moderates. we see this in the usa, where voter turnout is a huge determinant of election results for instance, democrats tend to do worse during midterms and local elections because young people vote less than old people. if everyone has to show up and cast some sort of ballot even a blank one , then riling up the base becomes less important and presumably candidates will adopt stances to attract the largest number of voters. in my view this is more in line with the democratic ideal of popular representation.

conclusion: America should be split into 5 separate countries
premises: america has grown too big and too politically diverse to function as a single country anymore. i don't know exactly where we'd draw the borders, but generally we would split the northeast, the south including texas , the midwest, the mountain states, and the pacific coast, each with their own new government. i'd even entertain an argument to make california it's own country. would it be a difficult transition in the short term? absolutely. would it be better in the long term? i believe so. let the south have all the 'fine' neo nazi's they want and elect emperor trump as their leader. let the mid west enact sharia christian law and let the bible lead their government. let the pacific states go full sjw. what are the downsides of doing something like this?
argument: America should be split into 5 separate countries : america has grown too big and too politically diverse to function as a single country anymore. i don't know exactly where we'd draw the borders, but generally we would split the northeast, the south including texas , the midwest, the mountain states, and the pacific coast, each with their own new government. i'd even entertain an argument to make california it's own country. would it be a difficult transition in the short term? absolutely. would it be better in the long term? i believe so. let the south have all the 'fine' neo nazi's they want and elect emperor trump as their leader. let the mid west enact sharia christian law and let the bible lead their government. let the pacific states go full sjw. what are the downsides of doing something like this?
auto_conc: I believe that the US should be split into 4 separate countries,
gt: i posted the following on a very similar to this about a year ago. they proposed 4 countries as opposed to your 5, but otherwise everything i'm about to say is materially the same: there are many many complexities to this, but i want to go into the weeds with just one: debt. the us government owes a lot of money to a lot of people. those debts are guaranteed by the constitution 14th amendment and are owed in us dollars. if the us splits up, somebody needs to handle all of the debt somehow. there would need to be a 'successor state' to the united states who would inherit the obligations of the erstwhile usa. for an historical example, russia was the successor state of the ussr, and inherited the soviet debt, which it finished paying off in 2006. if the us split into 4 equal ish size countries, the successor state would be left with a debt:gdp ratio of about 3. 5:1, which is way higher than any other developed country has right now and would be totally unsustainable. as such, the non successor states would need to either undertake debt payments to the successor state for decades into the future, or else would need to make enormous lump sum payments at the time of the disunion. the former transfer payment system would be a major detriment to the sovereignty of the new nations. in particular, it would mean decades of payments in a currency they no longer control to a foreign state. ask greece how fun that is. the latter would be an enormous and likely impossible burden, as they would need to all market trillions of dollars of bonds in new currencies at the same time which would be damn near impossible. i'd also add that by dividing up the fiscal power of the united states, you can end up with parts which are less than the whole. the us treasury is the single largest unified economic entity on earth right now. merely due to its massive size, it is inherently a very safe place to park your money as it has the command of more resources than anywhere else. four or 5 smaller states would not have the enormous size advantage that comes from being the usa. their currencies would fluctuate a lot more. a california anchored nation would for instance feel a much bigger burden from a second tech crash than would the current usa. that risk would mean people would demand higher yields from investments, and therefore higher interest rates on debt. markets also might not trust the smaller nation governments as much to be fiscally sound in a crisis, and you could see big debt crises like canada saw in the 1990s. this is obviously only a small slice of the complexities of actually doing something like this, but i think it's a good example of just how hard it is to actually do something like this.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you have a problem with the idea of splitting the south into smaller states. it would be very difficult to get rid of the southern states and the midwest. i think this would be a great idea for the rest of the country, but i don't think it's feasible for the north to be a part of the united states. the south would have to deal with a lot of the same problems that the north would have with the south.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think it would be a good idea to split up the united states into 5 different countries. i'm not sure how much of a difference it would make.
auto_conc_attacks: why do you think the east should be split off into four separate countries? what about the rest of the country? why do you want the west to be a part of the united states? why would you want california to be part of a state?

conclusion: Crimes involving breach of trust should have more severe legal repercussions than the similar ones without.
premises: to elucidate my view, i'll try to frame an illustration. consider two acts of theft being performed which constitute as a crime under legal purview. case a: a man is walking down a lonely street late at night. suddenly, a mugger appears out of nowhere and robs him at gunpoint. case b: a man is walking down a busy street. a stranger walks to him seeking for help, describing a life and death situation. on humanitarian grounds, the man follows the stranger who leads him to not so happening street only to realize that it's all a setup. he is then robbed after being held at gun point. now, it is reasonable to state that the ultimate outcome in both of the cases was the man ended up being robbed. however when considered on a profound level, the varying experiences have resulted in different psychological impacts on that person. in case a, it is streetwise to avoid a deserted road to prevent from being taken advantage of. hence, the man would have estimated the probability of getting mugged and made a conscious decision. this would then conform to his existing prejudice about travelling isolated roads at night, which he would definitely avoid in the near future. however an experience from case b would have definitely scarred him by affecting his school of thought towards humanity. it would drive him to a conclusion that it is better off to avoid helping a human or anybody for that matter to avoid the risk of a false case. the next time he sees someone asking for help, even though his conscience would provoke him to provide assistance, his previous experience would say otherwise, thus deterring him from bestowing a respectable act of humanity. on an individual level it would not make a big difference, but consider the impact it would have if hundreds of individuals were robbed in a similar manner. it would then go on to be a preconceived notion that helping somebody en route to an isolated location would have disastrous implications. now imagine the plight of a person asking for help if his case was genuine. statistics suggest that majority of rape victims knew their perpetrators at least at a hierarchical level of an acquaintance. if this keeps on increasing individuals would be wary of accomplices, thus developing trust issues. events like this would make humans lean on individualism and would make them think twice before trusting other humans. and this, as far as the functioning of society is considered, would be the worst thing to happen to it. the basic intention of law is to ensure that humans act in a civilized manner in a society. however what use would the law be if society ceased to exist.

conclusion: Paid DLC has ruined the video game industry.
premises: gone are the days where you could buy a game and know that game developers and publishers have put their heart and soul into a finished product. i know i'm being a bit naive if i said that companies like ea, nintendo and bethesda once had a passion to bring joy to their customers, those businesses in the end are still just like any other business: they're ultimate goal is to make money and nothing more. but around the late 2000s when companies started to realize that they can make lots of money just by adding extra skins and patches everything went down the toilet. money is now the driving force of how and why we consume video games. it's the reason why we have seen countless versions of call of duty or assassin's creed. this is also why the indie scene has also exploded as well, the only ones who have a passion for making fun games have realized they they can not develop their goals under the yoke of titans like microsoft or sony. time and time again we see companies take our money and leave after only a few months, we continue to be let down by game developers who make false claims. e3 drives us crazy and literally leaves some of us drooling wanting more, and yet again we are always disappointed by with product that we paid 60 100 dollars for. remember no mans sky, watch dogs 1, star wars battlefront 1? they are by no means old games if we go by their release date, but now that the industry pumps out new games every month with the incentive of only taking our money these games now seem to be dinosaurs.

auto_conc: I believe that the video game industry has gone downhill in the last 10 years
gt: why do you think the video game industry is ruined? sure some games come with paid dlc or just outright suck, but dlc is just a new tool companies use. there's always been issues with the video game industry, and there have always been companies that care about their product and people they serve. look at cd projekt red and the great stuff they produce. do they have paid dlc? yes. are their games incredible and the dlc is justified, absolutely. we get more games than ever. with modern tools it's now possible for one person or a small group to make a brilliant game. the indie scene has exploded and it's wonderful. we have games like fortnite and pokemon go taking over the public having responsible micro transaction models. do you really think the people making kingdom hearts 3 don't pour everything they have into that game making sure it's perfect? we are in the best age of video games so far. there's more variety, pricing differences, and graphics than ever before. the percent of people who play video games is on the rise. the industry will no doubt continue to grow and have crummy payment models, but the good games will always be there. this is an exciting time. vr is coming around, you can buy a full fledged system for 300 , and the internet lets us separate the bad games from the good before we buy. the industry isn't ruined it's stronger than ever. there are just some companies with crummy practices as there has always been.

she isn t talking to you anymore because you didn t say hi to her last week dan: i figured. janet is always womanciding obviously both men and women are capable of being emotional, so why call it woman ciding? i m sure you can see my point here. 2. both men and women are capable of being condescending, but a man doing it to a woman needs a specific term for it? i think if you break it down the sexism lies in the assumption that a man who is condescending is just an asshole if it s towards a man and sexist if it is towards a woman. 3. why not just use he is condescending or she is condescending because both sexes are capable of being condescending. i feel like if you make a special word for one of them you are being obvious sexist. my whole point is if we say he yelled at her we should also be saying she yelled at her. just like we should be saying she was condescending and he was condescending instead of she was condescending to her vs he was mansplaining to her 4. you don t know if the man you are speaking to is being condescending simply because he is an asshole. this is in effect creating a double standard where the belief is women can freely explain things to men but men cannot freely explain to women under risk of appearing to be a sexist. i don t care for the societal institutional argument where the claim is that sexism hurt women in the workplace and society because men had more power in those roles. i did not do that. i took no part in that and don t know anyone that has. i m sorry if someone you know was hurt by that happening but i had nothing to do with it and if you can associate me with that kind of sexism because of my gender, then you are the sexist one. i am very open to other perspectives and would love to hear what you have to say :

conclusion: People who denounce the poor for owning "Luxuries", Just want the poor to know their place.

conclusion: Certain private companies like the social media/tech giants should be bound by similar free speech laws as the government.
premises: let me start off by saying i do not think we should tolerate intolerance, but at the same time i am against censorship. these laws exist for very valid reasons, and in some places have a few, also valid, exceptions, such as calling for violence against a person or group. this means that a restaurant for example, can expel guests who are obnoxiously sharing extreme political opinions. now here is where my issue arises. take facebook for example. a social media site with billions of users. whether you agree with it or not, many people get their news from facebook. be it through news outlets posting articles on their pages, or groups sharing them, a very large number of people get their information about a plethora of topics from facebook. due to this fact, facebook has almost unprecedented power over what people can see. what can start off as extreme opinions that call for violence, ie something very clear cut and easy to determine, can slowly erode into something more grey and harder to define like 'no bigotry'. now i know this may seem like a slippery slope argument, but i am not saying it will necessarily turn into this, but simply highlighting that it is possible, and i don't think it should be. if facebook decided to update their policy to exclude things in a more vague way this could have far reaching impacts on the social sphere. there simply aren't any other platforms besides maybe twitter that can compete with facebook in terms of reaching a large audience. if you have an opinion or something you want to share, if you are barred from the widest used social media network, you are cut off from the largest way to share that idea. another perhaps more effective example would be if google skewed search results to favour a certain narrative. if searching something neutral like 'trump' in google brought up almost exclusively negative or positive articles, that would seriously impact how information was shared. google is perhaps the biggest example because they are not only a search engine, but the premier search engine for most people globally. i am aware that this would infringe upon the company's right to do what they want with their own property, but in the circumstances i think it is a reasonable concession.

gt: i absolutely disagree. no one is entitled to the servers, technical assistance, and high overhead required to deliver these 'platforms'. if someone violates a company's terms of service, then they have a right to kill their channel. these companies often host an individual's business model, such as a youtube channel, but so do television networks, which have always maintained their power to terminate any show at a whim. if i start a social media network with the intent of bringing people together and it begins to be used to undermine every one of my intentions, i shouldn't be forced to allow it to continue just because i'm 'big'.
masked_conc_attacks: if you want to be racist, you have to be a racist. if you don't like it, you can be racist. you can hate people for it, but you can't hate anyone for it. if someone is racist, they can be intolerant. if they are intolerant, they should be able to hate people. if a person is intolerant of a certain ideology, they shouldn't be allowed to hate that ideology.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a slippery slope argument, but i think it's a good one. the government has a right to dictate what you say, and if you don't like it, you shouldn't be allowed to say what you want. if you disagree with the government, then you should be able to say whatever you want, but that doesn't mean that you can't say what other people want.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it is possible for a company to censor what people can see. i think that a company can censor what they can see, but that doesn't mean it is impossible.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

auto_conc: people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational.
gt: this line of thinking is probably why we rarely see centrists win elections. you have to get through the gauntlet of the primaries first, which means being more insert party than the rest of the candidates. the problem is, now the vote is mostly split along party lines in the general election. say your side has two candidates in the primaries. let's say they're gop, it doesn't matter. candidate a falls about 90 on gop issues, while b is maybe 66 . you agree more with a, but b has a much better chance at getting center votes. however, you know the dems are pushing a 5 gop issue candidate, a hard left counterpart to your candidate a. you'd much rather have b than a dem, but you'd also rather have a than b. do you go for a hail mary vote, or a more certain win but compromise a little?
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. if you didn't vote for the lesser of two evils, you would have lost the opportunity to vote for your favorite candidate. but if you did, you wouldn't have won the election. you'd have lost your chance to vote.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure how you feel about the 'affect the election' argument, but i think it's important to remember that it's not just a matter of 'wasting a vote', it's also about whether or not it's worth it. if you don't vote for a third party candidate, then you're voting for the lesser of two evils.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's irrational to vote for the lesser of two evils, but i do think it is irrational to not vote at all. for example, i think that if you don't vote for hillary, you are voting for a candidate who is more likely to win.

conclusion: You should be able to report disability fraud anonymously
premises: the reason the government wants you to provide your information is because the burden of proof is on the accuser. if the accusation is not true, the accuser can be charged with making a false accusation. the government also claims that the person you accuse will not be notified who reported them. on the reason explanation, the burden of proof should not be on the accuser. under the current system, you are not allowed to report suspicious activity. if an accuser's neighbor receives disability for a bad back, and sees him doing yard work and playing golf, the accuser can not know 100 that he is committed fraud. however, the accuser can make a judgment that something does not seem right, and the accuser would like the government to take a look. this is not unreasonable. from the s. s website gt; typically you would have to know someone quite well in order to determine whether or not he or she is taking advantage of the system. if you know someone as well as s. s wants you to, the accuser would need to practically live with the accused. the burden of proof is too high, and the punishments for false accusations are too strong. on the latter, i cannot see why or how this is true. it may not be the procedure to release the information to the accused, but if it goes to court, it has to be part of the discovery. there will be the information of the accuser in the government files, and if the accused fought hard enough he will get it. however, if the accused really cannot know who accused them, why demand the information at all. the benefits of staying anonymous is obvious. someone sees someone committing fraud, reports it to the proper authorities, and goes about their lives with 0 concern. my current situation is i work with someone who's husband collects disability for disease. he is a drug user, in a motorcycle gang, and works an under the table job that pays him good money. the wife i work with makes over 80k per year. but if i am wrong, what happens to me? i face charges? will his wife find out via our workplace than the s. s office is charging me, than tell her 1 husband about? it is not worth my risks

conclusion: My roommate, who is away for a month, should still pay all flat rate bills for that month
premises: my bills are internet, gas, water, electric, and rent. i have two chief arguments for this. first, him being away does not affect these at all. if i were not living here too, then he would still have to pay all of these fees. by agreeing with these companies to have these services, he locked us into paying at least x per month in service fees. even if we decided that we no longer need water and stopped using it, we would still have to pay these fees for a year. therefore, him not using these services should have no bearing on whether or not he pays the service fees. this is assuming that we mutually agreed to these service, which we did. i would not use this argument if i had purchased cable tv that he did not want to begin with. second, these fees would have to be paid if i also left. for example, if i happened to plan a month long vacation at the same time, we would both be away and both not using these services. however, someone would have to pay the bills. by assuming his argument true, neither of us are responsible for the bills. yet, they must be paid by someone. therefore, using proof by contradiction, i must be correct.

conclusion: The USA should bring back compulsory service
premises: all would be required to serve for some x amount of years. serving in the military should still be available as an option but other accommodations should be made for differing beliefs. if you feel alright about us foreign policy you can do x years in the military, but if you are opposed to it you could do x year serving as a policeman. if you're a pacifist you could do x years serving as an emt for some public hospital or x years in the peace corps. forcing people to serve together in this way would accomplish a couple things: 1 ensures that well trained citizenry is always nearby and ready in case of catastrophe. in a world with this type of service, if a terrorist attack were to occur: 1 4 of all people in the vicinity will be trained soldiers, 1 4 will be trained police, 1 to 2 4 will have some medical training. first responders would already be there because everybody would basically be a first responder. 2 provides young people with something to do. in my mind the service would occur in the 18 22 time frame so that it comes before college. i don't know about any of you but i was someone who went to college because that was just the thing to do. no one had gone before me and that was the route to success, so there i went. it worked for me the debt was real but i got solid job out of it but it doesn't work out for a lot of folks. not only that but asking an 18 year old to decide the institution and career that may define the rest of their lives and saddle them with a mountain of debt seems insane to me. who the fuck knows anything at 18? 3 increases national unity. soldiers peace corp should serve with others from across the country, while police emts should work in parts of the city different form where they live. doing this ensures that all americans are for at least some short time in their lives forced to reckon with their fellow countrymen. besides providing perspective this also helps foster a sense of egalitarianism since it will provide the sense that a citizenship has been 'earned. ' recognition of valid service provides a sort of floor of respectability, which is something that seems sorely lacking these days. 4 it is a project that is unachievable in the free market. while one can imagine how organizations such as the ymca given the proper incentives could establish a role in a society as a pre college and service like pillar, it comes with some tricky issues. a private institution training soldiers and policemen is a break in the government monopoly on violence which i think most people agree is necessary for a functional government . a private institution is accountable to whoever funds it, moral or no, while a public institution would at least by law be held accountable to the voters. and the idea of charging money for things that the peace corps does just seems wrong. so, cmv. tbh i've always been okay with the idea of a draft in it's most raw form but i figure this might make it more palatable for people who don't.
argument: The USA should bring back compulsory service : all would be required to serve for some x amount of years. serving in the military should still be available as an option but other accommodations should be made for differing beliefs. if you feel alright about us foreign policy you can do x years in the military, but if you are opposed to it you could do x year serving as a policeman. if you're a pacifist you could do x years serving as an emt for some public hospital or x years in the peace corps. forcing people to serve together in this way would accomplish a couple things: 1 ensures that well trained citizenry is always nearby and ready in case of catastrophe. in a world with this type of service, if a terrorist attack were to occur: 1 4 of all people in the vicinity will be trained soldiers, 1 4 will be trained police, 1 to 2 4 will have some medical training. first responders would already be there because everybody would basically be a first responder. 2 provides young people with something to do. in my mind the service would occur in the 18 22 time frame so that it comes before college. i don't know about any of you but i was someone who went to college because that was just the thing to do. no one had gone before me and that was the route to success, so there i went. it worked for me the debt was real but i got solid job out of it but it doesn't work out for a lot of folks. not only that but asking an 18 year old to decide the institution and career that may define the rest of their lives and saddle them with a mountain of debt seems insane to me. who the fuck knows anything at 18? conclusion: The N-word is overly stigmatized and should be used freely in certain settings (such as academics)
premises: i'll preface this by saying: for those of you that don't know, the n word refers to 'nigger'. i'll simply refer to the term by 'nword' from here on out to avoid offending people. and although i may share this view on other euphemisms, i'll strictly be discussing the nword to keep the conversation scope narrow. when discussing the root origins of the word, people fear speaking it out loud. even i cringed when i typed out the nword in my first paragraph. stigmatizing the word gives it more power. that's like saying, 'hey! don't remind black people that they were once oppressed slaves! keep it on the hush hush. ' i believe the attitude should instead be more along the lines of, 'blacks should be proud of how empowered they've become despite societal oppression. so keep using it. we don't care because it only shows the leaps and bounds they've made in recent decades. ' we don't use 'the c word' for chink or 'the c word' for cracker. in fact, especially stigmatizing the nword over other racial slurs seems to send a message that other racial slurs are more ok when they should all be equally frowned upon in colloquial language.

gt: if you feel it 'should' be used freely in some cases, why do you self censor all but one time here? if you think it is the best option to self censor to avoid offending , why accuse everyone else of being wrong when they make the same decision you do?

known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that the word 'nigger' is not synonymous with the word itself. the word is used in the context of a racial slur, and when used in a derogatory context, it can be used to refer to a group of people. for example, if a white person calls a black person a nigger, they are not using the word to refer specifically to them. they are using it to refer directly to the white person, or to the black person who is using the n word. this is not to say that they should not use the word, but that they shouldn't be using it. i'm not saying that it should be stigmatized, but i'm saying that people should be able to use it freely in certain contexts.

conclusion: It is unethical to expose your child to video games.
premises: when parents purchase their children playstations, x box's, gaming pcs, etc, i see this is a serious moral failing. i hold this view because of the following intuitions: it decreases the child's attentiveness to school work. it can increase their propensity for violence. it can lead to the development of addictive personality. it decreases the possibility of the child focussing on other more worthwhile pursuits, such as human reading, going outside, learning, etc.
